{"uri": "8219717433", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "03:54:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T03:54:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T03:53:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/darwin-nunez-son-uruguay-brawl-33216494", "title": "Darwin Nunez consoles son in emotional clip as teammate explains brawl in stands", "body": "Darwin Nunez comforted his son after family members of the Uruguay national team were threatened.\n\nUruguay striker Darwin Nunez was seen hugging his young son after stepping in to defend his family who came under threat from Colombia fans.\n\nShortly after Uruguay had been dumped out of Copa America following a 1-0 defeat to Colombia, players were seen rushing to the stands as fights broke out. Liverpool and Uruguay striker Nunez was at the centre of the chaos, and was punched by a rival fan before retaliating.\n\nInitially, it was not clear what sparked the brawl, as Uruguay stars began jumping into the crowd while Colombia players were celebrating their victory on the pitch. But Uruguay defender Jose Maria Gimenez later expressed his side of the story, claiming that Colombia fans started to turn on friends and family of the Uruguay players who were sitting behind the team benches.\n\nGimenez slammed the lack of police presence as the mass brawl erupted in the stands between players, fans, and loved ones moments after the game ended, as he said: \"It was a disaster; there was no police and we had to defend our families.\n\nREAD MORE: Darwin Nunez in huge brawl in stands as Liverpool star hits fans at Copa America\n\nREAD MORE: Virgil van Dijk claims ref's actions at final whistle vs England said it all about penalty\n\n\"This is because of two or three who have one drink too many,\" he added. The crowd at Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte was filled with a Colombia majority, who matched the energy of a hostile Copa America semi-final.\n\nGimenez then stated that the actions of the Uruguay players were forced due to their families being attacked both verbally and physically by a section of Colombia fans. \"A certain sector of the Colombian fans made an avalanche where our loved ones were,\" said Gimenez.\n\nA video then surfaced of Nunez hugging his son on the field, looking visibly emotional after the traumatising incident. A report from Uruguayan outlet El Pais stated that Uruguay players were punched and kicked during the incident, before being led onto the field by security.\n\nThe report claimed that relatives of Uruguay midfielder Manuel Ugarte were hurt during the incident, and he consoled them on the field. The scenes after the game were similar to the events on the field during the 90 minutes, as a fierce semi-final saw eight players shown cards.\n\nFor all the latest on news, politics, sports, and showbiz from the USA, go to The Mirror US.\n\nJefferson Lerma put Colombia ahead after 39 minutes against the run of play, after Nunez had missed two major opportunities to hand Uruguay the lead. Just before half-time Colombia defender Daniel Munoz was then sent off for a second bookable offence, as he elbowed Ugarte in the ribs.\n\nColombia will face Argentina in Sunday's Copa America final after extending their unbeaten run to 28 games after the ugly 1-0 win. Colombia and Argentina have the two largest fan bases in the United States where Copa America is being held, and it's expected that host federation CONMEBOL will ensure there is heightened security {"uri": "8219808424", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "05:20:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T05:20:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T05:20:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.egypttoday.com/Article/8/133413/Colombia-beat-Uruguay-to-reach-Copa-final-players-clash-with", "title": "Colombia beat Uruguay to reach Copa final, players clash with fans", "body": "(Reuters) - Colombia beat Uruguay 1-0 in Wednesday's Copa America semi-final despite playing the second half with only 10 men to set up a title decider against defending champions Argentina, before the night descended into chaos as players clashed with fans.\n\nThe semi-final in Charlotte, North Carolina ended with Uruguayan players confronting Colombian fans in the stands as security personnel struggled to restore order. South American governing body CONMEBOL said it was investigating the incident.\n\nWith the majority of the 70,000-plus crowd cheering on Colombia from the start, Jefferson Lerma scored the winner after Uruguay forward Darwin Nunez had missed three good opportunities to put his side ahead.\n\nThe Liverpool striker had a great chance in the box in the 17th minute but curled his effort inches wide before a scuffed shot and another curling strike failed to find the target as he sat on his haunches wondering how he had missed.\n\nUruguay were made to pay for those missed chances when Lerma rose above the defence at a corner and squeezed his header past goalkeeper Sergio Rochet as James Rodriguez claimed his sixth assist of the tournament.\n\n\"We played an excellent match. The referee was not good... The match was very complicated, against a very tough opponent,\" said Rodriguez, who broke Argentine Lionel Messi's record of five assists in a single edition of the Copa America.\n\n\"But we achieved a well-deserved final. I've been here for almost 13 years, wanting this. We are happy.\"\n\nThe game took a turn in first-half stoppage time when Colombia right back Daniel Munoz elbowed Manuel Ugarte in the chest when play was stopped and picked up a second booking.\n\nWith Uruguay dominating possession in the second half, manager Marcelo Bielsa threw on Luis Suarez in the 67th minute and the veteran striker nearly scored moments later, the 37-year-old's shot hitting the post as he sank to his knees in frustration.\n\nColombia had a golden opportunity to seal the win in the 88th minute when they won the ball back in Uruguay's box but Mateus Uribe sent his low shot wide.\n\nColombia fans were left in disbelief when Uribe saw another shot deflect off the keeper and cannon off the crossbar in added time.\n\nDespite those misses Colombia held on for victory, extending their unbeaten run to a national record 28 games and reaching their first final since 2001 when they won their only title.\n\n\"I would have preferred to avoid the sending off of the Colombian player,\" Bielsa said.\n\n\"What happened in the second half, given the way in which Colombia had to play to maintain their situation with one man down, created greater challenges than the ones we were facing when they were 11.\"\n\nColombia face Argentina in Florida on Sunday while Uruguay stay in Charlotte for the third-place playoff against Canada on Saturday. It is Uruguay's best Copa performance since their last title win in 2011.\n\nArgentina are tied with Uruguay on 15 Copa titles and will own the record outright if they beat Colombia at Miami Gardens.\n\nAfter the game, videos showed what appeared to be Uruguay players wading into the stands to exchange blows with Colombia fans as police personnel tried to keep the two sides apart.", "https://www.egypttoday.com/siteimages/larg/20240711081003103.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9723292", "eventUri": "eng-9723292", "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": {"uri": "8220492807", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "12:50:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T12:50:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T12:49:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.nationalaccordnewspaper.com/colombia-beat-uruguay-to-reach-copa-final-players-clash-with-fans/", "title": "Colombia beat Uruguay to reach Copa final, players clash with fans  --  National Accord Newspaper", "body": "Colombia beat Uruguay 1-0 in Wednesday's Copa America semi-final in spite playing the second half with only 10 men.\n\nThe victory for Colombia meant they set up a title decider against defending champions Argentina, before the night descended into chaos as players clashed with fans.\n\nThe semi-final in Charlotte, North Carolina ended with Uruguayan players confronting Colombian fans in the stands as security personnel struggled to restore order.\n\nSouth American governing body CONMEBOL said it was investigating the incident.\n\nWith the majority of the 70,000-plus crowd cheering on Colombia from the start, Jefferson Lerma scored the winner.\n\nThis was after Uruguay forward Darwin Nunez had missed three good opportunities to put his side ahead.\n\nThe Liverpool striker had a great chance in the box in the 17th minute but curled his effort inches wide before a scuffed shot.\n\nAnother curling strike failed to find the target as he sat on his haunches wondering how he had missed.\n\nUruguay were made to pay for those missed chances when Lerma rose above the defence at a corner and squeezed his header past goalkeeper Sergio Rochet.\n\nJames Rodriguez who provided the pinpoint cross for Lerma claimed his sixth assist of the tournament.\n\n\"We played an excellent match. The referee was not good...\n\n\"The match was very complicated, against a very tough opponent,\" said Rodriguez, who broke Argentine Lionel Messi's record of five assists in a single edition of the Copa America.\n\n\"But we achieved a well-deserved final. I've been here for almost 13 years, wanting this. We are happy.\"\n\nThe game took a turn in first-half stoppage time when Colombia right back Daniel Munoz elbowed Manuel Ugarte in the chest when play was stopped and picked up a second booking.\n\nWith Uruguay dominating possession in the second half, manager Marcelo Bielsa threw on Luis Suarez in the 67th minute and the veteran striker nearly scored moments later.\n\nThe 37-year-old's shot hitting the post as he sank to his knees in frustration.\n\nColombia had a golden opportunity to seal the win in the 88th minute when they won the ball back in Uruguay's box but Mateus Uribe sent his low shot wide.\n\nColombia fans were left in disbelief when Uribe saw another shot deflect off the keeper and cannon off the crossbar in added time.\n\nIn spite those misses, Colombia held on for victory, extending their unbeaten run to a national record 28 games and reaching their first final since 2001 when they won their only title.\n\n\"I would have preferred to avoid the sending off of the Colombian player,\" Bielsa said.\n\n\"What happened in the second half, given the way in which Colombia had to play to maintain their situation with one man down, created greater challenges than the ones we were facing when they were 11.\"\n\nColombia face Argentina in Florida on Sunday while Uruguay stay in Charlotte for the third-place playoff against Canada on Saturday. It is Uruguay's best Copa performance since their last title win in 2011.\n\nArgentina are tied with Uruguay on 15 Copa titles and will own the record outright if they beat Colombia at Miami Gardens.\n\nAfter the game, videos showed what appeared to be Uruguay players wading into the stands to exchange blows with Colombia fans as police personnel tried to keep the two sides apart. {"uri": "8219731392", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "04:08:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T04:08:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T04:08:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.aninews.in/news/sports/football/copa-america-nunez-uruguay-players-brawl-with-colombia-fans-captain-gimenez-claims-players-defending-their-families20240711092250/", "title": "Copa America: Nunez, Uruguay players brawl with Colombia fans, captain Gimenez claims players defending their families", "body": "Charlotte [US], July 11 (ANI): A scuffle broke out between Uruguay players and Colombia fans after the Copa America semi-final at Bank of America Stadium.\n\nColombia punched their ticket to the final against Argentina after Jefferson Lerma headed the ball into the back of the net following a cross from James Rodriguez in the 39th minute of the game. Despite going down to 10 men, Lerma's sole goal was enough to secure a win for Colombia over Uruguay.\n\nAfter the final whistle blew, a scuffle broke out in the stands between the fans and Uruguay players.\n\nIn the video that went viral on social media, Liverpool striker Darwin Nunez and some Uruguay players allegedly climbed into the stands, had an altercation and clashed with each other. Nunez was allegedly at the forefront of the incident.\n\nFox Soccer posted a video on X of the entire incident, and their commentary team described the incident by saying, \"Uruguay players going into the stand and interacting, with if you will Colombian supporters, you obviously see things being thrown including fists, punches, beverages and garbage.\"\n\nESPN reported that South American football's governing body CONMEBOL, the organizers of the Copa, is investigating the entire incident.\n\nWhile speaking about the entire incident, Uruguay captain Jose Maria Gimenez said that the players were trying to defend their families.\n\n\"Let me say something before they cut you off because they won't let us speak into the microphone, \"they don't want me to say anything about what's going on, but this is a disaster,\" Gimenez said on the official broadcast, as quoted from ESPN.\n\n\"Please be careful, our families are in the stands, there are little newborn babies. It was a disaster; there was no police, and we had to defend our families. This is the fault of two or three people who had a few too many drinks and don't know how to drink,\" he added.\n\nAfter their 1-0 loss against Colombia, Uruguay will face Canada in the third-place playoff on Saturday. {"uri": "2024-07-418167005", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "05:05:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T05:05:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T04:02:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.reuters.com/sports/soccer/ten-man-colombia-edge-uruguay-1-0-book-copa-america-final-against-argentina-2024-07-11/", "title": "Colombia beat Uruguay to reach Copa final, players clash with fans", "body": "CHARLOTTE, North Carolina, July 10 (Reuters) - Colombia beat Uruguay 1-0 in Wednesday's Copa America semi-final despite playing the second half with only 10 men to set up a title decider against defending champions Argentina, before the night descended into chaos as players clashed with fans.\n\nThe semi-final in Charlotte, North Carolina ended with Uruguayan players confronting Colombian fans in the stands as security personnel struggled to restore order. South American governing body CONMEBOL said it was investigating the incident.\n\nWith the majority of the 70,000-plus crowd cheering on Colombia from the start, Jefferson Lerma scored the winner after Uruguay forward Darwin Nunez had missed three good opportunities to put his side ahead.\n\nThe Liverpool striker had a great chance in the box in the 17th minute but curled his effort inches wide before a scuffed shot and another curling strike failed to find the target as he sat on his haunches wondering how he had missed.\n\nUruguay were made to pay for those missed chances when Lerma rose above the defence at a corner and squeezed his header past goalkeeper Sergio Rochet as James Rodriguez claimed his sixth assist of the tournament.\n\n\"We played an excellent match. The referee was not good... The match was very complicated, against a very tough opponent,\" said Rodriguez, who broke Argentine Lionel Messi's record of five assists in a single edition of the Copa America.\n\n\"But we achieved a well-deserved final. I've been here for almost 13 years, wanting this. We are happy.\"\n\nMUNOZ SEES RED\n\nThe game took a turn in first-half stoppage time when Colombia right back Daniel Munoz elbowed Manuel Ugarte in the chest when play was stopped and picked up a second booking.\n\nWith Uruguay dominating possession in the second half, manager Marcelo Bielsa threw on Luis Suarez in the 67th minute and the veteran striker nearly scored moments later, the 37-year-old's shot hitting the post as he sank to his knees in frustration.\n\nColombia had a golden opportunity to seal the win in the 88th minute when they won the ball back in Uruguay's box but Mateus Uribe sent his low shot wide.\n\nColombia fans were left in disbelief when Uribe saw another shot deflect off the keeper and cannon off the crossbar in added time.\n\nDespite those misses Colombia held on for victory, extending their unbeaten run to a national record 28 games and reaching their first final since 2001 when they won their only title.\n\n\"I would have preferred to avoid the sending off of the Colombian player,\" Bielsa said.\n\n\"What happened in the second half, given the way in which Colombia had to play to maintain their situation with one man down, created greater challenges than the ones we were facing when they were 11.\"\n\nColombia face Argentina in Florida on Sunday while Uruguay stay in Charlotte for the third-place playoff against Canada on Saturday. It is Uruguay's best Copa performance since their last title win in 2011.\n\nArgentina are tied with Uruguay on 15 Copa titles and will own the record outright if they beat Colombia at Miami Gardens.\n\nAfter the game, videos showed what appeared to be Uruguay players wading into the stands to exchange blows with Colombia fans as police personnel tried to keep the two sides apart.\n\nReporting by Rohith Nair in Bengaluru, additional reporting by Field Level Media; Editing by Peter Rutherford", "source": {"uri": "reuters.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Reuters"}, {"uri": "8219786730", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "05:02:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T05:02:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T05:01:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/sport/football/article/3270026/liverpools-darwin-nunez-uruguay-teammates-brawl-fans-after-copa-america-defeat", "title": "Liverpool's Darwin Nunez, Uruguay teammates brawl with fans after Copa defeat", "body": "Television footage showed the striker hitting Colombian supporters as his teammates moved to protect \u2018loved ones\u2019 after a heated semi-final\n\nLiverpool star Darwin Nunez and about a dozen Uruguay teammates were involved in a brawl with Colombian fans that erupted after their 1-0 Copa America semi-final defeat.\n\nAfter a physical and contentious match, a melee broke out behind the Uruguay bench after Mexican referee Cesar Ramos\u2019 final whistle.\n\nThe crowd of 70,644 at Charlotte\u2019s Bank of America Stadium was about 90 per cent in favour in Colombia, but a small patch of Uruguay fans fought with Colombia supporters as beverages were thrown.\n\nThere was no segregation between Colombia fans and their Uruguayan counterparts.\n\nNunez and teammates had climbed a staircase into the crowd, and television footage showed the Uruguay striker unleashing a flurry of punches at Colombian supporters after jumping into the spectator seating.\n\nUruguay players have entered the stands and a fight has broken out between fans and players pic.twitter.com/XRbte2ibiy\n\n\u2014 FOX Soccer (@FOXSoccer) July 11, 2024\n\nSeveral other Uruguay players climbed into the crowd, seemingly to protect them, with Nunez prominent among them.\n\nIt took more than 10 minutes for police to restore order. The public address announcer asked for fans to leave the stadium, but several supporters remained.\n\nUruguay central defender Jose Maria Gimenez said players had leapt into the melee out of concern for the safety of family members and loved ones watching the game.\n\n\u201cThis is a disaster. Our families were in danger. We had to go to the stands to take out our loved ones, with tiny newborn babies,\u201d the Atletico Madrid player said.\n\n\u201cThere was not a single police officer \u2026 I hope those who are organising this are a little more careful with the families. Every game it\u2019s been happening because there are people who don\u2019t know how to handle a couple of drinks.\u201d\n\nAbout 100 Uruguayan fans and members of the federation staff remained on the field more than 20 minutes after the game, while Colombia fans made their way out to celebrate.\n\nUgly scenes also broke out on the field after the final whistle, with players and staff from both teams involved in a mass melee in the centre-circle following Colombia\u2019s victory.\n\nJefferson Lerma scored the winner in the 39th minute for Colombia, who played with a man less for the entire second half but held on to reach their first final since winning their only Copa title as hosts in 2001.\n\nIn a contentious match that included seven yellow cards and one red, Daniel Munoz was sent off in first-half stoppage time for his second yellow card.\n\nThe Colombians, who extended their unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games \u2013 the longest current streak in men\u2019s international football \u2013 will play against defending champions Argentina in the final in Florida.\n\nLionel Messi\u2019s Albiceleste are seeking a record 16th Copa title and are looking to join Spain from 2008-12 as the only countries to win three straight major championships.\n\nUruguay stay in Charlotte to meet Canada in Saturday night\u2019s third-place match.", "source": {"uri": Colombia will meet Lionel Messi's Argentina in the final of the continental tournament in Miami on Sunday.\n\nThe Colombian players were left in tears as they celebrated the sensational victory in front of thousands of fans, who traveled to Charlotte and filled the stands. James Rodriguez's emotional celebration was reflective of the mood in the camp as Colombia worked their way through to their first Copa America final since 2001. Colombia will defend their 28-game unbeaten run -- the longest in their football history -- when they meet defending champions and pre-tournament favourites Argentina in the big final.\n\nColombia managed to hold on to the 1-0 lead until the final whistle despite being reduced to 10 men for 45 minutes of the semi-final. Jefferson Lerma put them ahead in the first half with a well-timed header from a corner and the Colombian backline did the rest of the job, making sure Uruguay were constantly under pressure.\n\nUruguay paid the price for being wasteful upfront. Liverpool star Darwin Nunez missed several chances in the first half and Colombia made them pay. It could have easily been game over for Colombia when they were reduced to 10 men just before half-time. Daniel Munoz lost his cool and got himself sent off, with the right back receiving a second yellow card for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the chest when play was stopped.\n\nHowever, Colombia showed incredible grit and determination to hold off Uruguay, who dominated possession in the second half. {"uri": "2024-07-418630206", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "12:23:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T12:23:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T12:19:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.theolympian.com/sports/article289958389.html", "title": "Watch: Uruguay soccer players fight Colombia fans in stands after Copa America loss", "body": "July 11 (UPI) -- Uruguayan players went into the stands and fought with Colombia fans, with some landing punches, after a Copa America semifinal loss in Charlotte, N.C.\n\nThe incident occurred shortly after the final whistle of the 1-0 setback Wednesday at Bank of America Stadium. No. 12 Colombia advanced to face top-ranked Argentina in the Copa America finale.\n\n\"CONMEBOL strongly condemns any act of violence that affects football,\" the tournament organizer said in a statement. \"Our work is based on the conviction that football connects us and unites us, through its positive values.\n\n\"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all their passion into cheering on their teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nWednesday's clash featured 24 foul calls, six yellow cards and a red card. James Rodriguez assisted fellow midfielder Jefferson Lerma for the lone goal in the 39th minute.\n\nAfter the gritty game, several Uruguay and Colombia staff members and players -- including Uruguayan Luis Suarez -- met at midfield for a brief skirmish, which eventually disolved.\n\nCameras then panned to the stands, showing several Uruguay players, including striker Darwin Nunez, exchanging blows with fans in the stands. Another video showed Nunez attempting to throw a chair at the Colombia supporters before he entered the seating area.\n\nUruguay players and Uruguayan Football Association president Ignacio Alonso later claimed that the players were defending family members seated in the area. Several children wearing Uruguay apparel could be seen being passed down from the stands to team staff members and players as the skirmish continued.\n\nPolice eventually intervened and resolved the matter. Video footage showed several punches landed, including one on Nunez. Blood could also be seen on the faces of several participants.\n\n\"This is a disaster,\" Uruguay captain Jose Maria Gimenez told reporters. \"Our family was in danger. We had to go to the stands to take out our loved ones, with tiny newborn babies.\n\n\"There was not a single police officer. ... I hope those who are organizing this are a little more careful with the families. Every game it's been happening because there are people who don't know how to handle a couple of drinks.\"\n\nColombia will meet Argentina in the Copa America finale at 8 p.m. EDT Sunday at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla. The game will air on Fox.\n\nNo. 14 Uruguay will take on No. 48 Canada in the Copa America third-place match at 8 p.m. Saturday in Charlotte. {"uri": "8219693530", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "03:26:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T03:26:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T03:25:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/football/story/copa-america-uruguay-players-fight-colombia-fans-darwin-nunez-punch-video-stands-2565090-2024-07-11", "title": "Uruguay star Darwin Nunez punches Colombia fans in ugly fight at Copa America", "body": "A fight broke out between Uruguay players and a section of hostile Colombia fans at the Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte on Thursday after the Copa America semi-final between the two teams. Liverpool star Darwin Nunez was among the ones who were seen punching fans in the stands during the ugly post-match scenes. Fans were seen hurling caps, cans, and punches at the Uruguay players, who were making their way back to the changing room after a disappointing loss in the last-eight match.\n\nIn a video shot by one of the fans at the Bank of America Stadium, Darwin Nunez can be seen getting irked by chants from Colombian fans before he enters the stands and throws punches at a few of them. Barcelona's Ronald Araujo and Atletico Madrid's Jose Maria Gimenez were also seen standing alongside Nunez when the fight broke out. Security officials and police officers rushed to calm the situation down and escort the players away from the scene. A few players, including Nunez, returned to the field and met their families, who reportedly were abused by a section of fans.\n\nAlso Read: 10-man Colombia beat Uruguay, to face Argentina in final\n\nUruguay captain Gimenez lashed out at the security situation in Charlotte, saying the players feared for the well-being of their families, pointing fingers at hostile behaviour from Colombia fans, who dominated the stands on Thursday.\n\n\"It's a total disaster. There wasn't a single police officer. They showed up half an hour later. A disaster. And we were there, standing up for ourselves, for our loved ones,\" Gimenez told the broadcasters after the match.\n\n\"Our families are suffering because of some people who have a few drinks and don't know how to drink, who act like children. Hopefully, they'll take more precautions for the next game so this doesn't happen again, because this is a disaster,\" he added.\n\nNunez, who looked shaken after the incident, was cooled by his Liverpool teammate Luis Diaz and veteran Luis Suaraz.\n\nIt was a disappointing evening for Nunez and Uruguay as they paid the price for not being clinical with their chances in the Copa America semi-final. Nunez missed three good opportunities to put Uruguay in the lead in the first half before Colombia took the lead in the 39th minute after Jefferson Lerma headed a corner into the net.\n\nColombia were down to 10 men after Daniel Munoz was sent off after a second yellow for elbowing Uruguy's Manuel Ugarte in the chest. {"uri": "8219684200", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "03:15:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T03:15:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T03:14:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/sports/football-news/uruguay-vs-colombia-copa-america-semi-final-score-result-highlights-13791705.html", "title": "Copa America: 10-man Colombia stun Uruguay to reach final against Lionel Messi, Argentina", "body": "Colombian players celebrates after defeating Uruguay in Copa America semifinal match. AP\n\nTen-man Colombia stunned Uruguay 1-0 to reach the final of the 2024 Copa America after a high-octane semi-final on Wednesday. This is Colombia's first final in 23 years and they reached there with a 39th-minute Jefferson Lerma header.\n\nThe Colombians will now face holders Argentina in Sunday's final in Miami.\n\nIt was an anarchic semi-final played in front of a packed and passionate crowd which ended with scuffles on the field and fighting in the stands, including several players who had climbed in among supporters amid the flying punches.\n\nColombia, despite having Daniel Munoz sent off just before the interval and facing plenty of Uruguay pressure, hung on for a famous victory to the delight of their massive following of fans.\n\nThe downtown streets of the North Carolina city were packed with partying fans in bright yellow Colombia jerseys hours before the kick-off.\n\nInside the 74,800 capacity Bank of America Stadium, it was like a home game in Bogota with only pockets of Uruguayan supporters breaking up the wall of yellow on all four sides of the venue.\n\nNot surprisingly in such an atmosphere, Colombia started strongly with their livewire Liverpool winger Luis Diaz doing well to wriggle some space for a cross on the left, finding Daniel Munoz at the back post but the full-back's header was off target.\n\nUruguay were, as always, a threat on the counter-attack and their Liverpool star, Darwin Nunez, was close to finishing off one break when Rodrigo Bentancur found him with a clever pass but the forward poked his shot wide.\n\nNunez had another opening when Maximiliano Araujo played him clear in the inside-right channel but the striker rushed his shot, blasting high and wide.\n\nAt the other end, Colombia forced a turnover which led to James Rodriguez curling in a cross from the right but Jhon Cordoba's header was off target.\n\nLerma breakthrough\u00c2\n\nThe breakthrough came in the 39th minute when Lerma rose majestically above Jose Maria Gimenez and powerfully headed home Rodriguez's corner.\n\nIt was the sixth assist of the tournament for Rodriguez with the former Real Madrid midfielder beating the record for most assists in a single Copa, which was set by Lionel Messi in 2021.\n\nColombia looked to make the most of their momentum with Richard Rios forcing a save out of Uruguay keeper Sergio Rochet, after being played in by Munoz.\n\nBut having been so influential down the right in the opening half, Munoz lost his head completely, just before the break, picking up a second yellow card, after landing an elbow on Manuel Ugarte.\n\nIt was a moment of madness which left Colombia to defend their lead with just 10 men for the entire second half.\n\nColombia coach Nestor Lorenzo took off Rodriguez, who was also on a yellow card, in the 62nd minute as Uruguay gradually began to turn their numerical advantage into real pressure.\n\nNicolas de la Cruz threatened with a low drive before substitute Luis Suarez clipped the outside of the post with a drive from the edge of the box after good work from Federico Valverde.\n\nValverde, the Real Madrid midfielder, then went close himself with a low drive as Colombia's back-line continued to ride their luck.\n\nGiveaway from Uruguay keeper and fell to Mateus Uribe, who despite time and space placed his shot wide of the post.\n\nIn stoppage time Uruguay had a great chance to force penalties when Nunez laid the ball off to substitute Giorgian de Arrascaeta on the edge of the box but he leaned back and put his shot over the bar.\n\nThere was still time for Uribe to waste another chance to make sure of the win, this time hitting the bar in the final minute, but he will be forgiven his wastefulness by the delirious Colombian supporters.\n\nThe celebrations were marred by ugly scenes in the stands will concern organizers CONMEBOL ahead of a final which is sure to attract huge numbers of Argentines as well as Colombians.", "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Firstpost"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Liverpool forward Darwin Nunez is seen to be at the center of it.\n\nNunez and teammates climbed a staircase into the crowd, the Associated Press reported. It took more than 10 minutes for police to restore order. {"uri": "2024-07-418288836", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "07:26:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T07:26:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T04:15:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://theprint.in/sport/soccer-colombia-beat-uruguay-to-reach-copa-final-players-clash-with-fans/2169586/", "title": "Soccer-Colombia beat Uruguay to reach Copa final, players clash with fans", "body": "With the majority of the 70,000-plus crowd cheering on Colombia from the start, Jefferson Lerma scored the winner after Uruguay forward Darwin Nunez had missed three good opportunities to put his side ahead.\n\nThe Liverpool striker had a great chance in the box in the 17th minute but curled his effort inches wide before a scuffed shot and another curling strike failed to find the target as he sat on his haunches wondering how he had missed.\n\nUruguay were made to pay for those missed chances when Lerma rose above the defence at a corner and squeezed his header past goalkeeper Sergio Rochet as James Rodriguez claimed his sixth assist of the tournament.\n\n\"We played an excellent match. The referee was not good... The match was very complicated, against a very tough opponent,\" said Rodriguez, who broke Argentine Lionel Messi's record of five assists in a single edition of the Copa America.\n\n\"But we achieved a well-deserved final. I've been here for almost 13 years, wanting this. We are happy.\"\n\nMUNOZ SEES RED\n\nThe game took a turn in first-half stoppage time when Colombia right back Daniel Munoz elbowed Manuel Ugarte in the chest when play was stopped and picked up a second booking.\n\nWith Uruguay dominating possession in the second half, manager Marcelo Bielsa threw on Luis Suarez in the 67th minute and the veteran striker nearly scored moments later, the 37-year-old's shot hitting the post as he sank to his knees in frustration.\n\nColombia had a golden opportunity to seal the win in the 88th minute when they won the ball back in Uruguay's box but Mateus Uribe sent his low shot wide.\n\nColombia fans were left in disbelief when Uribe saw another shot deflect off the keeper and cannon off the crossbar in added time.\n\nDespite those misses Colombia held on for victory, extending their unbeaten run to a national record 28 games and reaching their first final since 2001 when they won their only title.\n\n\"I would have preferred to avoid the sending off of the Colombian player,\" Bielsa said.\n\n\"What happened in the second half, given the way in which Colombia had to play to maintain their situation with one man down, created greater challenges than the ones we were facing when they were 11.\"\n\nColombia face Argentina in Florida on Sunday while Uruguay stay in Charlotte for the third-place playoff against Canada on Saturday. It is Uruguay's best Copa performance since their last title win in 2011.\n\nArgentina are tied with Uruguay on 15 Copa titles and will own the record outright if they beat Colombia at Miami Gardens.\n\nAfter the game, videos showed what appeared to be Uruguay players wading into the stands to exchange blows with Colombia fans as police personnel tried to keep the two sides apart.\n\n(Reporting by Rohith Nair in Bengaluru, additional reporting by Field Level Media; Editing by Peter Rutherford)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "ThePrint"}, {"uri": "8219724066", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "04:04:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T04:04:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T04:01:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/3013016-scuffle-erupts-between-uruguay-players-and-colombia-fans-after-copa-america-semi-final", "title": "Scuffle Erupts Between Uruguay Players and Colombia Fans After Copa America Semi-Final | Sports-Games", "body": "A scuffle erupted between Uruguay players and Colombia fans following the Copa America semi-final at Bank of America Stadium. Colombia advanced to the final against Argentina thanks to Jefferson Lerma's goal in the 39th minute, despite being down to 10 men.\n\nAfter the final whistle, chaos ensued in the stands. Video footage circulating on social media showed Liverpool striker Darwin Nunez and other Uruguay players allegedly climbing into the stands and clashing with fans. Nunez appeared to be at the forefront of the altercation.\n\nFox Soccer shared a video on X, with commentators describing the scene as involving \"things being thrown including fists, punches, beverages, and garbage.\" ESPN reported that CONMEBOL, South American football's governing body, is investigating the incident.\n\nUruguay captain Jose Maria Gimenez stated the players were defending their families. \"Our families are in the stands, there are newborn babies. It was a disaster; there was no police, and we had to defend our families,\" Gimenez remarked on the official broadcast, adding that a few drunk individuals were responsible for the chaos.\n\nFollowing their 1-0 loss to Colombia, Uruguay will face Canada in the third-place playoff on Saturday. They now advance to the tournament's final where they will face Lionel Messi-led Argentina in Miami. Colombia played with ten men for the entire second half in their victory over Uruguay after defender Daniel Munoz was shown a red card for elbowing a Uruguayan player just before halftime, having already received a second yellow card.\n\nColombia advanced to their first Copa America final since 2001. They will defend their 28-game unbeaten streak, the longest in their history, against defending champions and tournament favourites Argentina in the final.\n\nALSO ON ABP Live | India Unlikely To Tour Pakistan For 2025 ICC Champions Trophy, BCCI Eyes These Nations As Alternative Venues\n\nDespite being down to 10 men for the entire second half, Colombia maintained their 1-0 lead until the final whistle in the semi-final. The match was highly physical, with players frequently pushing and shoving each other, leading to seven yellow cards and one red card.\n\nALSO ON ABP Live | ENG vs NED Euro 2024 Semifinal: England Overcome Netherlands With Watkins' Late Goal To Reach Euro 2024 Final\n\nMateus Uribe missed two crucial chances, one in the 85th minute and another in extra time, failing to capitalise on open opportunities to score a second goal. {"uri": "8220090620", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "08:49:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T08:49:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T08:48:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.osundefender.com/copa-america-nunez-uruguay-players-fight-colombian-fans-after-loss/", "title": "Copa America: Nunez, Uruguay Players Fight Colombian Fans After Loss - OsunDefender", "body": "There was a brawl on Wednesday night after the semi-final match between Uruguay and Colombia in the ongoing Copa America.\n\nLiverpool star, Darwin Nunez, and other Uruguay players fought with Colombian fans who were said to have attacked the players' family.\n\nUruguay suffered a 1-0 defeat with Colombia progressing to face Argentina in the final.\n\nUruguay central defender Jose Maria Gimenez said players had leapt into the melee out of concern for the safety of family members and loved ones watching the game.\n\n\"This is a disaster. Our family was in danger. We had to go to the stands to take out our loved ones, with tiny newborn babies,\" the Atletico Madrid player said.\n\n\"There was not a single police officer... I hope those who are organising this are a little more careful with the families.\n\n\"Every game it's been happening because there are people who don't know how to handle a couple of drinks.\"\n\nThe overwhelming majority of the spectators in the crowd were supporting Colombia but there was no segregation between them and their Uruguayan counterparts.\n\nSeveral Uruguay players climbed into the crowd, seemingly to protect fans, with Nunez prominent.\n\nThe fighting continued for several minutes until police finally intervened.\n\nA group of around 80-100 Uruguayan fans remained in the stadium, on the pitch, long after the rest of the fans had left with Uruguay players returning to the field to meet them.\n\nUgly scenes also broke out on the field after the final whistle, with players and staff from both teams involved in a mass melee in the centre circle following Colombia's victory.\n\nCONMEBOL, the South American football confederation which organises the Copa America, issued a statement condemning the incidents.\n\n\"CONMEBOL strongly condemns any acts of violence that affect football. Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values.\n\n\"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the pitch. {"uri": "2024-07-418136346", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "04:18:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T04:18:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T04:15:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.charlotteobserver.com/sports/soccer/article289952764.html", "title": "10-man Colombia edges Uruguay, advances to Copa America final", "body": "Colombia's unbeaten run survived one of its stiffest tests yet on Wednesday night. Now comes the ultimate test for Los Cafeteros: the Copa America final against defending champion Argentina.\n\nJefferson Lerma headed in James Rodriguez's corner kick late in the first half and 10-man Colombia held on to reach its first Copa America final in 23 years with a 1-0 victory over Uruguay on Wednesday in Charlotte.\n\nColombia, unbeaten in a national-record 28 matches, next heads to Miami Gardens, Fla., for the final against Lionel Messi and Argentina on Sunday.\n\nColombia was considerably the better side on Wednesday for the opening 45 minutes, only to be forced to hold on after Daniel Munoz received his second booking for an elbow thrown into Manuel Ugarte's torso in first-half stoppage time.\n\n\"We were very courageous,\" Colombia manager Nestor Lorenzo said through an interpreter. \"Even when we were one man down, we left two forwards on the pitch to always have an impact and create some danger.\"\n\nLos Cafeteros pushed on through the second half by a significantly pro-Colombian crowd of more than 70,000.\n\nColombia broke its previous record of 27 matches unbeaten set in the early 1990s by a group of players who finished third in the 1993 and 1995 Copa Americas. Colombia's only title came as host in 2001.\n\n\"They gave us a very important legacy,\" Lorenzo said of that early '90s team. \"They left it for us, and that was the foundation for Colombia football.\"\n\nColombia technically could add to its run without winning the title, since losing the final on penalties would count in the record books as a draw.\n\nRodriguez now has six assists, the most in a single Copa America since the stat was first kept in 2011.\n\nUruguay, which won all three of its group-stage games, did not score in either of its knockout-phase matches. The loss to Colombia ended influential manager Marcelo Bielsa's latest bid at a first major title in international play.\n\n\"The match was constantly interrupted, it was constantly stop and start,\" Bielsa lamented of the second half, through an interpreter. \"We should have created more chances and caused damage to the opponent. Even though we had some clear opportunities, we should have generated more goal opportunities than the ones we did.\"\n\nLerma put Colombia in front in the 39th minute after Rodriguez delivered the latest in a tournament full of perfectly struck set pieces.\n\nThis one came from a corner dropped onto Lerma's head at the back post. Lerma outjumped Jose Maria Gimenez to send his header downward, narrowly inside the left post before Uruguay goalkeeper Sergio Rochet could react.\n\nA great start for Los Cafeteros became far more complicated seven minutes later when Munoz rightly received his second caution from referee Cesar Ramos.\n\nUruguay all-time leading scorer Luis Suarez entered in the 67th minute and immediately made his presence felt in the 71st, striking the outside of the right post with a shot from just inside the penalty area.\n\nHowever, the insertion of center back Yerry Mina and switch to a five-man back line by Colombia manager Nestor Lorenzo helped limit Uruguay from there.\n\nColombia's Mateus Uribe missed the game's two best late chances, dragging an 88th-minute opportunity low and wide of the left post and seeing another effort in stoppage time deflect off a charging Rochet and then the crossbar.\n\n\"He is feeling a bit sad because he's a lion on the pitch and wants more,\" Lorenzo said of Uribe. \"I hugged him and I told him without him we wouldn't be where we are, so that he has to hold his head up high.\"\n\nUruguay will remain in Charlotte to face Canada in Saturday's third-place match, in what will be La Celeste's best finish at the tournament since winning the 2011 title. However, Uruguay could be short-handed if CONMEBOL issues punishments in relation to a post-match fight on Wednesday.\n\nAfter a scuffle with Colombian players at the center circle following the final whistle, multiple Uruguayan players wound up fighting fans in the stands. Darwin Nunez and Ronald Araujo were identified by multiple media reports as two of the Uruguayans involved in the melee.\n\nUruguay defender Jose Maria Gimenez said, according to The Athletic, that he The Colombian players were in tears after their victory in the semi-final and celebrated the win with thousands of fans.\n\nJefferson Lerma scored the first goal in the 39th minute of the game for Colombia. Lerma outjumped Uruguay's defence on a corner and squeezed his header past goalkeeper Sergio Rochet.\n\nMunoz received his first yellow card in the 31st minute from the Mexican referee Cesar Ramos for a rash tackle on Maximiliano Araujo and received his second yellow for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the stomach just before halftime.\n\nThe match was physical and players from both sides kept pushing and shoving each other, resulting in seven yellow and one red card. Liverpool star Darwin Nunez missed many chances before Colombia scored their first goal.\n\nUruguay dominated the possession in the second half and the veteran striker Luis Suarez nearly equalised in the 71st minute but the post denied his team's chance to come back in the match and 10-man Colombia held their nerve to book a spot in the final.\n\nEarlier in the first semi-final on Wednesday, Lionel Messi and Julian Alvarez helped Argentina to beat Canada by 2-0 and book their place in another final of the Copa America. Uruguay will now face Canada in the third play-off match on Saturday.\n\nColombia will defend their 28-game unbeaten streak when they will face defending champions Argentina in the big final on "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.01960784313725483, "wgt": 174, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8220245003", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "10:24:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T10:24:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T10:23:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5630799/2024/07/11/uruguay-colombia-copa-america-chaos/", "title": "How Uruguay vs Colombia descended into chaos - and the questions raised by the ugly scenes", "body": "What should have been a showpiece game in the semi-final of the Copa America in Charlotte on Wednesday night descended into something more akin to a bar-room brawl as several Uruguay players, including Darwin Nunez and the captain Jose Maria Gimenez, clashed with Colombia supporters in the stands after the final whistle.\n\nIt was an ugly, chaotic and extraordinary scene that overshadowed a compelling match, raising serious questions about the security arrangements in place at the Bank of America Stadium as well as CONMEBOL's decision to stage a game of this magnitude at a venue that was being used for the first time in the tournament.\n\nAnother match is taking place at the same stadium on Saturday, when Uruguay return for a third-place play-off against Canada, and there will surely need to be an investigation between now and then to establish the full chain of events that led to the unsavoury scenes that were circulating on social media in the aftermath of Colombia's 1-0 victory.\n\nNunez was visibly upset after becoming embroiled in an incident in which punches were traded and objects were thrown in one of the blocks in the lower tier where the families and friends of the Uruguay players were located close to Colombia fans.\n\nThere was a mixture of anger and frustration in the voices of the Uruguay players afterwards.\n\n\"It's a total disaster,\" Gimenez, the Uruguay captain, said. \"There wasn't a single police officer. They showed up half an hour later. A disaster. And we were there, standing up for ourselves, for our loved ones.\n\n\"Hopefully, organisers take a little more precautions with our families, with the people and those around the stadiums. Because this happens every game. Our families are suffering because of some people who have a few drinks and don't know how to drink, who act like children.\"\n\nThe Uruguayan Football Association (AUF) has said it will analyse all the footage before deciding whether to make an official complaint. But it is clear the AUF believes it was an oversight to put the players' friends and families in the same area as Colombia supporters without any sort of partition.\n\n\"I think there should've been some kind of barrier, especially because it was known practically from the beginning of the tournament that the Colombian fans were going to purchase 95 per cent of the tickets and that area (of the stadium) could get complicated,\" Ignacio Alonso, the AUF president, said.\n\nAs for the actions of Nunez, Gimenez and others, Alonso maintained what they did was only to be expected in the circumstances. \"The Uruguayan players reacted instinctively to what is natural: which is to defend and protect the children that were in that part of the stand, the women who were being assaulted, the wives, fathers, children and brothers who were there. It's an instinctive response of a father,\" he added.\n\nThe backdrop to all of this is that emotions had been running high at the stadium all night -- Colombia played the entire second half with 10 men after Daniel Munoz was shown a red card just before the interval -- but it was the final whistle, after seven minutes of stoppage time, that brought the first of two flashpoints.\n\nInitially, there was a melee in the centre circle, where more than 40 players and staff congregated immediately after the game. Some Colombia and Uruguay players embraced one another while others -- Uruguay's Luis Suarez and Colombia's Miguel Borja among them -- became involved in an altercation. There was a lot of pushing and shoving elsewhere but, on the face of it, nothing more sinister than that.\n\nMoments later, though, some of the Uruguay players started to sprint towards the touchline, in an area just to the right of their dugout. At first, it was unclear what was going on, other than that some children wearing Uruguay shirts were being carried out of the lower tier and onto the pitch.\n\nThe videos that emerged later provided a fuller picture and showed Nunez, along with Gimenez and the Barcelona defender Ronald Araujo, climbing up into the stand and angrily confronting Colombia supporters. As everything got more heated, Nunez appeared to be struck by one fan. The Liverpool striker also appeared to throw a punch back.\n\n\"'Some of the players had wives, small children, their parents, older relatives... They went to see how they were doing,\" Suarez said. \"Then those things started to happen, the images that you've seen. They (Nunez, Gimenez and others) were trying to protect their families. From what I saw, there were a lot of relatives and children affected. You're left powerless in that situation.\"\n\nContrary to what Gimenez thought, police officers were present at the scene, albeit they took some time -- more than 60 seconds -- to get the situation under control and needed the help of security personnel.\n\nPrior to that, it had threatened to turn into a free-for-all as other Uruguay players and staff got involved, clambering over seats. Video footage appears to show Rodrigo Bentancur throwing an object of some sort into that area.\n\nAs for Nunez, he was clearly still irate and deeply upset by everything that had happened when he got down from the stand. The forward picked up a chair, ran towards an area where Colombia fans were goading him, and threw it into the wall below, prompting some of the Uruguay substitutes to drag him away.\n\nNunez looked extremely emotional at that point. He was consoled by one of the Uruguay backroom staff on the pitch and also by Suarez and Luis Diaz, the Colombia forward who plays alongside him for Liverpool.\n\nAs the dust started to settle and the fans spilt out of the stadium, there were Uruguay players still on the pitch holding their children. Matias Vina had a baby in his hands at one stage, Nicolas de la Cruz sat with his daughter on his knee on the floor, and Nunez was later pictured with a child on his shoulder.\n\nThe Uruguay players looked like they were in a state of shock as much as anything. \"It was an ugly moment,\" Sergio Rochet, the Uruguay goalkeeper, said. \"It's not nice to see these problems, especially when your family is only two metres away. We are sad to go out of the tournament and now we have to deal with this situation.\n\n\"From what I saw, they (the supporters) started throwing things. You try to stay away from that, but when you see that it's your family, small children, it's difficult. I was surprised by the lack of empathy from the Colombia players. I think they should have come to calm the waters.\"\n\nLike a lot of people in the stadium, the Uruguay manager Marcelo Bielsa had no idea what was going on at first. He said he initially thought his players \"were going to thank the Uruguayan fans for the support. But then I learned that there were other kinds of unfortunate difficulties.\"\n\nAs for CONMEBOL, South American football's governing body issued a statement that made no reference whatsoever to any issues around a lack of organisation at the stadium -- something that was evident in so many ways on Wednesday night -- or safety problems.\n\n\"CONMEBOL strongly condemns any act of violence that affects football,\" it said. \"Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values. There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all their passion into cheering on their national teams and having an unforgettable party.\"", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "stuart_james@nytimes.com", "name": "Stuart James", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": His club are yet to comment but are understood to be trying to reach out to him and the Uruguayan football federation.\n\nLiverpool star Darwin Nunez was involved in a brawl with fans after his Uruguay team were knocked out of the Copa America tournament by Colombia.\n\nUruguay players, including Nunez, went into the stands after violence reportedly broke out in the players' family section.\n\nFootage showed him climbing up railings before confronting Colombia fans as others tried to restrain him, at the end of the match in the US city of Charlotte.\n\nUruguay players said they entered the stands to \"rescue\" their families.\n\nA fracas behind the Uruguay bench saw a group of fans clash with Colombia supporters, who made up the vast majority of the crowd, with drinks thrown in the air.\n\nOrder was restored by police after around 10 minutes with some Uruguayan fans and staff members remaining on the field.\n\nUruguay legend Luis Suarez, who came on as a substitute late in the game, said: \"Obviously if someone is attacking your family you want to go and defend them but that doesn't justify the image that it created.\n\n\"We had to protect our families that were there. {"uri": "8220731451", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "15:28:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T15:28:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T15:25:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/sports/nunez-uruguay-players-brawl-in-stands-with-f-1843053.html", "title": "Nunez, Uruguay Players Brawl In Stands With Fans After Copa Loss - UrduPoint", "body": "Liverpool star Darwin Nunez and other Uruguay players were involved in a brawl with Colombian fans which erupted after their 1-0 Copa America semi-final defeat on Wednesday\n\nCharlotte, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 11th Jul, 2024) Liverpool star Darwin Nunez and other Uruguay players were involved in a brawl with Colombian fans which erupted after their 1-0 Copa America semi-final defeat on Wednesday.\n\nUruguay striker Nunez unleashed a flurry of punches at Colombian supporters after jumping into the spectator seating at Charlotte's Bank of America Stadium following an ill-tempered loss to Colombia.\n\nUruguay central defender Jose Maria Gimenez said players had leapt into the melee out of concern for the safety of family members and loved ones watching the game.\n\n\"This is a disaster. Our family was in danger. We had to go to the stands to take out our loved ones, with tiny newborn babies,\" the Atletico Madrid player said.\n\n\"There was not a single police officer... I hope those who are organising this are a little more careful with the families.\n\n\"Every game it's been happening because there are people who don't know how to handle a couple of drinks.\"\n\nThe overwhelming majority of the spectators in the crowd were supporting Colombia but there was no segregation between them and their Uruguayan counterparts.\n\nSeveral Uruguay players climbed into the crowd, seemingly to protect fans, with Nunez prominent.\n\nThe fighting continued for several minutes until police finally intervened.\n\nA group of around 80-100 Uruguayan fans remained in the stadium, on the pitch, long after the rest of the fans had left with Uruguay players returning to the field to meet them.\n\nUgly scenes also broke out on the field after the final whistle, with players and staff from both teams involved in a mass melee in the centre-circle following Colombia's victory.\n\nCONMEBOL, the South American football confederation which organises the Copa America, issued a statement condemning the incidents.\n\n\"CONMEBOL strongly condemns any acts of violence that affects football. Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values.\n\n\"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the pitch. {"uri": "8219840951", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "05:48:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T05:48:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T05:48:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/sports/soccer/uruguayan-players-brawl-colombia-fans-copa-america-semifinal-loss-rcna161289", "title": "Uruguayan players brawl with Colombia fans following Copa America semifinal loss", "body": "Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez, center, of Uruguay reacts during the CONMEBOL Copa America 2024 semifinal match between Uruguay and Colombia, in Charlotte, N.C., on Wednesday.Buda Mendes / Getty Images\n\nThe second Copa America semifinal took a violent turn Wednesday when Uruguayan players brawled with fans in the stands following their elimination at the hands of Colombia.\n\nCameras captured several players, led by Uruguay's Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez, walking into the stands at Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, North Carolina, and exchanging punches with Colombia fans as security staff tried to hold the players back.\n\nN\u00fa\u00f1ez could be seen throwing several punches. Uruguay defender Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez seemed to throw at least one punch, according to videos verified by NBC News.\n\nIn a post-game interview, Gim\u00e9nez said the brawl stemmed from a \"certain sector of Colombia fans\" who he said \"did an avalanche\" on the families of Uruguayan players. He called on organizers to take more precautions \"because the same thing happens every game.\"\n\n\"This is a disaster. Our families were in danger,\" Gim\u00e9nez said.\n\nIgnacio Alonso, president of the Uruguayan Football Association, told reporters after the game that the Uruguayan players were trying to protect their families.\n\n\"Uruguay's players had an instinctive reaction, which is natural, which is going to defend and protect the children who were on that side of the stands, who were suffering attacks, the women, the parents, the closest family members, siblings,\" he said.\n\nIn a statement, CONMEBOL, South American soccer's governing body, said it \"strongly condemns any act of violence that affects football.\"\n\n\"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field,\" it added.\n\nThe melee followed Uruguay's 1-0 loss to Colombia in a game in which emotions were already high.\n\nJefferson Lerma put Colombia ahead in the 39th minute, but compatriot Daniel Mu\u00f1oz was sent off following a second yellow card after an elbow to Uruguay's Manuel Ugarte. Despite playing with a man advantage for the entirety of the second half, however, Uruguay was unable to find the equalizer and Colombia walked away with the victory.\n\nColombia will now play for the championship against Lionel Messi's Argentina on Sunday at Hard Rock Stadium in Florida. Uruguay, meanwhile, will play for third place Saturday against Canada.", "source": {"uri": "nbcnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8219882886", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "06:21:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T06:21:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T06:21:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/colombia-defeat-uruguay-to-reach-copa-america-final/article_ff847825-1080-5982-b7ae-272af39a44f6.html", "title": "Colombia defeat Uruguay to reach Copa America final", "body": "Colombia midfielder Mateus Uribe fights for the ball with Uruguay forward Darwin Nunez\n\nTen-man Colombia defeated Uruguay 1-0 to reach the final of the Copa America for the first time in 23 years after an ill-tempered semi-final on Wednesday.\n\nA 39th-minute Jefferson Lerma header sealed victory for the Colombians, who will now face holders Argentina in Sunday's final in Miami.\n\nIt was an anarchic semi-final played in front of a packed and passionate crowd which ended with scuffles on the field and fighting in the stands, including several players who had climbed in among supporters amid the flying punches.\n\nColombia, despite having Daniel Munoz sent off just before the interval and facing plenty of Uruguay pressure, hung on for a famous victory to the delight of their massive following of fans.\n\nThe win was the 28th game without defeat for Colombia, setting a new record for the team.\n\nThe downtown streets of the North Carolina city were packed with partying fans in bright yellow Colombia jerseys hours before the kick-off.\n\nNot surprisingly in such an atmosphere, Colombia started strongly with their livewire Liverpool winger Luis Diaz doing well to wriggle some space for a cross on the left, finding Daniel Munoz at the back post but the full-back's header was off target.\n\nUruguay were, as always, a threat on the counter-attack and their Liverpool star, Darwin Nunez, was close to finishing off one break when Rodr go Bentancur found him with a clever pass but the forward poked his shot wide.\n\nNunez had another opening when Maximiliano Araujo played him clear in the inside-right channel but the striker rushed his shot, blasting high and wide.\n\nAt the other end, Colombia forced a turnover which led to James Rodriguez curling in a cross from the right but Jhon Cordoba's header was off target.\n\n- Lerma breakthrough -\n\nThe breakthrough came in the 39th minute when Lerma rose majestically above Jose Maria Gimenez and powerfully headed home Rodriguez's corner.\n\nIt was the sixth assist of the tournament for Rodriguez with the former Real Madrid midfielder beating the record for most assists in a single Copa, which was set by Lionel Messi in 2021.\n\nColombia looked to make the most of their momentum with Richard Rios forcing a save out of Uruguay keeper Sergio Rochet, after being played in by Munoz.\n\nMore from this section Firefighters pump out 50-mile training ride in preparation for fundraising event in Ireland Kathua Terror Attack: Eyewitness Shares Horrific Ordeal, Say There Were Around 8-9 Terrorists| Watch PM Starmer wraps up UK tour after visit to N.Ireland\n\nBut having been so influential down the right in the opening half, Munoz lost his head completely, just before the break, picking up a second yellow card, after landing an elbow on Manuel Ugarte.\n\nIt was a moment of madness which left Colombia to defend their lead with just 10 men for the entire second half.\n\nColombia coach Nestor Lorenzo took off Rodriguez, who was also on a yellow card, in the 62nd minute as Uruguay gradually began to turn their numerical advantage into real pressure.\n\nNicolas de la Cruz threatened with a low drive before substitute Luis Suarez clipped the outside of the post with a drive from the edge of the box after good work from Federico Valverde.\n\nValverde, the Real Madrid midfielder, then went close himself with a low drive as Colombia's back-line continued to ride their luck.\n\nGiveaway from Uruguay keeper and fell to Mateus Uribe, who despite time and space placed his shot wide of the post.\n\nIn stoppage time Uruguay had a great chance to force penalties when Nunez laid the ball off to substitute Giorgian de Arrascaeta on the edge of the box but he leaned back and put his shot over the bar.\n\nThere was still time for Uribe to waste another chance to make sure of the win, this time hitting the bar in the final minute, but he will be forgiven his wastefulness by the delirious Colombian supporters.\n\nUruguay's Argentine coach Marcelo Bielsa took the blame for being unable to craft a win against ten-men in the second half.\n\n\"Uruguay were clearly in a position to win this game...I take special responsibility for not having been able to establish an advantage when we had the players capable of doing so,\" he said.\n\nHis compatriot and counterpart Lorenzo said he and his team had been rewarded for their positive approach to the game.\n\n\"We took the lead, the risk, and we were even brave. When we were down one we kept two strikers...and that is an act of courage that was rewarded,\" he said.\n\nThe celebrations were marred by ugly scenes in the stands will concern organizers CONMEBOL ahead of a final which is sure to attract huge numbers of Argentines as well as Colombians.\n\nsev/rcw", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, {"uri": "8219688877", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "03:19:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T03:19:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T03:19:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpools-darwin-nunez-caught-huge-29518795", "title": "Darwin Nunez involved in brawl with rival fans after Copa America defeat", "body": "Liverpool's popular Uruguay striker Darwin Nunez was embroiled in a fiery brawl as punches were exchanged between him and fans following Uruguay's Copa America exit at the hands of Colombia.\n\nThe tension escalated between the two countries after the final whistle, with Colombia narrowly securing a 1-0 victory courtesy of Jefferson Lerma's header in the 39th minute. Once the on-pitch commotion had subsided, the Uruguay players headed towards the stands, according to The Mirror.\n\nNunez led several Uruguay players into the crowd before hostility erupted from Colombian fans, leading to a large-scale fight between players and spectators. After being hit by a fan, Nunez defended himself, with footage showing him retaliating against multiple supporters.\n\nBarcelona's Ronald Araujo was also caught up in the fracas, with thousands of shocked fans capturing the incident on their phones. Security intervened to separate the two groups, swiftly escorting the Uruguay players towards the changing rooms.\n\nAs reported by Uruguayan publication El Pais, the Uruguay players had entered the crowd to support family members and friends seated behind the team bench. With a predominantly Colombian crowd in the stadium, the relatives of the Uruguay stars were reportedly subjected to abuse.\n\nA melee erupted involving players, officials, and fans after the football game, held at the Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, North Carolina, United States. Team leader Nunez ushered his fellow players into the stands to join their loved ones who had been brought onto the field for safety as tensions continued to rise.\n\nNotably, Jorge Giordano, director of the Uruguay national football team, and press officer Felipe Cotelo found themselves amidst the drama.\n\nReports indicate that Manuel Ugarte, a midfield player from Uruguay, rushed on-field to aid his injured family members amidst the chaos. It's also been noted that certain Uruguay-based supporters didn't walk away unscathed from the incident due to being vastly outnumbered by rival Colombian fans.\n\nJose Maria Gimenez, defender for Team Uruguay, did not mince words about the ordeal; calling it an absolute \"disaster\" and criticising the absence of law enforcement on the grounds. He was quoted saying: \"It was a disaster; there was no police and we had to defend our families.\"\n\nPlacing the blame on a minority of overindulged individuals, he further commented: \"This is because of two or three who have one drink too many. A certain sector of the Colombian fans made an avalanche where our loved ones were,\".\n\nIn the wake of the events, CONMEBOL, the governing body, is set to assess the situation prior to Sunday's highly anticipated Copa America final. The showdown will see Colombia, with their remarkable two-year-long defeat-free run, up against Argentina in Miami.\n\nDespite their impressive stats, Colombia heads into the match as the underdogs.\n\nArgentina are hoping to win a third-straight trophy, after Lionel Messi lifted the Copa America trophy in 2021 before winning the World Cup a year later. Messi had never won an international trophy before 2021, but has the chance to add to his legacy on Sunday in his new home city, after signing for MLS side Inter Miami last year.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8220060558", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "08:28:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T08:28:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T08:28:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://ktbb.com/post/?p=1337912", "title": "Title of the Page", "body": "James Rodr\u00edguez served up his sixth assist of the tournament to help 10-man Colombia beat Uruguay 1-0 in Charlotte, North Carolina, on Wednesday to set up a Copa Am\u00e9rica final against Argentina, before the night descended into chaos as players clashed with fans.\n\nArgentina beat Canada 2-0 in the first semifinal on Tuesday to book their place in Sunday's final in Miami Gardens, Florida.\n\nVictory for Colombia on Wednesday meant they extended their unbeaten run to a team-record 28 games, dating back to a loss to Argentina in February 2022.\n\nIn a contentious match that included seven yellow cards and one red, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle. Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez and about a dozen Uruguay teammates then went into the stands as fans brawled. A video showed N\u00fa\u00f1ez hitting a fan in Colombian team colours.\n\nJefferson Lerma scored the only goal in front of a fervent and overwhelmingly pro-Colombia crowd of 70,644 at Bank of America Stadium when he headed in a deep corner from James in the 39th minute.\n\nJames becomes the first South American player with six assists at a single major tournament since Pel\u00e9 for Brazil at the 1970 World Cup.\n\nColombia's task of maintaining their advantage was complicated when defender Daniel Mu\u00f1oz was sent off in first-half stoppage time after receiving a second yellow card for swinging an elbow at Uruguay's Manuel Ugarte. Mu\u00f1oz received his first yellow card from Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos in the 31st minute for a reckless slide tackle on Maximiliano Ara\u00fajo.\n\nLiverpool striker Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez failed to take advantage of multiple first-half opportunities, with Colombia goalkeeper Camilo Vargas not having to make his first save until he stopped Nicol\u00e1s de la Cruz's attempt in the 68th minute.\n\nSubstitute Luis Su\u00e1rez, Uruguay's career leader with 68 goals, hit the outside of a post with a shot in the 71st as Uruguay struggled to find a breakthrough against the 10 men.\n\nColombia's Mateus Uribe, another second-half sub, put an open shot wide in the 88th, and Uribe's open shot in the fourth minute of stoppage time ricocheted off the body of sliding goalkeeper Sergio Rochet then the crossbar.\n\nBut one goal proved enough for Colombia to reach their third Copa Am\u00e9rica final and first since winning their only title as hosts in 2001.\n\nAfter the game, videos showed Uruguay players wading into the stands to exchange blows with Colombia fans as police personnel tried to keep the two sides apart.\n\nUruguay captain Jose Maria Gimenez said the players were trying to defend their families.\n\n\"Let me say something before they cut you off because they won't let us speak into the microphone, they don't want me to say anything about what's going on but this is a disaster,\" Gimenez said on the official broadcast. \"Please be careful, our families are in the stands, there are little newborn babies. It was a disaster; there was no police and we had to defend our families.\n\nArgentina are seeking a record 16th Copa Am\u00e9rica title and looking to join Spain as the only countries to win three straight major titles.\n\nWednesday's match was played in 90-degree heat on a surface that was converted from artificial turf to grass in the weeks leading up to the contest.\n\nUruguay will face Canada in the third-place playoff on Saturday.\n\nInformation from The Associated Press contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "ktbb.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBB"}, "authors": [],
