{"uri": "8219686244", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "03:17:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T03:17:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T03:16:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.wionews.com/football/ten-man-colombia-edge-past-uruguay-1-0-to-book-copa-america-final-against-argentina-739734", "title": "Ten-man Colombia edge past Uruguay 1-0 to book Copa America final against Argentina", "body": "Colombia, despite having Daniel Munoz sent off just before the interval and facing plenty of Uruguay pressure, hung on for a famous victory to the delight of their massive following of fans.\n\nTen-man Colombia defeated Uruguay 1-0 to reach the final of the Copa America for the first time in 23 years after an ill-tempered semi-final on Wednesday. A 39th-minute Jefferson Lerma header sealed victory for the Colombians, who will now face holders Argentina in Sunday's final in Miami.\n\nIt was an anarchic semi-final played in front of a packed and passionate crowd which ended with scuffles on the field and fighting in the stands, including several players who had climbed in among supporters amid the flying punches.\n\nColombia, despite having Daniel Munoz sent off just before the interval and facing plenty of Uruguay pressure, hung on for a famous victory to the delight of their massive following of fans.\n\nThe downtown streets of the North Carolina city were packed with partying fans in bright yellow Colombia jerseys hours before the kick-off.\n\nInside the 74,800 capacity Bank of America Stadium, it was like a home game in Bogota with only pockets of Uruguayan supporters breaking up the wall of yellow on all four sides of the venue.\n\nNot surprisingly in such an atmosphere, Colombia started strongly with their livewire Liverpool winger Luis Diaz doing well to wriggle some space for a cross on the left, finding Daniel Munoz at the back post but the full-back's header was off target.\n\nUruguay were, as always, a threat on the counter-attack and their Liverpool star, Darwin Nunez, was close to finishing off one break when Rodrigo Bentancur found him with a clever pass but the forward poked his shot wide.\n\nNunez had another opening when Maximiliano Araujo played him clear in the inside-right channel but the striker rushed his shot, blasting high and wide.\n\nAt the other end, Colombia forced a turnover which led to James Rodriguez curling in a cross from the right but Jhon Cordoba's header was off target.\n\nAlso read: Euro 2024: Final minute Watkins goal takes England into final over Netherlands\n\nThe breakthrough came in the 39th minute when Lerma rose majestically above Jose Maria Gimenez and powerfully headed home Rodriguez's corner. It was the sixth assist of the tournament for Rodriguez with the former Real Madrid midfielder beating the record for most assists in a single Copa, which was set by Lionel Messi in 2021.\n\nColombia looked to make the most of their momentum with Richard Rios forcing a save out of Uruguay keeper Sergio Rochet, after being played in by Munoz.\n\nBut having been so influential down the right in the opening half, Munoz lost his head completely, just before the break, picking up a second yellow card, after landing an elbow on Manuel Ugarte.\n\nIt was a moment of madness which left Colombia to defend their lead with just 10 men for the entire second half.\n\nColombia coach Nestor Lorenzo took off Rodriguez, who was also on a yellow card, in the 62nd minute as Uruguay gradually began to turn their numerical advantage into real pressure.\n\nNicolas de la Cruz threatened with a low drive before substitute Luis Suarez clipped the outside of the post with a drive from the edge of the box after good work from Federico Valverde. Valverde, the Real Madrid midfielder, then went close himself with a low drive as Colombia's back-line continued to ride their luck.\n\nGiveaway from Uruguay keeper and fell to Mateus Uribe, who despite time and space placed his shot wide of the post.\n\nIn stoppage time Uruguay had a great chance to force penalties when Nunez laid the ball off to substitute Giorgian de Arrascaeta on the edge of the box but he leaned back and put his shot over the bar.\n\nThere was still time for Uribe to waste another chance to make sure of the win, this time hitting the bar in the final minute, but he final", "body": "MIAMI, July 11 -- Ten-man Colombia defeated Uruguay 1-0 to reach the final of the Copa America for the first time in 23 years after an ill-tempered semi-final on Wednesday.\n\nA 39th-minute Jefferson Lerma header sealed victory for the Colombians, who will now face holders Argentina in Sunday's final in Miami.\n\nIt was an anarchic semi-final played in front of a packed and passionate crowd which ended with scuffles on the field and fighting in the stands, including several players who had climbed in among supporters amid the flying punches.\n\nColombia, despite having Daniel Munoz sent off just before the interval and facing plenty of Uruguay pressure, hung on for a famous victory to the delight of their massive following of fans.\n\nThe win was the 28th game without defeat for Colombia, setting a new record for the team.\n\nThe downtown streets of the North Carolina city were packed with partying fans in bright yellow Colombia jerseys hours before the kick-off.\n\nNot surprisingly in such an atmosphere, Colombia started strongly with their livewire Liverpool winger Luis Diaz doing well to wriggle some space for a cross on the left, finding Daniel Munoz at the back post but the full-back's header was off target.\n\nUruguay were, as always, a threat on the counter-attack and their Liverpool star, Darwin Nunez, was close to finishing off one break when Rodr go Bentancur found him with a clever pass but the forward poked his shot wide.\n\nNunez had another opening when Maximiliano Araujo played him clear in the inside-right channel but the striker rushed his shot, blasting high and wide.\n\nAt the other end, Colombia forced a turnover which led to James Rodriguez curling in a cross from the right but Jhon Cordoba's header was off target.\n\nThe breakthrough came in the 39th minute when Lerma rose majestically above Jose Maria Gimenez and powerfully headed home Rodriguez's corner.\n\nIt was the sixth assist of the tournament for Rodriguez with the former Real Madrid midfielder beating the record for most assists in a single Copa, which was set by Lionel Messi in 2021.\n\nColombia looked to make the most of their momentum with Richard Rios forcing a save out of Uruguay keeper Sergio Rochet, after being played in by Munoz.\n\nBut having been so influential down the right in the opening half, Munoz lost his head completely, just before the break, picking up a second yellow card, after landing an elbow on Manuel Ugarte.\n\nIt was a moment of madness which left Colombia to defend their lead with just 10 men for the entire second half.\n\nColombia coach Nestor Lorenzo took off Rodriguez, who was also on a yellow card, in the 62nd minute as Uruguay gradually began to turn their numerical advantage into real pressure.\n\nNicolas de la Cruz threatened with a low drive before substitute Luis Suarez clipped the outside of the post with a drive from the edge of the box after good work from Federico Valverde.\n\nValverde, the Real Madrid midfielder, then went close himself with a low drive as Colombia's back-line continued to ride their luck.\n\nGiveaway from Uruguay keeper and fell to Mateus Uribe, who despite time and space placed his shot wide of the post.\n\nIn stoppage time Uruguay had a great chance to force penalties when Nunez laid the ball off to substitute Giorgian de Arrascaeta on the edge of the box but he leaned back and put his shot over the bar.\n\nThere was still time for Uribe to waste another chance to make sure of the win, this time hitting the bar in the final minute, but he will be forgiven his wastefulness by the delirious Colombian supporters.\n\nUruguay's Argentine coach Marcelo Bielsa took the blame for being unable to craft a win against ten-men in the second half.\n\n\"Uruguay were clearly in a position to win this game...I take special responsibility for not having been able to establish an advantage when we had the players capable of doing so,\" he said.\n\nHis compatriot and counterpart Lorenzo said he and his team had been rewarded for their positive approach to the game.\n\n\"We took the lead, the risk, and we were even brave. When we were down one we kept two strikers...and that is an act of courage that was rewarded,\" he said.\n\nThe celebrations were marred by ugly scenes in the stands will concern organizers CONMEBOL ahead of a final which is sure to attract huge numbers of Argentines as well as Colombians. -- AFP", "source": {"uri": "malaymail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Malay Mail"}, "authors": [], We had to stand up for our loved ones\"\n\nThose were the pleas of defender Jose Maria Gimenez postgame, who witnessed family members of La Celeste, Uruguay players themselves, Colombia fans and organizers scuffle in the stands for more than 10 minutes.\n\nMoments after Colombia closed out a 1-0 victory over Uruguay in the Copa America semifinals in Miami, it all went to chaos. An altercation broke out in the stands that included striker Darwin Nunez, defender Ronald Araujo and others clashing with fans.\n\nVideo replays showed that punches were thrown, objects were tossed and people were struck. It was a dangerous and unsettling scene. And one that marred what has been a damn good game.\n\nColombia showed an incredible amount of heart while down a man, outlasting Uruguay to earn that 1-0 win that sent them to the Copa America final. But what happened post-match certainly dampened what happened during the game.\n\nNunez, Araujo and a several other players could face ramifications, especially after a brawl that seemed to snowball. A video showed N\u00fa\u00f1ez hitting a fan in Colombia team colors, and according to the Associated Press, it took more than 10 minutes for police to restore order. The public address announcer asked for fans to leave the stadium, but several supporters remained.\n\nAbout 100 Uruguayan fans and members of the federation staff remained on the field more than 20 minutes after the game, while Colombia fans made their way out to celebrate.\n\nSouth American football's governing body CONMEBOL, which organizes Copa America, said it is investigating the incident.\n\n\"I thought that the incident ended with some argument on the midfield and when I saw that happening I went to the locker room,\" Uruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa said in a press conference. \"I thought that they were thanking the fans for their support. But then I learned that there were some problems over there unfortunately.\"\n\nEventually, the focus will return to soccer, and the upcoming clash between Colombia and Argentina with a trophy on the line. Maybe that match will be good enough to establish itself as the defining moment of this tournament, but perhaps not. {"uri": "8219892090", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "06:30:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T06:30:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T06:29:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.fox28spokane.com/colombia-defeat-uruguay-to-reach-copa-america-final/", "title": "Colombia defeat Uruguay to reach Copa America final | FOX 28 Spokane", "body": "Ten-man Colombia defeated Uruguay 1-0 to reach the final of the Copa America for the first time in 23 years after an ill-tempered semi-final on Wednesday.\n\nA 39th-minute Jefferson Lerma header sealed victory for the Colombians, who will now face holders Argentina in Sunday's final in Miami.\n\nIt was an anarchic semi-final played in front of a packed and passionate crowd which ended with scuffles on the field and fighting in the stands, including several players who had climbed in among supporters amid the flying punches.\n\nColombia, despite having Daniel Munoz sent off just before the interval and facing plenty of Uruguay pressure, hung on for a famous victory to the delight of their massive following of fans.\n\nThe win was the 28th game without defeat for Colombia, setting a new record for the team.\n\nThe downtown streets of the North Carolina city were packed with partying fans in bright yellow Colombia jerseys hours before the kick-off.\n\nNot surprisingly in such an atmosphere, Colombia started strongly with their livewire Liverpool winger Luis Diaz doing well to wriggle some space for a cross on the left, finding Daniel Munoz at the back post but the full-back's header was off target.\n\nUruguay were, as always, a threat on the counter-attack and their Liverpool star, Darwin Nunez, was close to finishing off one break when Rodr go Bentancur found him with a clever pass but the forward poked his shot wide.\n\nNunez had another opening when Maximiliano Araujo played him clear in the inside-right channel but the striker rushed his shot, blasting high and wide.\n\nAt the other end, Colombia forced a turnover which led to James Rodriguez curling in a cross from the right but Jhon Cordoba's header was off target.\n\n- Lerma breakthrough -\n\nThe breakthrough came in the 39th minute when Lerma rose majestically above Jose Maria Gimenez and powerfully headed home Rodriguez's corner.\n\nIt was the sixth assist of the tournament for Rodriguez with the former Real Madrid midfielder beating the record for most assists in a single Copa, which was set by Lionel Messi in 2021.\n\nColombia looked to make the most of their momentum with Richard Rios forcing a save out of Uruguay keeper Sergio Rochet, after being played in by Munoz.\n\nBut having been so influential down the right in the opening half, Munoz lost his head completely, just before the break, picking up a second yellow card, after landing an elbow on Manuel Ugarte.\n\nIt was a moment of madness which left Colombia to defend their lead with just 10 men for the entire second half.\n\nColombia coach Nestor Lorenzo took off Rodriguez, who was also on a yellow card, in the 62nd minute as Uruguay gradually began to turn their numerical advantage into real pressure.\n\nNicolas de la Cruz threatened with a low drive before substitute Luis Suarez clipped the outside of the post with a drive from the edge of the box after good work from Federico Valverde.\n\nValverde, the Real Madrid midfielder, then went close himself with a low drive as Colombia's back-line continued to ride their luck.\n\nGiveaway from Uruguay keeper and fell to Mateus Uribe, who despite time and space placed his shot wide of the post.\n\nIn stoppage time Uruguay had a great chance to force penalties when Nunez laid the ball off to substitute Giorgian de Arrascaeta on the edge of the box but he leaned back and put his shot over the bar.\n\nThere was still time for Uribe to waste another chance to make sure of the win, this time hitting the bar in the final minute, but he will be forgiven his wastefulness by the delirious Colombian supporters.\n\nUruguay's Argentine coach Marcelo Bielsa took the blame for being unable to craft a win against ten-men in the second half.\n\n\"Uruguay were clearly in a position to win this game...I take special responsibility for not having been able to establish an advantage when we had the players capable of doing so,\" he said.\n\nHis compatriot and counterpart Lorenzo said he and his team had been rewarded for their positive approach to the game.\n\n\"We took the lead, the risk, and we were even brave. When we were down one we kept two strikers...and that is an act of courage that was rewarded,\" he said.\n\nThe celebrations were marred by ugly scenes in the stands will concern organizers CONMEBOL Captain Jose Maria Gimenez said the players were trying to defend their families.\n\n\"Let me say something before they cut you off because they won't let us speak into the microphone, they don't want me to say anything about what's going on but this is a disaster,\" Gimenez said on the official broadcast.\n\n\"Please be careful, our families are in the stands, there are little newborn babies. It was a disaster; there was no police and we had to defend our families.\n\n\"This is the fault of two or three people who had a few too many drinks and don't know how to drink.\"\n\nPlayers and staff from both Colombia and Uruguay were also involved in a confrontation on the field after the final whistle.\n\n\"I thought that the incident ended with some argument on the midfield and when I saw that happening I went to the locker room,\" Uruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa said in a press conference.\n\n\"I thought that they were thanking the fans for their support. But then I learned that there were some problems over there, unfortunately.\"\n\nJefferson Lerma's first-half header gave Colombia a place in Sunday's final while Uruguay will play Canada in the {"uri": "8219753152", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "04:31:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T04:31:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T04:28:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-colombia-beats-uruguay-1-0-and-will-face-lionel-messi-and-argentina-in-copa-america-final-2-6101842.html", "title": "Sports News | Colombia Beats Uruguay 1-0 and Will Face Lionel Messi and Argentina in Copa America Final | LatestLY", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on Sports at LatestLY. Colombia is headed to the Copa America championship game for the first time in 23 years after a contentious win over Uruguay in which it played the second half a man short and players brawled with fans in the stands following the final whistle.\n\nCharlotte (North Carolina), Jul 11 (AP) Colombia is headed to the Copa America championship game for the first time in 23 years after a contentious win over Uruguay in which it played the second half a man short and players brawled with fans in the stands following the final whistle.\n\nJefferson Lerma scored in the 39th minute for a 1-0 win Wednesday night and a matchup with Lionel Messi and defending champion Argentina on Sunday.\n\nAlso Read | Jefferson Lerma's Header Powers Colombia to 1-0 Win Over Uruguay, Seals Date With Argentina in Copa America 2024 Final.\n\n\"Until you overcome your weaknesses you cannot grow,\" Colombia coach Nester Lorenzo said through a interpreter. \"And when you overcome those obstacles you can grow.\"\n\nDaniel Mu\u00f1oz was ejected in first-half stoppage time for an elbow that led to his second yellow card. Despite Uruguay having 61.9% possession, Colombia held on to reach the championship for the first time since winning its only Copa title as host in 2001.\n\nAlso Read | UEFA Euro 2024: Ollie Watkins' Late Goal Put England Into Final After Beating Netherlands 2-1.\n\nColombia extended its unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games, one more than from 1992-94 and the longest current streak in men's international soccer.\n\n\"They are very hungry as players and very eager and they really add many elements to their game beyond the tactical side,\" Lorenzo said.\n\nIn a match that included seven yellow cards in addition to the red, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle. Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez and about a dozen Uruguay teammates went into the stands as fans brawled.\n\nA video showed N\u00fa\u00f1ez hitting a fan in Colombian team colors.\n\nDefending champion Argentina and Colombia meet at Miami Gardens, Florida, in the tournament finale. The Albiceleste are seeking a record 16th Copa title and are looking to join Spain from 2008-12 as the only countries to win three straight major championships.\n\nUruguay stays in Charlotte to meet Canada in Saturday night's third-place match.\n\nBefore an overwhelmingly pro-Colombia crowd of 70,644 that filled Bank of America Stadium with yellow jerseys and flags, Uruguay fell behind for the first time in the tournament.\n\nJames Rodr\u00edguez's corner kick was headed in from short range by Lerma, who outjumped Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez for his third international goal and second of the tournament. Rodr\u00edguez has six assists in the tournament -- triple the total of any other player.\n\nMu\u00f1oz received his first yellow card from Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos in the 31st minute for a reckless slide tackle on Maximiliano Ara\u00fajo and his second for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the stomach.\n\nRodr\u00edguez was given a yellow card in the 55th minute for arguing with Ramos when the referee failed to stop play after Richard R\u00edos was kicked on a shin by Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez.\n\nR\u00edos was removed on a stretcher, re-entered the match, then went down in another challenge and was substituted in the 62nd minute. Rodr\u00edguez was removed at the same time to keep him eligible for the final.\n\nColombia goalkeeper Camilo Vargas didn't have to make his first save until he stopped Nicol\u00e1s de la Cruz in the 68th minute.\n\nLuis Su\u00e1rez, Uruguay's career leader with 68 goals, entered in the 66th minute and hit the outside of a post with a shot in the 71st. He grasped his head in his hands in disgust.\n\n\"The moments in which we could unbalance the game, we did not succeed,\" Uruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa said. \"We should have generated more goal situations than we did.\"\n\nColombia's Mateus Uribe, another second-half sub, put an open shot wide in the 88th, and Uribe's open shot in the fourth minute of stoppage time ricocheted off the body of sliding goalkeeper Sergio Rochet and then the crossbar.\n\nUruguay moved Rochet up to the attacking half of the field in the final minute, desperate for a goal.\n\nThe match was played in 90-degree heat on a surface that was converted from artificial turf to grass in the weeks leading up the game.\n\nPlayers on the NFL's Carolina Panthers have been outspoken about soccer teams having the luxury of playing on grass on their home field. Players say NFL games on artificial turf leave them more susceptible to injuries.\n\nWith two games left, attendance of 1.48 million is just 1,663 shy of the total for the 2016 tournament in the United States. {"uri": "2024-07-418129645", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "04:06:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T04:06:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T02:23:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240711-colombia-defeat-uruguay-1-0-to-reach-copa-america-final", "title": "Colombia defeat Uruguay 1-0 to reach Copa America final", "body": "Charlotte (AFP) - Ten-man Colombia defeated Uruguay 1-0 to reach the final of the Copa America for the first time in 23 years after an ill-tempered semi-final on Wednesday.\n\nA 39th-minute Jefferson Lerma header sealed victory for the Colombians, who will now face holders Argentina in Sunday's final in Miami.\n\nIt was an anarchic semi-final played in front of a packed and passionate crowd which ended with scuffles on the field and fighting in the stands, including several players who had climbed in among supporters amid the flying punches.\n\nColombia, despite having Daniel Munoz sent off just before the interval and facing plenty of Uruguay pressure, hung on for a famous victory to the delight of their massive following of fans.\n\nThe downtown streets of the North Carolina city were packed with partying fans in bright yellow Colombia jerseys hours before the kick-off.\n\nInside the 74,800 capacity Bank of America Stadium, it was like a home game in Bogota with only pockets of Uruguayan supporters breaking up the wall of yellow on all four sides of the venue.\n\nNot surprisingly in such an atmosphere, Colombia started strongly with their livewire Liverpool winger Luis Diaz doing well to wriggle some space for a cross on the left, finding Daniel Munoz at the back post but the full-back's header was off target.\n\nUruguay were, as always, a threat on the counter-attack and their Liverpool star, Darwin Nunez, was close to finishing off one break when Rodrigo Bentancur found him with a clever pass but the forward poked his shot wide.\n\nNunez had another opening when Maximiliano Araujo played him clear in the inside-right channel but the striker rushed his shot, blasting high and wide.\n\nAt the other end, Colombia forced a turnover which led to James Rodriguez curling in a cross from the right but Jhon Cordoba's header was off target.\n\nLerma breakthrough\n\nThe breakthrough came in the 39th minute when Lerma rose majestically above Jose Maria Gimenez and powerfully headed home Rodriguez's corner.\n\nIt was the sixth assist of the tournament for Rodriguez with the former Real Madrid midfielder beating the record for most assists in a single Copa, which was set by Lionel Messi in 2021.\n\nColombia looked to make the most of their momentum with Richard Rios forcing a save out of Uruguay keeper Sergio Rochet, after being played in by Munoz.\n\nBut having been so influential down the right in the opening half, Munoz lost his head completely, just before the break, picking up a second yellow card, after landing an elbow on Manuel Ugarte.\n\nIt was a moment of madness which left Colombia to defend their lead with just 10 men for the entire second half.\n\nColombia coach Nestor Lorenzo took off Rodriguez, who was also on a yellow card, in the 62nd minute as Uruguay gradually began to turn their numerical advantage into real pressure.\n\nNicolas de la Cruz threatened with a low drive before substitute Luis Suarez clipped the outside of the post with a drive from the edge of the box after good work from Federico Valverde.\n\nValverde, the Real Madrid midfielder, then went close himself with a low drive as Colombia's back-line continued to ride their luck.\n\nGiveaway from Uruguay keeper and fell to Mateus Uribe, who despite time and space placed his shot wide of the post.\n\nIn stoppage time Uruguay had a great chance to force penalties when Nunez laid the ball off to substitute Giorgian de Arrascaeta on the edge of the box but he leaned back and put his shot over the bar.\n\nThere was still time for Uribe to waste another chance to make sure of the win, this time hitting the bar in the final minute, but he will be forgiven his wastefulness by the delirious Colombian supporters.\n\nThe celebrations were marred by ugly scenes in the stands will concern organizers CONMEBOL ahead of a final which is sure to attract huge numbers of Argentines as well as A 39th-minute Jefferson Lerma header sealed victory for the Colombians, who will now face holders Argentina in Sunday's final in Miami. It was an anarchic semi-final played in front of a packed and passionate crowd which ended with scuffles on the field and fighting in the stands, including several players who had climbed in among supporters amid the flying punches.\n\nColombia, despite having Daniel Munoz sent off just before the interval and facing plenty of Uruguay pressure, hung on for a famous victory to the delight of their massive following of fans.\n\nThe downtown streets of the North Carolina city were packed with partying fans in bright yellow Colombia jerseys hours before the kick-off.\n\nInside the 74,800 capacity Bank of America Stadium, it was like a home game in Bogota with only pockets of Uruguayan supporters breaking up the wall of yellow on all four sides of the venue.\n\nNot surprisingly in such an atmosphere, Colombia started strongly with their livewire Liverpool winger Luis Diaz doing well to wriggle some space for a cross on the left, finding Daniel Munoz at the back post but the full-back's header was off target.\n\nUruguay were, as always, a threat on the counter-attack and their Liverpool star, Darwin Nunez, was close to finishing off one break when Rodrigo Bentancur found him with a clever pass but the forward poked his shot wide.\n\nNunez had another opening when Maximiliano Araujo played him clear in the inside-right channel but the striker rushed his shot, blasting high and wide.\n\nAt the other end, Colombia forced a turnover which led to James Rodriguez curling in a cross from the right but Jhon Cordoba's header was off target.\n\nThe breakthrough came in the Our work is based on the conviction that football connects us and unites us, through its positive values.\n\n\"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all their passion into cheering on their teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nNunez's management company has been contacted for comment.\n\nA {"uri": "2024-07-418233580", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "06:28:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T06:28:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T05:31:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/colombia-defeat-uruguay-to-reach-copa-america-final/article_d99f630f-864f-5da3-a63f-f1abd8e81f6c.html", "title": "Colombia defeat Uruguay to reach Copa America final", "body": "Colombia midfielder Mateus Uribe fights for the ball with Uruguay forward Darwin Nunez\n\nTen-man Colombia defeated Uruguay 1-0 to reach the final of the Copa America for the first time in 23 years after an ill-tempered semi-final on Wednesday.\n\nA 39th-minute Jefferson Lerma header sealed victory for the Colombians, who will now face holders Argentina in Sunday's final in Miami.\n\nIt was an anarchic semi-final played in front of a packed and passionate crowd which ended with scuffles on the field and fighting in the stands, including several players who had climbed in among supporters amid the flying punches.\n\nColombia, despite having Daniel Munoz sent off just before the interval and facing plenty of Uruguay pressure, hung on for a famous victory to the delight of their massive following of fans.\n\nThe win was the 28th game without defeat for Colombia, setting a new record for the team.\n\nThe downtown streets of the North Carolina city were packed with partying fans in bright yellow Colombia jerseys hours before the kick-off.\n\nNot surprisingly in such an atmosphere, Colombia started strongly with their livewire Liverpool winger Luis Diaz doing well to wriggle some space for a cross on the left, finding Daniel Munoz at the back post but the full-back's header was off target.\n\nUruguay were, as always, a threat on the counter-attack and their Liverpool star, Darwin Nunez, was close to finishing off one break when Rodr go Bentancur found him with a clever pass but the forward poked his shot wide.\n\nNunez had another opening when Maximiliano Araujo played him clear in the inside-right channel but the striker rushed his shot, blasting high and wide.\n\nAt the other end, Colombia forced a turnover which led to James Rodriguez curling in a cross from the right but Jhon Cordoba's header was off target.\n\n- Lerma breakthrough -\n\nThe breakthrough came in the 39th minute when Lerma rose majestically above Jose Maria Gimenez and powerfully headed home Rodriguez's corner.\n\nIt was the sixth assist of the tournament for Rodriguez with the former Real Madrid midfielder beating the record for most assists in a single Copa, which was set by Lionel Messi in 2021.\n\nColombia looked to make the most of their momentum with Richard Rios forcing a save out of Uruguay keeper Sergio Rochet, after being played in by Munoz.\n\nBut having been so influential down the right in the opening half, Munoz lost his head completely, just before the break, picking up a second yellow card, after landing an elbow on Manuel Ugarte.\n\nIt was a moment of madness which left Colombia to defend their lead with just 10 men for the entire second half.\n\nColombia coach Nestor Lorenzo took off Rodriguez, who was also on a yellow card, in the 62nd minute as Uruguay gradually began to turn their numerical advantage into real pressure.\n\nNicolas de la Cruz threatened with a low drive before substitute Luis Suarez clipped the outside of the post with a drive from the edge of the box after good work from Federico Valverde.\n\nValverde, the Real Madrid midfielder, then went close himself with a low drive as Colombia's back-line continued to ride their luck.\n\nGiveaway from Uruguay keeper and fell to Mateus Uribe, who despite time and space placed his shot wide of the post.\n\nIn stoppage time Uruguay had a great chance to force penalties when Nunez laid the ball off to substitute Giorgian de Arrascaeta on the edge of the box but he leaned back and put his shot over the bar.\n\nThere was still time for Uribe to waste another chance to make sure of the win, this time hitting the bar in the final minute, but he will be forgiven his wastefulness by the delirious Colombian supporters.\n\nUruguay's Argentine coach Marcelo Bielsa took the blame for being unable to craft a win against ten-men in the second half.\n\n\"Uruguay were clearly in a position to win this game...I take special responsibility for not having been able to establish an advantage when we had the players capable of doing so,\" he said.\n\nHis compatriot and counterpart Lorenzo said he and his team had been rewarded for their positive approach to the game.\n\n\"We took the lead, the risk, and we were even brave. When we were down one we kept two strikers...and that is an act of courage that was rewarded,\" he said.\n\nThe celebrations were marred by ugly scenes in the stands will concern organizers CONMEBOL ahead of a final which is sure to attract huge numbers of Argentines as well as Colombians.\n\nsev/rcw\n\nMore from this section\n\nReconnect with Your Food in Andrea Kristin's Best Selling {"uri": "8219751530", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "04:26:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T04:26:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T04:26:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.mangalorean.com/colombia-outlast-uruguay-to-punch-ticket-to-copa-america-final/", "title": "Colombia outlast Uruguay to punch ticket to Copa America final - Mangalorean.com", "body": "Colombia outlast Uruguay to punch ticket to Copa America final\n\nCharlotte (US): Colombia beat Uruguay 1-0 to extend their 28 game unbeaten streak and earning a place in Copa America final late on Wednesday night.\n\nColombia is headed to Miami Gardens to play Argentina in the Grand Final at Hard Rock Stadium on Sunday while Uruguay will stay in Charlotte to play Canada at Bank of America Stadium on Saturday to determine third place.\n\nThe first 10 minutes saw two juggernauts cautiously testing each other, resulting in only one shot. Colombia appeared more likely to create the first big chance, but it was Uruguay's Darwin Nunez who came close.\n\nNunez battled past multiple Colombian defenders in the penalty area and unleashed a powerful shot to the bottom left corner, narrowly missing. Despite several chances, the Uruguayan striker couldn't score.\n\nAfter losing center back Ronald Araujo to injury against Brazil, Uruguay suffered another blow as Rodrigo Bentancur went off injured in the 35th minute with Guillermo Varela replacing him.\n\nIn the 40th minute, Colombia finally broke through as James Rodriguez's set-piece delivery leading to a headed goal. Rodriguez's whipped corner found Jefferson Lerma, who powered it into Rochet's near post.\n\nThis goal marked a milestone for Colombia's captain, as he broke Lionel Messi's record for the most assists in a single tournament edition with his sixth, giving Colombia the lead in the semifinal.\n\nIn the 45th minute, the match shifted as Daniel Munoz received a second yellow card, reducing Colombia to 10 men just before halftime.\n\nBy the 70th minute, the game became increasingly stretched. Uruguayan legend Luis Suarez, coming on as a substitute, had a great chance at the top of the box, but his shot grazed the side of the post.\n\nIn the 87th minute, Colombia's Mateus Uribe missed a one-on-one chance after a Uruguayan defensive mistake. During seven minutes of stoppage time, Uribe had another one-on-one, but Rochet made a crucial save, deflecting the shot off the bar.\n\nUruguay held on for the final minutes, and a last-gasp effort {"uri": "2024-07-418150872", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "04:40:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T04:40:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T04:33:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.news18.com/football/colombia-defeat-uruguay-1-0-copa-america-final-match-highlights-jefferson-lerma-brawl-score-8961505.html", "title": "Colombia Defeat Uruguay 1-0 to Enter Copa America Final", "body": "It was an anarchic semi-final played in front of a packed and passionate crowd which ended with scuffles on the field and fighting in the stands, including several players who had climbed in among supporters amid the flying punches.\n\nTen-man Colombia defeated Uruguay 1-0 to reach the final of the Copa America for the first time in 23 years after an ill-tempered semi-final on Wednesday.\n\nA 39th-minute Jefferson Lerma header sealed victory for the Colombians, who will now face holders Argentina in Sunday's final in Miami.\n\nIt was an anarchic semi-final played in front of a packed and passionate crowd which ended with scuffles on the field and fighting in the stands, including several players who had climbed in among supporters amid the flying punches.\n\nColombia, despite having Daniel Munoz sent off just before the interval and facing plenty of Uruguay pressure, hung on for a famous victory to the delight of their massive following of fans.\n\nThe win was the 28th game without defeat for Colombia, setting a new record for the team.\n\nThe downtown streets of the North Carolina city were packed with partying fans in bright yellow Colombia jerseys hours before the kick-off.\n\nNot surprisingly in such an atmosphere, Colombia started strongly with their livewire Liverpool winger Luis Diaz doing well to wriggle some space for a cross on the left, finding Daniel Munoz at the back post but the full-back's header was off target.\n\nUruguay were, as always, a threat on the counter-attack and their Liverpool star, Darwin Nunez, was close to finishing off one break when Rodr go Bentancur found him with a clever pass but the forward poked his shot wide.\n\nNunez had another opening when Maximiliano Araujo played him clear in the inside-right channel but the striker rushed his shot, blasting high and wide.\n\nAt the other end, Colombia forced a turnover which led to James Rodriguez curling in a cross from the right but Jhon Cordoba's header was off target.\n\nLerma breakthrough\n\nThe breakthrough came in the 39th minute when Lerma rose majestically above Jose Maria Gimenez and powerfully headed home Rodriguez's corner.\n\nIt was the sixth assist of the tournament for Rodriguez with the former Real Madrid midfielder beating the record for most assists in a single Copa, which was set by Lionel Messi in 2021.\n\nColombia looked to make the most of their momentum with Richard Rios forcing a save out of Uruguay keeper Sergio Rochet, after being played in by Munoz.\n\nBut having been so influential down the right in the opening half, Munoz lost his head completely, just before the break, picking up a second yellow card, after landing an elbow on Manuel Ugarte.\n\nIt was a moment of madness which left Colombia to defend their lead with just 10 men for the entire second half.\n\nColombia coach Nestor Lorenzo took off Rodriguez, who was also on a yellow card, in the 62nd minute as Uruguay gradually began to turn their numerical advantage into real pressure.\n\nNicolas de la Cruz threatened with a low drive before substitute Luis Suarez clipped the outside of the post with a drive from the edge of the box after good work from Federico Valverde.\n\nValverde, the Real Madrid midfielder, then went close himself with a low drive as Colombia's back-line continued to ride their luck.\n\nGiveaway from Uruguay keeper and fell to Mateus Uribe, who despite time and space placed his shot wide of the post.\n\nIn stoppage time Uruguay had a great chance to force penalties when Nunez laid the ball off to substitute Giorgian de Arrascaeta on the edge of the box but he leaned back and put his shot over the bar.\n\nThere was still time for Uribe to waste another chance to make sure of the win, this time hitting the bar in the final minute, but he will be forgiven his wastefulness by the delirious Colombian supporters.\n\nUruguay's Argentine coach Marcelo Bielsa took the blame for being unable to craft a win against ten-men in the second half.\n\n\"Uruguay were clearly in a position to win this game...I take special responsibility for not having been able to establish an advantage when we had the players capable of doing so,\" he said.\n\nHis compatriot and counterpart Lorenzo said he and his team had been rewarded for their positive approach to the game.\n\n\"We took the lead, the risk, and we were even brave. When we were down one we kept two strikers...and that is an act of courage that was rewarded,\" he said.\n\nThe celebrations were marred by ugly scenes in the stands will concern organizers CONMEBOL ahead of a final which is sure to attract huge numbers of Argentines as well as Colombians.", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News18"}, "authors": [{"uri": Captain Jose Maria Gimenez said the players were trying to defend their families.\n\n\"Let me say something before they cut you off because they won't let us speak into the microphone, they don't want me to say anything about what's going on but this is a disaster,\" Gimenez said on the official broadcast.\n\n\"Please be careful, our families are in the stands, there are little newborn babies. {"uri": "8220690311", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "14:58:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T14:58:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T14:57:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.masslive.com/sports/2024/07/we-had-to-defend-our-families-soccer-players-enter-stands-fight-fans-at-copa-america.html", "title": "'We had to defend our families.' Soccer players enter stands, fight fans at Copa America", "body": "It was an ugly scene Wednesday night in Charlotte after a Copa America semifinal as a fight broke out in the stands between players and fans.\n\nAfter a 1-0 loss to Colombia, about a dozen players from the Uruguay men's national team were seen entering the stands and brawling with opposing fans. You can see video of the incident here.\n\nFollowing a match that was described as \"physical and contentious,\" fighting broke out in the stands behind the Uruguay bench as beverages were thrown. Uruguay players then climbed a staircase entered the stands and clashed with Colombia fans.\n\nUruguay captain Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez claimed after the game that players were attempting to defend their families.\n\n\"Our families are in the stands, there are little newborn babies. It was a disaster; there was no police and we had to defend our families,\" Gim\u00e9nez said, according to ESPN.\n\nDarwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez, a forward who also plays for Liverpool, was among the Uruguay players identified as being at the forefront of the violence.\n\nThe Copa America is a soccer tournament held every four years among South American national teams.\n\nUruguay striker Luis Suarez said that players felt that it seemed like their fans were \"trapped\" amid a hostile crowd of opposing fans.\n\n\"I could see from afar that there were a lot of families and many of my teammates' children trapped in that section,\" Suarez said, according to ESPN. \"It's normal that you feel helpless and want to help when they're having things thrown at them.\"\n\nAccording to the Associated Press, the crowd over 70,000 fans at Bank of America Stadium was \"about 90% in favor of Colombia.\"\n\nThe AP also reports that the fighting last for about 10 minutes before security intervened.\n\nCONMEBOL, the governing body of soccer in South America and the tournament's organizer, released a statement condemning the violence.\n\n\"Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values,\" the statement said. \"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all of their passion into cheering on their national teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nAs a result of Wednesday night's game, Colombia will move on to face Argentina in the final on Sunday. {"uri": "8219840950", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "05:48:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T05:48:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T05:48:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/sports/darwin-nunez-uruguay-players-brawl-in-stands-with-fans-after-copa-loss/articleshow/111652124.cms", "title": "Darwin Nunez, Uruguay players brawl in stands with fans after Copa loss", "body": "Liverpool star Darwin Nunez and Uruguay players clashed with Colombian fans after their 1-0 Copa America semi-final loss, escalating into a brawl at Charlotte's Bank of America Stadium. Concerned for their families' safety, players intervened in the stands. CONMEBOL condemned the violence, emphasizing football's unifying values.Liverpool star Darwin Nunez and other Uruguay players were involved in a brawl with Colombian fans which erupted after their 1-0 Copa America semi-final defeat on Wednesday.\n\nUruguay striker Nunez unleashed a flurry of punches at Colombian supporters after jumping into the spectator seating at Charlotte's Bank of America Stadium following an ill-tempered loss to Colombia.\n\nUruguay central defender Jose Maria Gimenez said players had leapt into the melee out of concern for the safety of family members and loved ones watching the game.\n\n\"This is a disaster. Our family was in danger. We had to go to the stands to take out our loved ones, with tiny newborn babies,\" the Atletico Madrid player said.\n\n\"There was not a single police officer... I hope those who are organising this are a little more careful with the families.\n\n\"Every game it's been happening because there are people who don't know how to handle a couple of drinks.\"\n\nThe overwhelming majority of the spectators in the crowd were supporting Colombia but there was no segregation between them and their Uruguayan counterparts.\n\nSeveral Uruguay players climbed into the crowd, seemingly to protect fans, with Nunez prominent.\n\nThe fighting continued for several minutes until police finally intervened.\n\nA group of around 80-100 Uruguayan fans remained in the stadium, on the pitch, long after the rest of the fans had left with Uruguay players returning to the field to meet them.\n\nUgly scenes also broke out on the field after the final whistle, with players and staff from both teams involved in a mass melee in the centre-circle following Colombia's victory.\n\nCONMEBOL, the South American football confederation which organises the Copa America, issued a statement condemning the incidents.\n\n\"CONMEBOL strongly condemns any acts of violence that affects football. Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values.\n\n\"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the pitch. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all their passion into cheering on their national teams and having an unforgettable party.\"", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", {"uri": "8219669735", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "03:00:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T03:00:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T02:59:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.insidesport.in/football/james-rodriguez-10-man-colombia-stun-uruguay-set-argentina-clash-in-copa-america-final/", "title": "10-man Colombia stun Uruguay, set Argentina clash in Copa America final", "body": "Colombia will be aiming to win their second Copa America title, having previously triumphed in 2001. This will be their third time reaching the final (1975, 2001).\n\nColombia has booked their place in the Copa America 2024 final after a dramatic 1-0 victory over Uruguay in a tense semifinal clash at Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte.\n\nColombia took the lead in the 39th minute through a well-worked corner. James Rodr\u00edguez, in a moment of brilliance, delivered a pinpoint cross that found Jefferson Lerma's head.\n\nThe midfielder's powerful header gave Uruguay's goalkeeper no chance, sending the Colombian fans in the 70,644 strong crowd into a frenzy.\n\nJust before halftime, the momentum shifted when Colombian defender Daniel Munoz was shown a second yellow card, reducing his team to 10 men. This setback could have easily derailed Colombia's dream run, but they showed remarkable resilience.\n\nColombia's defense stood firm throughout the second half, repelling numerous Uruguayan attacks. Despite going down a man, they remained disciplined and frustrated Uruguay's attempts to find an equalizer.\n\nThe Colombians also had their chances to extend their lead. Midfielder Mateus Uribe saw two golden opportunities go begging in the latter stages of the match, much to the disappointment of the Colombian faithful.\n\nUruguay, on the other hand, continued their struggles in front of goal. Their star striker Darwin Nunez failed to convert any of his four shots in the first half, while Jose Gimenez also spurned two chances in the second. Uruguay, who haven't scored in their last two games, couldn't break Colombia's resolute defense.\n\nWith the final whistle, Colombia erupted in celebration. This victory extends their unbeaten streak to a staggering 28 games. They now face a gargantuan challenge in the final - Lionel Messi's Argentina, the reigning Copa America and World Cup champions. The final will be played at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami on Sunday.\n\nColombia will be aiming to win their second Copa America title, having previously triumphed in 2001. This will be their third time reaching the final (1975, 2001). Argentina, tied with Uruguay for most Copa America titles (15), will be looking to defend their crown. {"uri": "2024-07-418271011", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "07:10:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T07:10:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T07:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.news.com.au/sport/football/this-is-out-of-control-liverpool-star-at-centre-of-wild-fan-brawl-at-copa-america/news-story/14a15eb49a9a082e65d86b947e1a9447", "title": "'This is out of control': Liverpool striker at centre of wild fan brawl at Copa America", "body": "Liverpool star Darwin Nunez and other Uruguay players were involved in a brawl with Colombian fans which erupted after their 1-0 Copa America semi-final defeat on Wednesday.\n\nUruguay striker Nunez unleashed a flurry of punches at Colombian supporters after jumping into the spectator seating at Charlotte's Bank of America Stadium following an ill-tempered loss to Colombia.\n\nUruguay central defender Jose Maria Gimenez said players had leapt into the melee out of concern for the safety of family members and loved ones watching the game.\n\n\"This is a disaster. Our family was in danger. We had to go to the stands to take out our loved ones, with tiny newborn babies,\" the Atletico Madrid player said.\n\n\"There was not a single police officer ... I hope those who are organising this are a little more careful with the families.\n\n\"Every game it's been happening because there are people who don't know how to handle a couple of drinks.\"\n\nWatch the wild Copa America brawl in the video above\n\nThe overwhelming majority of the spectators in the crowd were supporting Colombia but there was no segregation between them and their Uruguayan counterparts.\n\nSeveral Uruguay players climbed into the crowd, seemingly to protect fans, with Nunez prominent.\n\nThe fighting continued for several minutes until police finally intervened. A group of around 80-100 Uruguayan fans remained in the stadium, on the pitch, long after the rest of the fans had left with Uruguay players returning to the field to meet them.\n\nUgly scenes also broke out on the field after the final whistle, with players and staff from both teams involved in a mass melee in the centre-circle following Colombia's victory.\n\nCONMEBOL, the South American football confederation which organises the Copa America, issued a statement condemning the incidents.\n\n\"CONMEBOL strongly condemns any acts of violence that affects football. Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values.\n\n\"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the pitch. {"uri": "8219931296", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "06:59:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T06:59:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T06:59:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.the42.ie/colombia-uruguay-copa-america-6433220-Jul2024/", "title": "10-man Colombia defeat Uruguay to reach first Copa America final in 23 years", "body": "Jefferson Lerma sealed the victory with a header in the 39th minute.\n\nTEN-MAN COLOMBIA defeated Uruguay 1-0 to reach the final of the Copa America for the first time in 23 years after an ill-tempered semi-final on Wednesday.\n\nA 39th-minute Jefferson Lerma header sealed victory for the Colombians, who will now face holders Argentina in Sunday's final in Miami.\n\nIt was an anarchic semi-final played in front of a packed and passionate crowd which ended with scuffles on the field and fighting in the stands, including several players who had climbed in among supporters amid the flying punches.\n\nColombia, despite having Daniel Munoz sent off just before the interval and facing plenty of Uruguay pressure, hung on for a famous victory to the delight of their massive following of fans.\n\nThe win was the 28th game without defeat for Colombia, setting a new record for the team.\n\nThe downtown streets of the North Carolina city were packed with partying fans in bright yellow Colombia jerseys hours before the kick-off.\n\nNot surprisingly in such an atmosphere, Colombia started strongly with their livewire Liverpool winger Luis Diaz doing well to wriggle some space for a cross on the left, finding Daniel Munoz at the back post but the full-back's header was off target.\n\nUruguay were, as always, a threat on the counter-attack and their Liverpool star, Darwin Nunez, was close to finishing off one break when Rodr go Bentancur found him with a clever pass but the forward poked his shot wide.\n\nNunez had another opening when Maximiliano Araujo played him clear in the inside-right channel but the striker rushed his shot, blasting high and wide.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAt the other end, Colombia forced a turnover which led to James Rodriguez curling in a cross from the right but Jhon Cordoba's header was off target.\n\n- Lerma breakthrough -\n\nThe breakthrough came in the 39th minute when Lerma rose majestically above Jose Maria Gimenez and powerfully headed home Rodriguez's corner.\n\nIt was the sixth assist of the tournament for Rodriguez with the former Real Madrid midfielder beating the record for most assists in a single Copa, which was set by Lionel Messi in 2021.\n\nColombia looked to make the most of their momentum with Richard Rios forcing a save out of Uruguay keeper Sergio Rochet, after being played in by Munoz.\n\nBut having been so influential down the right in the opening half, Munoz lost his head completely, just before the break, picking up a second yellow card, after landing an elbow on Manuel Ugarte.\n\nIt was a moment of madness which left Colombia to defend their lead with just 10 men for the entire second half.\n\nColombia coach Nestor Lorenzo took off Rodriguez, who was also on a yellow card, in the 62nd minute as Uruguay gradually began to turn their numerical advantage into real pressure.\n\nNicolas de la Cruz threatened with a low drive before substitute Luis Suarez clipped the outside of the post with a drive from the edge of the box after good work from Federico Valverde.\n\nValverde, the Real Madrid midfielder, then went close himself with a low drive as Colombia's back-line continued to ride their luck.\n\nGiveaway from Uruguay keeper and fell to Mateus Uribe, who despite time and space placed his shot wide of the post.\n\nIn stoppage time Uruguay had a great chance to force penalties when Nunez laid the ball off to substitute Giorgian de Arrascaeta on the edge of the box but he leaned back and put his shot over the bar.\n\nThere was still time for Uribe to waste another chance to make sure of the win, this time hitting the bar in the final minute, but he will be forgiven his wastefulness by the delirious Colombian supporters.\n\nUruguay's Argentine coach Marcelo Bielsa took the blame for being unable to craft a win against ten-men in the second half.\n\n\"Uruguay were clearly in a position to win this game...I take special responsibility for not having been able to establish an advantage when we had the players capable of doing so,\" he said.\n\nHis compatriot and counterpart Lorenzo said he and his team had been rewarded for their positive approach to the game.\n\n\"We took the lead, the risk, and we were even brave. When we were down one we kept two strikers...and that is an act of courage that was rewarded,\" he said.\n\nThe celebrations were marred by ugly scenes in the stands will concern organizers CONMEBOL ahead of a final which is sure to attract huge numbers of Argentines as well as Colombians.\n\n- \u00a9 AFP 2024\n\nFollow us: the42.ie", "source": {"uri": "the42.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-07-418155622", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "04:46:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T04:46:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T04:20:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/copa-america-news-uruguay-vs-colombia-clash-tainted-malice-in-the-palace-like-brawl", "title": "Uruguay vs. Colombia clash tainted with Malice in the Palace-like brawl", "body": "Emotions ran high on Tuesday as ten-man Colombia edged out Uruguay 1-0 in the Copa America semifinal, securing their first final appearance in 23 years. The heated match ended with chaotic scenes extending into the stands rivaling the notorious Malice in the Palace.\n\nChaos erupted postgame in Charlotte as several Uruguay players stormed into the stands at Bank of America Stadium and clashed with Colombian fans.\n\nIn a match marked by seven yellow cards and one red, players from both sides engaged in a scrum on the field at the final whistle. Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez and around a dozen of his Uruguay teammates went into the stands, where fans were brawling. A video captured N\u00fa\u00f1ez striking a fan wearing Colombian team colors.\n\nThe cause of the Uruguay, Colombia brawl\n\nUruguay's Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez addressed the broadcast after the altercation, alleging that the brawl was triggered by harassment of Uruguay players' families by a group of Colombian fans.\n\nThe violence followed a frustrating defeat for Uruguay, which was competing for a spot in the final to challenge Argentina for its first Copa Am\u00e9rica title since 2011. Instead, Uruguay will face Canada in the third-place game on Saturday, likely without several players due to impending disciplinary actions stemming from the brawl.\n\nHours before kickoff, the downtown streets of North Carolina were bustling with enthusiastic fans in vibrant yellow Colombia jerseys.\n\nFans were quick to react on X(formerly Twitter) after witnessing the brawl:\n\nOne user @onegiordano wrote: \"Shameful, totally unprofessional... @CopaAmerica\"\n\nAnother user, @ugartesgf seemed to be on the side of Uruguay stating, \"THEY WERE DEFENDING THEIR KIDS. THEIR FAMILY\"\n\nWhile @soulistaken said, \"Colombia winning on and off the field\"\n\nOne goal was enough for Jefferson Lerma and Colombia\n\nUruguay, was expected to overcome Colombia in the semifinal, but faltered in the 40th minute when Jefferson Lerma headed in a stunning corner kick from James Rodriguez.\n\nTheir chances of mounting a comeback were boosted early in the second half when Colombia's Daniel Mu\u00f1oz fouled Manuel Ugarte, resulting in a second yellow card and reducing his team to 10 men against Uruguay's 11.\n\nMu\u00f1oz was booked twice by Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos during the match. His first yellow card came in the 31st minute for a reckless slide tackle on Maximiliano Ara\u00fajo, and his second was issued for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the stomach.\n\nRodr\u00edguez received a yellow card in the 55th minute for disputing with Ramos when the referee did not stop play after Richard R\u00edos was kicked on the shin by Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez.\n\nR\u00edos was taken off on a stretcher, returned to the match, then went down again in another challenge and was substituted in the 62nd minute. Rodr\u00edguez was also substituted at the same time to ensure he remained eligible for the final.\n\nUruguay's near misses\n\nUruguay's all-time leading goal scorer, Luis Su\u00e1rez, came on as a substitute in the 66th minute and struck the outside of the post with a shot in the 71st minute.\n\nColombian goalkeeper Camilo Vargas didn't face his first shot on goal until he saved Nicol\u00e1s de la Cruz's attempt in the 68th minute.\n\nColombia's Mateus Uribe, who came on as a second-half substitute, missed an open shot wide in the 88th minute. Then, in the fourth minute of stoppage time, Uribe's attempt struck the body of sliding goalkeeper Sergio Rochet and deflected off the crossbar.\n\nThe game took place in 90-degree heat on a field that had been converted from artificial turf to grass in the weeks leading up to the match.\n\nDefending champions Argentina will face Colombia on Sunday night in Miami Gardens, Florida. La Albiceleste are aiming for a record 16th Copa America title and hope to become only the second country, after Spain from 2008 to 2012, to win three consecutive major championships.", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-418104441", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "03:22:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T03:22:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T03:17:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.charlotteobserver.com/sports/soccer/article289806879.html", "title": "70,000-plus watch Colombia top Uruguay in Charlotte Copa America semifinal, 1-0", "body": "Swaths of fans clad in yellow and sky blue filled the streets of Charlotte and sang chants as they anticipated the most prestigious soccer match that the city has ever hosted.\n\nBank of America Stadium was nearly sold out as 70,644 fans traveled from near and far to watch as 10-man Colombia topped Uruguay, 1-0, in Wednesday's Copa America semifinal.\n\nLifted by a goal from Jefferson Lerma and a sea of supporters in the stands, Colombia will head to Miami to play reigning World Cup and Copa America champions Argentina on Sunday in this year's final.\n\nUruguay will stay in Charlotte and take on Canada in Saturday's third-place game.\n\nThe semifinal of the oldest international continental tournaments in the world brought ticket buyers from all 50 states and 60 countries to Charlotte, according to data provided by a Tepper Sports and Entertainment spokesperson.\n\nAbout two-thirds of fans traveled from more than 100 miles away. Among domestic attendees, 54% traveled from outside the Carolinas.\n\nTwo of those supporters were Lucia Lopez and Agustin Aguerre -- a mother and son who were born in Uruguay and traveled from their homes in Washington, D.C., and New York to watch Wednesday's semifinal.\n\nBoth have seen plenty of Uruguay matches -- Aguerre was at La Celeste's last Copa America triumph in 2011 -- but haven't been able to go to a game together since Aguerre was little. After Uruguay topped Brazil in penalty kicks in Saturday's quarterfinal, the two bought tickets and flew to meet up in Charlotte.\n\n\"There were about 20 Colombians for every Uruguayan (at the airport),\" Aguerre said.\n\nA stadium that was largely clad in yellow celebrated the game's only goal. Former Real Madrid, Bayern Munich and Everton star James Rodriguez swung in a corner kick that found the head of Lerma, who powered the ball into the back of the net to give Colombia a 1-0 lead in the 39th minute.\n\nThe goal was met by a roar from Colombia fans, including a family with three generations in attendance.\n\nEdgar Ayerbe Sr., his son Edgar Ayerbe Jr. and daughter in-law Jeannette Ayerbe as well as their sons, Alex and Max Ayerbe, drove down from Raleigh for the historic game. Ayerbe Sr., who was born in Cali, Colombia, estimates he's been to between 15 and 20 Colombia matches in his lifetime and got to accompany his grandsons for their first Colombia game.\n\n\"Yeah I know, but it wasn't like this, it wasn't like this,\" he responded -- with the noise of drums, horns and chants from both sets of supporters behind him.\n\nEdgar Sr.'s nephew, Dani Sandoval, was also in attendance, unsurprisingly.\n\nHe's followed Colombia to every game this tournament with Parceros United, an organization and brand that hosts events and parties for Colombia fans before games in different cities. Sandoval, who was born in Colombia and moved to the U.S. at age 12, and a partner started the organization after he followed Los Cafeteros in Russia at the 2018 World Cup.\n\nDespite Colombia having the better of the play and taking the lead after Lerma's goal, a majority of the stadium became much more nervous minutes later when Colombia went down to 10 men after Daniel Munoz's second yellow card.\n\nEven in a tense second half in which Uruguay created chances to equalize, Colombia held on in front of a crowd of raucous supporters in Charlotte to extend its unbeaten run to a record 28 games -- a streak that spans back to March 2022. After the final whistle, Uruguay and Liverpool forward Darwin Nunez jumped into the stands and exchanged punches with fans.\n\nDespite the ugly scenes after the game ended, Colombia will get a chance to earn its second Copa America title -- its only previous triumph came in 2001 -- against Lionel Messi and Argentina on Sunday in Miami. {"uri": "8219693217", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "03:25:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T03:25:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T03:24:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/colombia-defeat-uruguay-1-0-to-reach-copa-america-final/article_ff847825-1080-5982-b7ae-272af39a44f6.html", "title": "Colombia defeat Uruguay 1-0 to reach Copa America final", "body": "Ten-man Colombia defeated Uruguay 1-0 to reach the final of the Copa America for the first time in 23 years after an ill-tempered semi-final on Wednesday.\n\nA 39th-minute Jefferson Lerma header sealed victory for the Colombians, who will now face holders Argentina in Sunday's final in Miami.\n\nIt was an anarchic semi-final played in front of a packed and passionate crowd which ended with scuffles on the field and fighting in the stands, including several players who had climbed in among supporters amid the flying punches.\n\nColombia, despite having Daniel Munoz sent off just before the interval and facing plenty of Uruguay pressure, hung on for a famous victory to the delight of their massive following of fans.\n\nThe downtown streets of the North Carolina city were packed with partying fans in bright yellow Colombia jerseys hours before the kick-off.\n\nInside the 74,800 capacity Bank of America Stadium, it was like a home game in Bogota with only pockets of Uruguayan supporters breaking up the wall of yellow on all four sides of the venue.\n\nNot surprisingly in such an atmosphere, Colombia started strongly with their livewire Liverpool winger Luis Diaz doing well to wriggle some space for a cross on the left, finding Daniel Munoz at the back post but the full-back's header was off target.\n\nUruguay were, as always, a threat on the counter-attack and their Liverpool star, Darwin Nunez, was close to finishing off one break when Rodrigo Bentancur found him with a clever pass but the forward poked his shot wide.\n\nNunez had another opening when Maximiliano Araujo played him clear in the inside-right channel but the striker rushed his shot, blasting high and wide.\n\nAt the other end, Colombia forced a turnover which led to James Rodriguez curling in a cross from the right but Jhon Cordoba's header was off target.\n\n- Lerma breakthrough -\n\nThe breakthrough came in the 39th minute when Lerma rose majestically above Jose Maria Gimenez and powerfully headed home Rodriguez's corner.\n\nMore from this section Tory leadership hopeful wants Boris Johnson to return - but has harsh words for Farage Parkside Drive residents calling on city to make their street safer Defiant Biden throws down gauntlet to Democrats\n\nIt was the sixth assist of the tournament for Rodriguez with the former Real Madrid midfielder beating the record for most assists in a single Copa, which was set by Lionel Messi in 2021.\n\nColombia looked to make the most of their momentum with Richard Rios forcing a save out of Uruguay keeper Sergio Rochet, after being played in by Munoz.\n\nBut having been so influential down the right in the opening half, Munoz lost his head completely, just before the break, picking up a second yellow card, after landing an elbow on Manuel Ugarte.\n\nIt was a moment of madness which left Colombia to defend their lead with just 10 men for the entire second half.\n\nColombia coach Nestor Lorenzo took off Rodriguez, who was also on a yellow card, in the 62nd minute as Uruguay gradually began to turn their numerical advantage into real pressure.\n\nNicolas de la Cruz threatened with a low drive before substitute Luis Suarez clipped the outside of the post with a drive from the edge of the box after good work from Federico Valverde.\n\nValverde, the Real Madrid midfielder, then went close himself with a low drive as Colombia's back-line continued to ride their luck.\n\nGiveaway from Uruguay keeper and fell to Mateus Uribe, who despite time and space placed his shot wide of the post.\n\nIn stoppage time Uruguay had a great chance to force penalties when Nunez laid the ball off to substitute Giorgian de Arrascaeta on the edge of the box but he leaned back and put his shot over the bar.\n\nThere was still time for Uribe to waste another chance to make sure of the win, this time hitting the bar in the final minute, but he will be forgiven his wastefulness by the delirious Colombian supporters.\n\nThe celebrations were marred by ugly scenes in the stands will concern organizers CONMEBOL ahead of a final {"uri": "8219938719", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "07:04:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T07:04:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T07:04:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/darwin-n-ez-uruguay-teammates-enter-stands-as-fans-fight-after-copa-america-loss-to/article_fae763ea-0355-5f6b-be6e-20a0cf1ae8c4.html", "title": "Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez, Uruguay teammates enter stands as fans fight after Copa America loss to Colombia", "body": "Uruguay's Ronald Araujo, right, argues with fans after a Copa America semifinal soccer match against Colombia in Charlotte, N.C., Wednesday, July 10, 2024.\n\nCHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) -- Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez and about a dozen Uruguay teammates went into the stands as fans brawled at Bank of America Stadium following a 1-0 loss to Colombia in a Copa America semifinal on Wednesday night.\n\nAfter a physical and contentious match, a melee broke out behind the Uruguay bench after Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos' final whistle.\n\nThe crowd of 70,644 was about 90% in favor in Colombia, but a small patch of Uruguay fans fought with Colombia supporters as beverages were thrown.\n\nN\u00fa\u00f1ez and teammates then climbed a staircase into the crowd. A video showed N\u00fa\u00f1ez hitting a fan in Colombian team colors.\n\nUruguay captain Jos\u00e9 Gim\u00e9nez said players went in the crowd to protect their families.\n\n\"This is a disaster. Our family is in danger. We had to get into the stands to take out our loved ones with small babies, newborns,\" he told TUDN. \"Everything was a disaster. There was not a single police officer.\"\n\nIt took more than 10 minutes for police to arrive on the scene and to restore order. The public address announcer asked for fans to leave the stadium, but several supporters remained.\n\nAbout 100 Uruguayan fans and and members of the federation staff remained on the field for their own protection more than 20 minutes after the game, while Colombia fans made their way out to celebrate.\n\nCONMEBOL released a statement after the game saying that it strongly condemns any act of violence that affects the game.\n\n\"Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values,\" the organization said. \"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all of their passion into cheering on their national teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nUruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa said he didn't see what was happening right away.\n\n\"There was some argument in the midfield, and when I saw that happening, I went to the locker room. I thought they were thanking the fans for their support,\" Beilsa said. \"But then I learned there were some problems over there unfortunately.\"\n\nAP Copa America coverage: But Colombia bravely held on for a famous win and will play Argentina in Sunday's final.\n\n\"Until you overcome your weaknesses you cannot grow,\" Colombia coach Nester Lorenzo said after the game. \"And when you overcome those obstacles you can grow.\"\n\nUruguay will play Canada a day earlier in the third-place playoff. At the end of the game N\u00fa\u00f1ez and about a dozen of his teammates went into the stands as fans brawled. A video showed N\u00fa\u00f1ez hitting a fan in Colombian team colors.\n\nJos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez said members of the Uruguay players' families were threatened by fans.\n\n\"Let me say something before they cut you off because they won't let us speak into the microphone, they don't want me to say anything about what's going on but this is a disaster,\" Gim\u00e9nez said on the official broadcast.\n\n\"Please be careful, our families are in the stands, there are little newborn babies. It was a disaster; there was no police and we had to defend our families. Despite being favored to win and having a superior squad, Uruguay failed to capitalize on their advantages. The match saw Colombia win with a goal from Jefferson Lerma, even after being reduced to ten men.\n\nUruguay's head coach Marcelo Bielsa took full responsibility for the team's 1-0 defeat to Colombia in the Copa America semi-final. The game, held at the Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, North Carolina, saw Colombia secure a win with a goal by Jefferson Lerma, despite being reduced to ten men.\n\nUruguay had been one of the pre-tournament favorites, having previously defeated the host United States and Brazil, the five-times World Cup champions. Bielsa stated, \"Uruguay was in a clear condition to win this match if you assess the individual talent in each squad.\" He acknowledged his inability to make a difference with the stronger roster.\n\nThe match turned chaotic towards the end, with Uruguay unable to capitalize on their numerical advantage after Colombia's Daniel Munoz was sent off before halftime. Following the match, CONMEBOL opened an investigation into a clash between Uruguay players and Colombia fans in the stands.
