{"uri": "8219874468", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "06:15:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T06:15:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T06:15:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpools-darwin-nunez-huge-brawl-29518892", "title": "Darwin Nunez in huge brawl with fans during Copa America tie", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nUruguay's forward Darwin Nunez was embroiled in a fiery brawl as punches were exchanged between the Liverpool ace and spectators after his nation was ousted from the Copa America by Colombia.\n\nThe tension escalated between the two countries following the final whistle, with Colombia narrowly securing a 1-0 victory courtesy of Jefferson Lerma's header in the 39th minute. Once the on-pitch scuffle subsided, the Uruguay players headed towards the stands.\n\nNunez spearheaded a group of Uruguay players into the crowd before hostility erupted from Colombian fans, leading to a large-scale fight between the players and the supporters. After being struck by a fan, Nunez was seen defending himself, with footage revealing him retaliating against several spectators.\n\nREAD MORE:Everything Craig Bellamy said in first Wales press conference as he lays out what he expects\n\nREAD MORE: 'Forget about formations!' Inside Craig Bellamy's first public appearance as Wales boss\n\nLater, the Liverpool star was spotted embracing his young son on the pitch, who might have been involved in the chaotic scenes. Barcelona's Ronald Araujo was also part of the incident, with thousands of shocked fans capturing the altercation on their mobile phones.\n\nSecurity personnel intervened to separate the two groups, attempting to escort the Uruguay players to the dressing room as swiftly as possible, reports the Mirror.\n\nAs reported by Uruguayan publication El Pais, the Uruguay players ventured into the crowd to back their family and friends who were seated just behind the team bench. With a significant majority of Colombian fans inside the stadium, the relatives of Uruguay stars were subjected to abuse.\n\nNunez spearheaded the charge of players into the stands as their family and friends were ushered onto the pitch for safety. The situation quickly deteriorated, becoming physical.\n\nUruguay national team director Jorge Giordano and press officer Felipe Cotelo found themselves embroiled in the chaos.\n\nThe report also mentioned that Uruguay midfielder Manuel Ugarte tended to his injured relatives on the field. Several Uruguayan supporters sustained serious injuries during the melee, finding themselves overwhelmed by the larger group of Colombian fans.\n\nUruguay's defender Jose Maria Gimenez recounted the ordeal, labelling it a \"disaster\" due to the absence of police. \"It was a disaster; there was no police and we had to defend our families,\" he expressed.\n\nGimenez further criticised the situation, attributing the violence to a minority of overzealous fans. \"This is because of two or three who have one drink too many. A certain sector of the Colombian fans made an avalanche where our loved ones were,\" he elaborated.\n\nIn light of these events, governing body CONMEBOL is set to conduct a thorough review before Sunday's Copa America final, which sees Colombia facing off against Argentina in Miami. Despite being on an impressive 28-game unbeaten streak, spanning more than two years, Colombia will play as underdogs to Argentina.\n\nArgentina are on the hunt for a third consecutive trophy, following Lionel Messi's triumphs in the Copa America 2021 and the World Cup a year later. Prior to 2021, Messi had not won an international trophy, but now he has the opportunity to further cement his legacy this Sunday in his new home city, having signed with MLS team Inter Miami last {"uri": "8220055151", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "08:25:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T08:25:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T08:24:33Z", "dataType": "news", SUCH TV", "body": "Ten-man Colombia defeated Uruguay 1-0 to reach the final of the Copa America for the first time in 23 years after an ill-tempered semi-final on Wednesday.\n\nA 39th-minute Jefferson Lerma header sealed victory for the Colombians, who will now face defending Copa America champions Argentina in Sunday's final in Miami.\n\nIt was an anarchic semi-final played in front of a packed and passionate crowd which ended with scuffles on the field and fighting in the stands, including several players who had climbed in among supporters amid the flying punches.\n\nColombia, despite having Daniel Munoz sent off just before the interval and facing plenty of Uruguay pressure, hung on for a famous victory to the delight of their massive following of fans.\n\nThe win was the 28th game without defeat for Colombia, setting a new record for the team.\n\nThe downtown streets of the North Carolina city were packed with partying fans in bright yellow Colombia jerseys hours before the kick-off.\n\nNot surprisingly in such an atmosphere, Colombia started strongly with their livewire Liverpool winger Luis Diaz doing well to wriggle some space for a cross on the left, finding Daniel Munoz at the back post but the full-back's header was off target.\n\nUruguay were, as always, a threat on the counter-attack and their Liverpool star, Darwin Nunez was close to finishing off one break when Rodr Bentancur found him with a clever pass but the forward poked his shot wide.\n\nNunez had another opening when Maximiliano Araujo played him clear in the inside-right channel but the striker rushed his shot, blasting high and wide.\n\nAt the other end, Colombia forced a turnover which led to James Rodriguez curling in a cross from the right but Jhon Cordoba's header was off target.\n\nThe breakthrough came in the 39th minute when Lerma rose majestically above Jose Maria Gimenez and powerfully headed home Rodriguez's corner.\n\nIt was the sixth assist of the tournament for Rodriguez with the former Real Madrid midfielder beating the record for most assists in a single Copa, which was set by Lionel Messi in 2021.\n\nColombia looked to make the most of their momentum with Richard Rios forcing a save out of Uruguay keeper Sergio Rochet, after being played in by Munoz.", "source": {"uri": "suchtv.pk", "dataType": "news", "title": "SUCH TV"}, "authors": [], Colombia is headed to the Copa America championship game for the first time in 23 years after a contentious win over Uruguay in which it played the second half a man short and players brawled with fans in the stands following the final whistle.\n\nJefferson Lerma scored in the 39th minute for a 1-0 win Wednesday night and secured a matchup with Lionel Messi and defending champion Argentina on Sunday.\n\n\"Until you overcome your weaknesses you cannot grow,\" Colombia coach Nester Lorenzo said through a interpreter. \"And when you overcome those obstacles you can grow.\"\n\nDaniel Mu\u00f1oz was ejected in first-half stoppage time for an elbow that led to his second yellow card. Despite Uruguay having 61.9 percent possession, Colombia held on to reach the championship for the first time since winning its only Copa title as host in 2001.\n\nColombia extended its unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games, one more than from 1992-94 and the longest current streak in men's international soccer.\n\n\"They are very hungry as players and very eager and they really add many elements to their game beyond the tactical side,\" Lorenzo said.\n\nIn a match that included seven yellow cards in addition to the red, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle. The brawl erupted after their 1-0 Copa America semi-final defeat on Wednesday.\n\nUruguay striker, Nunez, unleashed a flurry of punches at Colombian supporters after jumping into the spectator seating at Charlotte's Bank of America Stadium following an ill-tempered loss to Colombia.\n\nUruguay central defender Jose Maria Gimenez said players had leapt into the melee out of concern for the safety of family members and loved ones watching the game.\n\n\"This is a disaster. Our family was in danger. We had to go to the stands to take out our loved ones, with tiny newborn babies,\" the Atletico Madrid player said.\n\n\"There was not a single police officer... I hope those who are organising this are a little more careful with the families.\n\n\"Every game it's been happening because there are people who don't know how to handle a couple of drinks.\"\n\nThe overwhelming majority of the spectators in the crowd were supporting Colombia but there was no segregation between them and their Uruguayan counterparts.\n\nSeveral Uruguay players climbed into the crowd, seemingly to protect fans, with Nunez prominent.\n\nThe fighting continued for several minutes until police finally intervened.\n\nA group of around 80-100 Uruguayan fans remained in the stadium, on the pitch, long after the rest of the fans had left with Uruguay players returning to the field to meet them.\n\nUgly scenes also broke out on the field after the final whistle, with players and staff from both teams involved in a mass melee in the centre circle following Colombia's victory.\n\nCONMEBOL, the South American football confederation which organises the Copa America, issued a statement condemning the incidents.\n\n\"CONMEBOL strongly condemns any acts of violence that affect football. Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values.\n\n\"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the pitch. Our work is based on the conviction that football connects us and unites us, through its positive values.\n\n\"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all their passion into cheering on their teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nNunez's management company has been contacted for comment.\n\nLiverpool have not yet commented on the matter. as well as some of his Uruguay teammates - got among the group of fueding fans, having climbed up a fairly lofty barrier to get in closer to the action.\n\nClimbing up with relative ease, Nunez then made his way up beside a mixture of Uruguay fans and players who were grouped together, with some leaning forward and swiping and jostling with Colombia fans approaching from the other direction.\n\nHe disappeared from view momentarily before quickly reemerging and appearing to gesture with a nod towards some of the Colombian contingent, before he began to swipe out towards one of them.\n\nAfter a brief pause, Nunez then regrouped and began to advance forward towards the Colombia fans with his fist clenched as if ready to square off.\n\nOne fan - who appeared to be from the Uruguay side - gently pushed Nunez back in what appeared to be a precautionary move but the forward continued to push towards the opposition fans, before fan struck him in the head to spark further bedlam as the striker got lost in the sea of bodies.\n\nNunez was one of a number of Uruguay players involved in the brawl in the families' section inside the stadium, with some of the Uruguayan squad claiming Colombia fans had endangered family members.\n\nIn the wake of the incident Luis Suarez said: 'Obviously if someone is attacking your family you want to go and defend them but that doesn't justify the image that it created.\n\n'We had to protect our families that were there. What I could see there was a lot of family, a lot of children of my team-mates who were trapped and things were falling on them and you felt helpless.'\n\nColombia will face reigning Copa champions {"uri": "2024-07-418679664", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "13:06:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T13:06:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T03:52:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://supersport.com/hereforher/news/703e1584-3bbd-400f-8557-65dde3a2701c/nunez-uruguay-players-brawl-in-stands-with-fans-after-copa-loss", "title": "Nunez, Uruguay players brawl in stands with fans after Copa loss", "body": "Liverpool star Darwin Nunez and other Uruguay players were involved in a brawl with Colombian fans which erupted after their 1-0 Copa America semifinal defeat on Wednesday.\n\nUruguay striker Nunez unleashed a flurry of punches at Colombian supporters after jumping into the spectator seating at Charlotte's Bank of America Stadium following an ill-tempered loss to Colombia.\n\nUruguay central defender Jose Maria Gimenez said players had leapt into the melee out of concern for the safety of family members and loved ones watching the game.\n\n\"This is a disaster. Our family was in danger. We had to go to the stands to take out our loved ones, with tiny newborn babies,\" the Atletico Madrid player said.\n\n\"There was not a single police officer... I hope those who are organising this are a little more careful with the families.\n\n\"Every game it's been happening because there are people who don't know how to handle a couple of drinks.\"\n\nThe overwhelming majority of the spectators in the crowd were supporting Colombia but there was no segregation between them and their Uruguayan counterparts.\n\nSeveral Uruguay players climbed into the crowd, seemingly to protect fans, with Nunez prominent.\n\nThe fighting continued for several minutes until police finally intervened.\n\nA group of around 80-100 Uruguayan fans remained in the stadium, on the pitch, long after the rest of the fans had left with Uruguay players returning to the field to meet them.\n\nUgly scenes also broke out on the field after the final whistle, with players and staff from both teams involved in a mass melee in the centre-circle following Colombia's victory.\n\nCONMEBOL, the South American football confederation which organises the Copa America, issued a statement condemning the incidents.\n\n\"CONMEBOL strongly condemns any acts of violence that affects football. Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values.\n\n\"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the pitch. {"uri": "8219923232", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "06:53:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T06:53:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T06:53:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/colombia-beats-uruguay-1-0-and-will-face-lionel-messi-and-argentina-in-copa-america/article_30d9705c-cc24-5e4f-b6c2-8c942cf25e36.html", "title": "Colombia beats Uruguay 1-0 and will face Lionel Messi and Argentina in Copa America final", "body": "Colombia's coach Nestor Lorenzo watches his team playing Uruguay in a Copa America semifinal soccer match in Charlotte, N.C., Wednesday, July 10, 2024.\n\nCHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) -- Colombia is headed to the Copa America championship game for the first time in 23 years after a contentious win over Uruguay in which it played the second half a man short and players brawled with fans in the stands following the final whistle.\n\nJefferson Lerma scored in the 39th minute for a 1-0 win Wednesday night and a matchup with Lionel Messi and defending champion Argentina on Sunday.\n\n\"Until you overcome your weaknesses you cannot grow,\" Colombia coach Nester Lorenzo said through a interpreter. \"And when you overcome those obstacles you can grow.\"\n\nDaniel Mu\u00f1oz was ejected in first-half stoppage time for an elbow that led to his second yellow card. Despite Uruguay having 61.9% possession, Colombia held on to reach the championship for the first time since winning its only Copa title as host in 2001.\n\nColombia extended its unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games, one more than from 1992-94 and the longest current streak in men's international soccer.\n\n\"They are very hungry as players and very eager and they really add many elements to their game beyond the tactical side,\" Lorenzo said.\n\nIn a match that included seven yellow cards in addition to the red, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle. Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez and about a dozen Uruguay teammates went into the stands as fans brawled.\n\nA video showed N\u00fa\u00f1ez hitting a fan in Colombian team colors.\n\nCONMEBOL released a statement after the game saying that it strongly condemns any act of violence that affects the game.\n\n\"Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values,\" the organization said. \"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all of their passion into cheering on their national teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nDefending champion Argentina and Colombia meet at Miami Gardens, Florida, in the tournament finale. The Albiceleste are seeking a record 16th Copa title and are looking to join Spain from 2008-12 as the only countries to win three straight major championships.\n\nUruguay stays in Charlotte to meet Canada in Saturday night's third-place match.\n\nBefore an overwhelmingly pro-Colombia crowd of 70,644 that filled Bank of America Stadium with yellow jerseys and flags, Uruguay fell behind for the first time in the tournament.\n\nJames Rodr\u00edguez's corner kick was headed in from short range by Lerma, who outjumped Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez for his third international goal and second of the tournament. Rodr\u00edguez has six assists in the tournament -- triple the total of any other player.\n\nMu\u00f1oz received his first yellow card from Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos in the 31st minute for a reckless slide tackle on Maximiliano Ara\u00fajo and his second for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the stomach.\n\nRodr\u00edguez was given a yellow card in the 55th minute for arguing with Ramos when the referee failed to stop play after Richard R\u00edos was kicked on a shin by Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez.\n\nR\u00edos was removed on a stretcher, re-entered the match, then went down in another challenge and was substituted in the 62nd minute. Rodr\u00edguez was removed at the same time to keep him eligible for the final.\n\nColombia goalkeeper Camilo Vargas didn't have to make his first save until he stopped Nicol\u00e1s de la Cruz in the 68th minute.\n\nLuis Su\u00e1rez, Uruguay's career leader with 68 goals, entered in the 66th minute and hit the outside of a post with a shot in the 71st. He grasped his head in his hands in disgust.\n\n\"The moments in which we could unbalance the game, we did not succeed,\" Uruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa said. \"We should have generated more goal situations than we did.\"\n\nColombia's Mateus Uribe, another second-half sub, put an open shot wide in the 88th, and Uribe's open shot in the fourth minute of stoppage time ricocheted off the body of sliding goalkeeper Sergio Rochet and then the crossbar.\n\nUruguay moved Rochet up to the attacking half of the field in the final minute, desperate for a goal.\n\nThe match was played in 90-degree heat on a surface that was converted from artificial turf to grass in the weeks leading up the game.\n\nPlayers on the NFL's Carolina Panthers have been outspoken about soccer teams having the luxury of playing on grass on their home field. Players say NFL games on artificial turf leave them more susceptible to injuries.\n\nWith two games left, attendance of 1.48 million is just 1,663 shy of the total for the 2016 tournament in the United States,\n\nAP Copa America coverage: https://apnews.com/hub/copa-america", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": Liverpool also plans to speak with the UFF before making any decision on the matter, ESPN is reporting. The team also wants to check on Nunez's wellbeing in addition to his family's.\n\nUruguayan newspaper El Pais reported that Nunez jumped into the stands to confront Colombian supporters whom he believed posed a threat to his family and the families of his teammates. Nunez attempted to launch a chair into the crowd at one point, but was thwarted by a security guard.\n\nNunez as well as teammates Jose Gimenez and Ronald Araujo battled with Colombian fans while Tottenham midfielder Rodrigo Betancur was seen throwing two bottles into he crowd - one of which hit a Uruguayan staffer.\n\nThere is some concern that Nunez could face a lengthy ban from South American football's governing body, CONMEBOL. What's more, FIFA has the ability to issue a world-wide ban, which would impact Nunez's 2024-25 season with Liverpool.\n\nLiverpool FC officials plan to hold immediate talks with Darwin Nunez (center) after the brawl\n\nRead More Darwin Nunez may face a lengthy BAN after violent clashes with Colombia fans\n\nNunez and about a dozen Uruguay teammates went into the stands as fans brawled at Bank of America Stadium following a 1-0 loss to Colombia in a Copa America semifinal on Wednesday night.\n\nAfter a physical and contentious match, a melee broke out behind the Uruguay bench after Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos' final whistle.\n\nThe crowd of 70,644 was about 90% in favor in Colombia, but a small patch of Uruguay fans fought with Colombia supporters as beverages were thrown.\n\nN\u00fa\u00f1ez and teammates then climbed a staircase into the crowd. A video showed N\u00fa\u00f1ez hitting a fan in Colombian team colors.\n\nGimenez said players went in the crowd to protect their families.\n\n'This is a disaster. Our family is in danger. We had to get into the stands to take out our loved ones with small babies, newborns,' he told TUDN. 'Everything was a disaster. There was not a single police officer.'\n\nIt took more than 10 minutes for police to arrive on the scene and to restore order. The public address announcer asked for fans to leave the stadium, but several supporters remained.\n\nAbout 100 Uruguayan fans and members of the federation staff remained on the field for their own protection more than 20 minutes after the game, while Colombia fans made their way out to celebrate.\n\nCONMEBOL released a statement after the game saying that it strongly condemns any act of violence that affects the game.\n\n'Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values,' the organization said. 'There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all of their passion into cheering on their national teams and having an unforgettable party.'\n\nUruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa said he didn't see what was happening right away.\n\n'There was some argument in the midfield, and when I saw that happening, I went to the locker room. This is the fault of two or three people who had a few too many drinks and don't know how to drink.\"\n\nThe scenes in the dressing room followed scuffles on the pitch and as per Associated Press, police were only able to restore order after a 10 minute period.\n\nSouth American football governing body CONMEBOL have said they are investigating the situation.\n\nManager Marcelo Bielsa commented on the matter, telling a press conference:\n\n\"I thought that the incident ended with some argument on the midfield and when I saw that happening I went to the locker room.\n\n\"I thought that they were thanking the fans for their support. {"uri": "8219697014", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "03:29:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T03:29:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T03:29:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://larrybrownsports.com/soccer/uruguay-players-stands-fight-fans-colombia/635933", "title": "Uruguay players enter stands to fight fans after Copa America loss to Colombia", "body": "Almost exactly 20 years after the Malice at the Palace, the Copa America tournament has witnessed its own ugly incident between players and fans.\n\nUruguay lost to Colombia 1-0 during their Copa America semifinal match on Wednesday. The match took place at Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, N.C., and things took an ugly turn after the full-time whistle sounded.\n\nA number of Uruguay players entered the stands and began fighting with Colombia's fans, going through a connecting stairwell that led up from the pitch. Here is the video that was shown on the FOX television broadcast.\n\nUruguay's Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez, who plays at the club level for England's Liverpool F.C., was at the forefront of the altercation. N\u00fa\u00f1ez had taken off his jersey at that point but could easily be recognized by his distinctive man bun. Take a look at another video angle from the stands, which showed Colombia fans hurling trash and liquids at the Uruguay players, who responded by throwing punches.\n\nAn additional angle aired on local television showed N\u00fa\u00f1ez squaring up to fight (and then eating a shot to the dome).\n\nThe semifinal match was a contentious affair that saw Colombia go down to 10 men late during the first half after Daniel Mu\u00f1oz was sent off for violently elbowing Uruguay's Manuel Ugarte. Mu\u00f1oz had already gotten a yellow card earlier in the match and drew a second yellow with the elbow, triggering a red card and an automatic ejection.\n\nFour other yellow cards were shown between the two teams during the contest, and hostilities continued after the final whistle too. Players from both Uruguay and Colombia were seen exchanging shoves in a postgame scrum at midfield that was seemingly initiated by Uruguay forward Luis Suarez (who has a long history of issues with opponents).\n\nColombia now advances to play Argentina on Sunday in what will be their first Copa America final appearance since they won the whole thing back in 2001. Colombia also extended their national team's undefeated streak to a very impressive 28 matches. But their victory over Uruguay on Wednesday may end up getting overshadowed by the ugly melee between players and fans that took place in the stands afterwards.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8219650792", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "02:38:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T02:38:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T02:35:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/3012970-colombia-triumphs-over-uruguay-with-10-men-to-reach-copa-america-final", "title": "Colombia Triumphs Over Uruguay with 10 Men to Reach Copa America Final | Sports-Games", "body": "Colombia beat Uruguay 1-0 in the Copa America semi-final, setting up a final against Argentina. Jefferson Lerma's first-half header sealed the win despite Colombia playing the second half with 10 men. Uruguay missed several scoring opportunities, ultimately unable to capitalize on their numerical advantage.\n\nIn a dramatic Copa America semi-final, Colombia emerged victorious with a 1-0 score over Uruguay on Wednesday, even after playing the second half a man down. Jefferson Lerma's first-half header proved decisive in setting up a final clash against defending champions Argentina.\n\nThe match saw Colombia's Daniel Munoz sent off just before halftime. Despite dominating possession in the second half, Uruguay failed to convert opportunities, with Liverpool's Darwin Nunez missing three crucial chances earlier in the game. Luis Suarez, brought on in the 67th minute, also struck the post, adding to Uruguay's frustrations.\n\nColombia nearly extended their lead late on, but Mateus Uribe's attempts were off-target. The win extends Colombia's unbeaten run to 28 games, securing their place in Sunday's final. {"uri": "8220711276", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "15:11:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T15:11:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T15:10:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/uruguayan-soccer-players-colombian-fans-150419173.html", "title": "Uruguayan soccer players and Colombian fans fought, but Charlotte got the black eye", "body": "Uruguayan soccer players climbed into the Bank of America stands after their defeat in a Copa America semifinal Wednesday night, with several of them exchanging punches with Colombian fans.\n\nNo matter what the results of the brawl are -- suspensions, arrests, lawsuits, whatever -- it's clear that this postgame altercation gave Charlotte a black eye. You don't want your city mentioned as the dateline on coverage of an international sporting controversy, but here we are.\n\nWas there enough security at the stadium? Were the Uruguayan family members really in imminent danger, as a Uruguayan player would claim later on the official TV broadcast? Could all of this have been avoided? Those are the questions that will be wrestled with in the coming hours and days, and the questions that will sully what otherwise was a spectacular summer night of soccer, with Colombia upsetting Uruguay, 1-0, in one of the biggest soccer matches Charlotte has hosted. By winning, Colombia earned a spot in the Copa America final Sunday against Argentina.\n\nThis result delighted the near-sellout crowd of 70,644 fans at Bank of America Stadium, which was mostly clad in yellow and blue and appeared to be about 90% in favor of Colombia. Throughout the game -- actually, throughout this overly physical Copa tournament -- tempers flared and yellow cards were issued. After the game, there were some arguments on the field between the players.\n\nBut all of that was sort of normal. What brought this incident into the abnormal was what looked like -- from social media and Fox Soccer videos -- close to a dozen Uruguayan teammates going into the stands. This happens so rarely in sports that when it does, documentaries sometimes get made about it (see \"Malice in the Palace,\" the infamous NBA player/fan brawl between Detroit and Indiana in 2004.)\n\nUruguay is contending that its players believed their family members -- who were indeed surrounded by thousands of rowdy Colombian fans celebrating a victory -- were in danger. That's purportedly why what is usually a sacrosanct line -- the one between players and fans -- was breached.\n\nIn an impassioned interview with the official TV broadcast that was translated from Spanish and posted to X by the @FoxSoccer account, Uruguay captain Jose Maria Gimenez said in part: \"They stormed all our families, a certain sector of Colombian fans. They don't want me to say anything about what's going on, but this is a disaster. This is a disaster.\n\n\"Our family is in danger,\" Gimenez continued. \"We had to get on top of the stands ASAP to rescue our loved ones with newborn babies. It was a disaster. There was not a single policeman. ... And we were there facing the consequences for our people. Those who are organizing this (need to be) a little more careful with the families and with the people around the stadiums. Our families are suffering because of some who drink one or two shots of alcohol; who don't know how to drink; who behave like children.\"\n\nFortunately, everyone who walks into Bank of America stadium goes through some sort of metal detector. What happened Wednesday was seemingly confined to fisticuffs and thrown drinks. Any injuries likely will be minor.\n\nBut it's not a good look. The game had already been contentious, with Colombia's Daniel Munoz sent off for getting two yellow cards in the same contest. That left Colombia down one man for the entire second half. But Colombia held off Uruguay, made a first-half goal stand up and won anyway. Then came the brief disagreements and arguments on the field after the final whistle.\n\nAnd then, the fight in the stands.\n\nVideos appear to show some security people trying to get to the altercation that included Uruguayan star forward Darwin Nunez, but having difficulty due to crowded aisles and people leaning in trying to videotape or watch the fight. Stadium officials weren't immediately available for comment.\n\nUruguay still has another game to play in Charlotte, too. Because of the loss, Uruguay will play Canada on Saturday at Bank of America Stadium in the third-place game.\n\nSuspensions from the Copa America organization -- which sustained a black eye here, too -- would certainly seem likely. The tournament's governing body is called CONMEBOL and issued a milquetoast statement after that said \"CONMEBOL strongly condemns any act of violence that affects football\" and not much else.\n\nAfter the inevitable suspensions, I wonder if Uruguay will even have enough players to field a team against Canada.\n\nIn any case, it was a good night for a while for soccer, and for {"uri": "2024-07-418561788", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "11:26:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T11:26:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T10:46:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/uruguay-star-darwin-nunez-consoles-his-son-during-spat-with-colombian-fans-after-copa-america-exit", "title": "Uruguay star Darwin Nunez consoles his son during spat with Colombian fans after Copa America exit", "body": "It was a complete mess after the Copa America semifinal between Uruguay and Colombia.\n\nIn a tense and dramatic match at the Copa America, Uruguay lost a heartbreaking 1-0 to Colombia at the Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte. The match ended with chaotic scenes on and off the pitch.\n\nThe game's only goal came from Jefferson Lerma, who scored six minutes before halftime. Despite Colombia being reduced to ten men, Uruguay couldn't find an equalizer, leaving the players and fans deeply disappointed. The final whistle marked the beginning of more troubles as emotions ran high.\n\nChaos in the stands\n\nAfter the match, the situation escalated as Uruguay's star player, Darwin Nunez, became involved in a brawl. Nunez and other players climbed into the stands to confront Colombian supporters. This confrontation quickly turned violent, with players, officials, and supporters getting into physical altercations. Nunez himself was caught by a punch during the melee.\n\nThe trouble started when friends and family members of the Uruguayan team, who were sitting behind the team benches, were targeted by some Colombian fans. Uruguay captain Jose Maria Gimenez spoke to reporters about the lack of security at the stadium. He expressed his frustration, saying, \"It was a disaster; there was no police, and we had to defend our families. This is because of two or three who have one drink too many. A certain sector of the Colombian fans made an avalanche where our loved ones were.\"\n\nThe chaos left many Uruguayan players and staff shaken. Nunez, visibly upset, managed to bring his family to the safety of the pitch. He was seen hugging his son on the field, a poignant moment highlighting the distress caused by the incident. Other Uruguayan players and staff were also reported to have been punched and kicked during the chaos. The situation now awaits an official response from CONMEBOL, the governing body for South American football.\n\nThe aftermath of the match raised significant concerns about security at the stadium and the behavior of some fans. The lack of police presence and the inability to control the crowd led to dangerous situations for the players and their families. Uruguay's experience serves as a reminder of the need for better security measures at football matches to protect everyone involved.\n\nEmotional impact on Uruguay players and families\n\nThe emotional toll on the players and their families was significant. Nunez, who had to console his young son on the field, represented the distress felt by many. The sight of a professional athlete, known for his strength and resilience, showing vulnerability publicly struck a chord with many fans and observers. It underscored the fact that football players, despite their fame and prowess on the field, are human beings with families and loved ones who can be deeply affected by such incidents.\n\nThe violence also brought into focus the behavior of a small but disruptive group of fans who can tarnish the reputation of the sport. Football is meant to bring people together, fostering a sense of community and shared passion. However, when that passion turns into aggression, it creates an unsafe environment that detracts from the joy of the game.\n\nThe incident will likely be a topic of discussion for a long time, not only because of its impact on the current Copa America tournament but also because of its implications for future events. Authorities will need to implement stricter security measures and take decisive action against those who incite violence. This will help ensure that football remains a sport where players can perform, and families can enjoy the game without fear.\n\nFor now, Uruguay must regroup and focus on their upcoming challenges. The players will need to support each other and their families as they recover from this traumatic experience. The incident is a stark reminder of the unpredictable nature of football and the need for vigilance both on and off the field. Our work is based on the conviction that football connects us and unites us, through its positive values.\n\n\"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all their passion into cheering on their teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nNunez's management company has been contacted for comment.\n\nA skirmish behind the Uruguay bench saw a group of supporters clash with Colombia fans, who made up the vast majority of the crowd, with drinks thrown.\n\nPolice restored order after more than 10 minutes with a group of Uruguayan fans and team staff remaining on the field.\n\nA 39th-minute goal from Jefferson Lerma was the difference between the sides, with Colombia playing a man short after Daniel Munoz was sent off just before the break.\n\nUruguay captain Jose Maria Gimenez said the players were trying to defend their families.\n\n\"Let me say something before they cut you off because they won't let us speak into the microphone, they don't want me to say anything about what's going on but this is a disaster,\" Gimenez said on the official broadcast.\n\n\"Please be careful, our families are in the stands, there are little newborn babies. "Colombia defeat Uruguay 1-0 to reach Copa America final", "body": "Ten-man Colombia defeated Uruguay 1-0 to reach the final of the Copa America for the first time in 23 years after an ill-tempered semi-final on Wednesday.\n\nA 39th-minute Jefferson Lerma header sealed victory for the Colombians, who will now face holders Argentina in Sunday's final in Miami.\n\nIt was an anarchic semi-final played in front of a packed and passionate crowd which ended with scuffles on the field and fighting in the stands, including several players who had climbed in among supporters amid the flying punches.\n\nColombia, despite having Daniel Munoz sent off just before the interval and facing plenty of Uruguay pressure, hung on for a famous victory to the delight of their massive following of fans.\n\nThe downtown streets of the North Carolina city were packed with partying fans in bright yellow Colombia jerseys hours before the kick-off.\n\nInside the 74,800 capacity Bank of America Stadium, it was like a home game in Bogota with only pockets of Uruguayan supporters breaking up the wall of yellow on all four sides of the venue.\n\nNot surprisingly in such an atmosphere, Colombia started strongly with their livewire Liverpool winger Luis Diaz doing well to wriggle some space for a cross on the left, finding Daniel Munoz at the back post but the full-back's header was off target.\n\nUruguay were, as always, a threat on the counter-attack and their Liverpool star, Darwin Nunez, was close to finishing off one break when Rodrigo Bentancur found him with a clever pass but the forward poked his shot wide.\n\nNunez had another opening when Maximiliano Araujo played him clear in the inside-right channel but the striker rushed his shot, blasting high and wide.\n\nAt the other end, Colombia forced a turnover which led to James Rodriguez curling in a cross from the right but Jhon Cordoba's header was off target.\n\n- Lerma breakthrough -\n\nThe breakthrough came in the 39th minute when Lerma rose majestically above Jose Maria Gimenez and powerfully headed home Rodriguez's corner.\n\nIt was the sixth assist of the tournament for Rodriguez with the former Real Madrid midfielder beating the record for most assists in a single Copa, which was set by Lionel Messi in 2021.\n\nColombia looked to make the most of their momentum with Richard Rios forcing a save out of Uruguay keeper Sergio Rochet, after being played in by Munoz.\n\nBut having been so influential down the right in the opening half, Munoz lost his head completely, just before the break, picking up a second yellow card, after landing an elbow on Manuel Ugarte.\n\nIt was a moment of madness which left Colombia to defend their lead with just 10 men for the entire second half.\n\nColombia coach Nestor Lorenzo took off Rodriguez, who was also on a yellow card, in the 62nd minute as Uruguay gradually began to turn their numerical advantage into real pressure.\n\nNicolas de la Cruz threatened with a low drive before substitute Luis Suarez clipped the outside of the post with a drive from the edge of the box after good work from Federico Valverde.\n\nValverde, the Real Madrid midfielder, then went close himself with a low drive as Colombia's back-line continued to ride their luck.\n\nGiveaway from Uruguay keeper and fell to Mateus Uribe, who despite time and space placed his shot wide of the post.\n\nIn stoppage time Uruguay had a great chance to force penalties when Nunez laid the ball off to substitute Giorgian de Arrascaeta on the edge of the box but he leaned back and put his shot over the bar.\n\nThere was still time for Uribe to waste another chance to make sure of the win, this time hitting the bar in the final minute, but he will be forgiven his wastefulness by the delirious Colombian supporters.\n\nThe celebrations were marred by ugly scenes in the stands will concern organizers CONMEBOL ahead of a final which is sure to attract huge numbers of Argentines as well as Colombians.\n\nsev/rcw\n\nMore from this section\n\nProNotary Announces Exciting New Partner Program\n\n[Not Banned] Failed to Detect Location 12 Error Fixed by iToolab AnyGo Pok\u00e9mon GO Colombia played the entire second half one man down after Daniel Mu\u00f1oz was sent off with a red card for an aggressive shove in the first half.\n\nColombia heads to the Copa Am\u00e9rica final for just the third time in the tournament's history. The nation's last title in the tournament came in 2001, which was the last time Colombia reached the finals.\n\nThe match's only score resulted from a James Rodr\u00edguez corner kick that found just enough room to reach Lerma at the edge of the goal area. Lerma headed his shot in unison with a deflection attempt from a Uruguayan defender and landed the ball inside the bottom left edge of the net.\n\nYou can stream WCNC Charlotte on Roku, Amazon Fire TV and Apple TV, just download the free app.\n\nUruguay managed just two shots on goal in the match, both of which came in the second half. Uruguay's Luis Su\u00e1rez hit the right post in the 71st minute and Manuel Ugarte had a shot blocked in the 85th minute.\n\nColombia heads to the final without conceding a goal in the knockout stage after beating Panama 5-0 in the quarterfinal. Uruguay knocked off Brazil with penalty kicks in the quarterfinal.\n\nEven with Colombia being over 2,000 miles away from Charlotte, fans turned out in droves to support their national team.\n\n\"[Soccer] runs through our veins,\" Jeffrey Lopez said after traveling from Orlando to Charlotte to support Colombia. \"It's literally in our culture.\"\n\nUruguayan fans were also out in support of their team during the match as a packed Bank of America Stadium witnessed an intense competition between the two sides.\n\n\"It's growing here in the United States,\" Lopez said. \"We want it to continue to grow and then get other states here. More opportunities, more teams.\"\n\nTempers flared on and off the pitch during the match. Fans were seen fighting with what appeared to be Uruguayan players at Bank of America Stadium after the match.\n\nColombia will face Argentina, led by Lionel Messi, in Miami on Sunday. {"uri": "8219721188", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "03:59:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T03:59:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T03:58:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/the-spun/video-fight-broke-out-between-players-fans-at-end-of-copa-am-rica-semifinal/article_09e4fcec-67df-5166-afd2-d42f3afc88da.html", "title": "Video: Fight Broke Out Between Players, Fans At End Of Copa Am\u00e9rica Semifinal", "body": "A wild scene unfolded at the end of Wednesday's Copa Am\u00e9rica semifinal matchup between Uruguay and Colombia.\n\nDespite a Daniel Mu\u00f1oz ejection leaving them short-handed, Colombia advanced to the final with a 1-0 win. After the loss, Uruguay players went into the stands and fought with Colombia supporters.\n\nPunches and drinks were thrown during a heated altercation at Bank of America Stadium. Liverpool striker Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez was among the Uruguay players who left the pitch into the Charlotte crowd.\n\nFOX Soccer shared footage of the chaotic scene:\n\nWednesday's game wasn't much prettier before the post-game brawl. Uruguay tallied more yellow cards (three) than shots on goal (two) despite possessing the ball for 61.9 percent of the match.\n\nColombia prevailed after playing with 10 men throughout the second half. Mu\u00f1oz received a second yellow card during the opening half's stoppage time for elbowing Manuel Ugarte.\n\nAfter scoring 13 goals in four group-stage victories, Uruguay went consecutive games without finding the net. They advanced past Brazil on penalty picks, but Jefferson Lerma broke Wednesday's stalemate by giving Colombia its lone goal on a corner kick in the 39th minute.\n\nColombia will play in their third Copa Am\u00e9rica final and first since 2001. They'll face Argentina, who can pass Uruguay by winning their record-setting 16th title.\n\nMiami's Hard Rock Stadium will host the final matchup on Sunday at 8 p.m. ET.\n\nRelated: Fans Are Bashing Video footage revealed Suarez's role in antagonising the opposition, contributing to the ensuing brawl.\n\nAs the final seconds wound down and Colombia secured their 1-0 victory, chaos erupted in the middle of the pitch. Players, referees, camera crews, and business executives became entangled in a frenzied scrum, the scene a blur of motion and confusion.\n\nAmid it all, the Uruguayan legend, donning his iconic No. 9 jersey, was seen towering over rival players and shoving members believed to be part of the opposition's coaching staff. With tensions running high, Suarez pushed a man in a red hat off balance, igniting further chaos as a reserve Uruguayan player retaliated.\n\nREAD MORE: Darwin Nunez and Luis Diaz shared exchange moments before ugly Copa America brawl\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool should pile on Chelsea misery as Michael Edwards can fix $3M transfer error\n\nThe commentary team captured the moment perfectly: \"I'll give you one guess who sparked this originally,\" they said as the cameras zoomed in on Suarez. \"And now it's boiling over,\" they continued as more coaches rushed in to subdue the pandemonium.\n\nThe heated tensions didn't stop at the pitch; they spilled dramatically into the stands when Darwin Nunez was one of a number of Uruguay players who scaled the stands and clashed with Colombia fans. Nunez, shirtless and visibly furious, was seen exchanging punches, defending himself while shouting at his antagonists as drinks flew across the stands.\n\nThe crowd continued to taunt the striker as the situation turned into a chaotic spectacle. Uruguay defender Jose Maria Gimenez claimed players were defending their nearby families from Colombia fans. Gimenez said: \"It was a disaster; there was no police and we had to defend our families.\"\n\nColombia clinched a 1-0 victory over Uruguay after Jefferson Lerma connected on a header from a whipping cross by James Rodriguez, giving the team an early lead in the first half. However, Daniel Munoz made the win more challenging for Colombia, reducing them to 10 men after receiving a second yellow card for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the chest, drawing an unnecessary foul.\n\nDespite having the numerical advantage, Uruguay struggled to generate any meaningful attack, managing just two shots on goal throughout the game. They attempted to apply pressure, winning late free kicks in the game's defining moments, but failed to convert any of their chances as the clock wound down.\n\nCurrently, CONMEBOL has not addressed any of the video footage from the tumultuous semifinal, nor has it announced any punishments. But in the past, the governing body announced its speedy condemnation of violence last year when three fans were arrested over a brawl in Rio de Janeiro ahead of the Copa Libertadores final between semi-final which was played in front of a packed and passionate crowd, ended with scuffles on the field and fighting in the stands, including several players who had climbed in among supporters amid the flying punches.\n\nColombia, despite having Daniel Munoz sent off just before the interval and facing plenty of Uruguay pressure, hung on for a famous victory to the delight of their massive following of fans.\n\nThe win was the 28th game without defeat for Colombia, setting a new record for the team.\n\nThe downtown streets of the North Carolina city were packed with partying fans in bright yellow Colombia jerseys hours before the kick-off.\n\nNot surprisingly in such an atmosphere, Colombia started strongly with their livewire Liverpool winger Luis Diaz doing well to wriggle some space for a cross on the left, finding Daniel Munoz at the back post but the full-back's header was off target.\n\nUruguay were, as always, a threat on the counter-attack and their Liverpool star, Darwin Nunez was close to finishing off one break when Rodrigo Bentancur found him with a clever pass but the forward poked his shot wide.\n\nNunez had another opening when Maximiliano Araujo played him clear in the inside-right channel but the striker rushed his shot, blasting high and wide.\n\nAt the other end, Colombia forced a turnover which led to James Rodriguez curling in a cross from the right but Jhon Cordoba's header was off target.\n\n- Lerma breakthrough -\n\nThe breakthrough came in the 39th minute when Lerma rose majestically above Jose Gimenez and powerfully headed home Rodriguez's corner.\n\nIt was the sixth assist of the tournament for Rodriguez with the former Real Madrid midfielder beating the record for most assists in a single Copa, which was set by Lionel Messi in 2021.\n\nColombia looked to make the most of their momentum with Richard Rios forcing a save out of Uruguay keeper Sergio Rochet, after being played in by Munoz.\n\nBut having been so influential down the right in the opening half, Munoz lost his head completely, just before the break, picking up a second yellow card, after landing an elbow on Manuel Ugarte.\n\nIt was a moment of madness that left Colombia to defend their lead with just 10 men for the entire second half.\n\nColombia coach Nestor Lorenzo took off Rodriguez, who was also on a yellow card, in the 62nd minute as drive from the edge of the box after good work from Federico Valverde.\n\nValverde, the Real Madrid midfielder, then went close himself with a low drive as Colombia's back-line continued to ride their luck.\n\nGiveaway from Uruguay's keeper and fell to Mateus Uribe, who, despite time and space, placed his shot wide of the post.\n\nIn stoppage time, Uruguay had a great chance to force penalties when Nunez laid the ball off to substitute Giorgian de Arrascaeta on the edge of the box but he leaned back and put his shot over the bar.\n\nThere was still time for Uribe to waste another chance to make sure of the win, this time hitting the bar in the final minute, but he will be forgiven for his wastefulness by the delirious Colombian supporters.\n\nUruguay's Argentine coach Marcelo Bielsa took the blame for being unable to craft a win against ten men in the second half.\n\n\"Uruguay were clearly in a position to win this game...I take special responsibility for not having been able to establish an advantage when we had the players capable of doing so,\" he said.\n\nHis compatriot and counterpart Lorenzo said he and his team had been rewarded for their positive approach to the game.\n\n\"We Clearly shaken by the confrontation, Nunez stroked his son's back while his distraught spouse spoke and gestured toward the crowd.\n\nOther new surfaced footage shows Nunez darting towards the crowd while holding a black chair, which he attempted to launch towards the fans. A security guard thwarted Nunez, but the violent encounter was only getting started.\n\nDarwin Nunez consoles his young son in the aftermath of Wednesday's shocking brawl\n\nNunez attempted to throw a chair into the crowd, but was thwarted by a security guard\n\nRead More More Americans watching EuroCup than Copa America?\n\nSeveral of Nunez's teammates entered the fray as police remained curiously absent from the scene.\n\n'This is an embarrassment, there wasn't one police officer to control them. fans.\n\nThe families of Uruguay players were then escorted out of the stadium through a different exit to ensure their safety, according to reporter Favian Renkel.\n\nUruguay manager Marcelo Bielsa was asked about the scenes after the match, and said he 'didn't see everything.'\n\n'I went to the locker room...the Uruguayan players were thanking the Uruguayan fans for their support,' he continued.\n\nNunez scuffles with fans after Uruguay lost after the Copa America 2024 semifinals\n\nAraujo, who missed the game through injury, could be seen clashing with fans in the stands\n\nUruguay moves on to face Canada in the Copa America third-place game on Saturday, while Colombia will play rival Argentina in Sunday's final.\n\nThe skirmish followed a hotly-contested match which saw Colombia just barely hold on to a one-goal lead to advance to the Copa America final vs. Argentina.\n\nWithin a fiery atmosphere at Bank of America Stadium, Colombia saw a man sent off, both {"uri": "2024-07-418165468", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "05:02:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T05:02:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T02:12:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/07/10/colombia-beats-uruguay-1-0-and-will-face-lionel-messi-and-argentina-in-copa-america-final/", "title": "Colombia beats Uruguay 1-0 and will face Lionel Messi and Argentina in Copa America final", "body": "CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) -- Colombia is headed to the Copa America championship game for the first time in 23 years after a contentious win over Uruguay in which it played the second half a man short and players brawled with fans in the stands following the final whistle.\n\nJefferson Lerma scored in the 39th minute for a 1-0 win Wednesday night and a matchup with Lionel Messi and defending champion Argentina on Sunday.\n\n\"Until you overcome your weaknesses you cannot grow,\" Colombia coach Nester Lorenzo said through a interpreter. \"And when you overcome those obstacles you can grow.\"\n\nDaniel Mu\u00f1oz was ejected in first-half stoppage time for an elbow that led to his second yellow card. Despite Uruguay having 61.9% possession, Colombia held on to reach the championship for the first time since winning its only Copa title as host in 2001.\n\nColombia extended its unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games, one more than from 1992-94 and the longest current streak in men's international soccer.\n\n\"They are very hungry as players and very eager and they really add many elements to their game beyond the tactical side,\" Lorenzo said.\n\nIn a match that included seven yellow cards in addition to the red, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle. Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez and about a dozen Uruguay teammates went into the stands as fans brawled.\n\nA video showed N\u00fa\u00f1ez hitting a fan in Colombian team colors.\n\nCONMEBOL released a statement after the game saying that it strongly condemns any act of violence that affects the game.\n\n\"Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values,\" the organization said. \"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all of their passion into cheering on their national teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nDefending champion Argentina and Colombia meet at Miami Gardens, Florida, in the tournament finale. The Albiceleste are seeking a record 16th Copa title and are looking to join Spain from 2008-12 as the only countries to win three straight major championships.\n\nUruguay stays in Charlotte to meet Canada in Saturday night's third-place match.\n\nBefore an overwhelmingly pro-Colombia crowd of 70,644 that filled Bank of America Stadium with yellow jerseys and flags, Uruguay fell behind for the first time in the tournament.\n\nJames Rodr\u00edguez's corner kick was headed in from short range by Lerma, who outjumped Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez for his third international goal and second of the tournament. Rodr\u00edguez has six assists in the tournament -- triple the total of any other player.\n\nMu\u00f1oz received his first yellow card from Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos in the 31st minute for a reckless slide tackle on Maximiliano Ara\u00fajo and his second for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the stomach.\n\nRodr\u00edguez was given a yellow card in the 55th minute for arguing with Ramos when the referee failed to stop play after Richard R\u00edos was kicked on a shin by Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez.\n\nR\u00edos was removed on a stretcher, re-entered the match, then went down in another challenge and was substituted in the 62nd minute. Rodr\u00edguez was removed at the same time to keep him eligible for the final.\n\nColombia goalkeeper Camilo Vargas didn't have to make his first save until he stopped Nicol\u00e1s de la Cruz in the 68th minute.\n\nLuis Su\u00e1rez, Uruguay's career leader with 68 goals, entered in the 66th minute and hit the outside of a post with a shot in the 71st. He grasped his head in his hands in disgust.\n\n\"The moments in which we could unbalance the game, we did not succeed,\" Uruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa said. \"We should have generated more goal situations than we did.\"\n\nColombia's Mateus Uribe, another second-half sub, put an open shot wide in the 88th, and Uribe's open shot in the fourth minute of stoppage time ricocheted off the body of sliding goalkeeper Sergio Rochet and then the crossbar.\n\nUruguay moved Rochet up to the attacking half of the field in the final minute, desperate for a goal.\n\nThe match was played in 90-degree heat on a surface that was converted from artificial turf to grass in the weeks leading up the game.\n\nPlayers on the NFL's Carolina Panthers have been outspoken about soccer teams having the luxury of playing on grass on their home field. Players say NFL games on artificial turf leave them more susceptible to injuries.\n\nWith two games left, attendance of 1.48 million is just 1,663 shy of the total for the 2016 tournament in the Click and follow now!\n\nUgly scenes erupted after the Copa America semi-final match between Uruguay and Colombia at the Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, leading to a post-match brawl involving players and fans.\n\nPlayers of the Uruguayan national team, with Liverpool striker Darwin Nunez playing a starring role, were sighted in a fistfight with scores of Colombian fans following an ill-tempered defeat.\n\nUruguay, one of only three sides to finish the group stages with an unblemished record, were poised to make a return to the final for the first time since 2011.\n\nHowever, their hopes were dashed by a Jefferson Lerma goal six minutes before halftime, which proved decisive as the James Rodriguez-led Colombian side marched on to the grand finale.\n\nThe final whistle sparked scenes of jubilation among Colombia players and fans alike.\n\nAccording to Forbes, Los Cafeteros' win over Uruguay also extended their unbeaten streak to a record 28 international After his career started to go downhill following his move away from Real Madrid, Rodriguez has found his second wind as he continued his magical run in the semi-final against Uruguay.\n\nIn the 39th minute, Rodriguez produced a pinpoint cross and found Jefferson Lerma, who headed the ball into the back of the net. With Colombia in the lead, Rodriguez claimed his sixth assist in the ongoing campaign of the Copa America. He surpassed Argentina maestro, Lionel Messi's tally of five in a single Copa America campaign. He achieved the feat in 2021, during Albiceleste's title-winning campaign. (Copa America: Massive Fight Breaks Out After Uruguay-Colombia Semi-Final, Darwin Nunez Involved!)\n\nThe 32-year-old attacking midfielder kicked off his campaign by bagging two assists against Paraguay in Colombia's opening group game. He went on to register one against Costa Rica and two again in Colombia's quarterfinal clash against Panama.\n\nDespite taking a lead, Colombia's task to defend their slender one-goal advantage became an intricate affair. Defender Daniel Munoz swung his elbow at Uruguay's Manuel Ugarte, was shown a second yellow card and got sent off the field in the first-half stoppage time. With time running out, Uruguay decided to introduce one of their most prolific strikers, Luis Suarez, into the thick of the action.\n\nIn the 71st minute, he had the opportunity to bring the game back on level terms but failed to deliver in the decisive moment. Colombia struck the crossbar in the final minutes of the game, but one goal turned out to be sufficient to seal their date with Argentina in the final.\n\nAfter the game, a scuffle broke out between the Uruguay players and Colombia fans. In the video that went viral on social media, Liverpool striker Darwin Nunez and some Uruguay players allegedly climbed into the stands, had an altercation and clashed with each other. Nunez was allegedly at the forefront of the incident. Uruguay will face Canada in the third-place playoff on Saturday. Our family was in danger. We had to go to the stands to take out our loved ones, with tiny newborn babies,\" the Atletico Madrid player said.\n\n\"There was not a single police officer...I hope those who are organising this are a little more careful with the families.\n\n\"Every game it's been happening because there are people who don't know how to handle a couple of drinks.\"\n\nThe overwhelming majority of the spectators in the crowd were supporting Colombia but there was no segregation between them and their Uruguayan counterparts.\n\nWhile punches were thrown several Uruguay players climbed into the crowd, seemingly to protect them, with Nunez prominent among them.\n\nThe fighting continued for several minutes until police finally intervened.\n\nA group of around 80-100 Uruguayan fans remained in {"uri": "8219668064", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "02:58:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T02:58:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T02:57:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/copa-america-colombia-upends-uruguay-a-man-down-in-tense-semifinal-that-ends-in-violence-015800945.html", "title": "Copa Am\u00e9rica: Colombia upends Uruguay a man down in tense semifinal that ends in violence", "body": "Playing shorthanded for more than a half, Colombia upended Uruguay, 1-0 in a tense Copa Am\u00e9rica semifinal Wednesday night that ended with a postgame scuffle on the field and a brawl in the stands.\n\nWith the win, Colombia advances to its first Copa Am\u00e9rica final and its second ever since winning the championship in 2001. There, it will face a stiff task against Lionel Messi and reigning World Cup champion Argentina, which cruised through its half of the field while allowing a single goal in five games.\n\nColombia and Argentina will face off Sunday night in Miami.\n\nWednesday's semifinal was played in Charlotte, but might as well have been hosted in Bogot\u00e1. The Bank of America stands were packed with fans sporting yellow Colombia gear. Colombia delivered for those fans in a testy game that tallied six yellow cards and a red-card ejection before the postgame exchanges.\n\nColombia entered Wednesday's game as the highest-scoring team in the tournament (11 goals), fresh off a 5-0 quarterfinal win over Panama. It struck first on a corner kick in the 38th minute. James Rodr\u00edguez sent the ball to the back post on the corner kick, where Jefferson Lerma leapt high in the air and squeezed the ball between the post and goalkeeper Sergio Rochet.\n\nThe goal was just the second allowed by Uruguay all tournament.\n\nColombia's defense, meanwhile, stifled a Uruguay offense that scored nine goals in four previous Copa Am\u00e9rica games. Uruguay didn't put any of its four first-half shots on goal.\n\nThe tide threatened to shift late in the second half. Colombia's Daniel Mu\u00f1oz, who picked up a yellow card earlier in the half on a tackle, picked up his second yellow just before the half. After a scuffle following a foul on Colombia's Davinson S\u00e1nchez, Uruguay's Manuel Ugarte grabbed Mu\u00f1oz's jersey from behind.\n\nMu\u00f1oz responded with an elbow to the chest that knocked Ugarte to the turf, drawing his second yellow and ultimately a red card that led to his ejection.\n\nHead coach N\u00e9stor Lorenzo protested to no avail. Mu\u00f1oz was tossed, and Colombia was set to play the second half a man down.\n\nUruguay's offense was much improved after halftime as it controlled the ball and put two of its seven shots on goal. But it didn't convert on the scoreboard as Colombia held on for victory.\n\nThe tension that marked the game throughout carried over at midfield after the final whistle. Players traded shoves and blows at midfield in the moments after the game.\n\nThe scuffle was eventually subdued on the field, but carried over into the stands, where Uruguayan players including Liverpool's Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez traded blows and shoves with Colombia fans. Fans were seen throwing drinks toward players, while N\u00fa\u00f1ez charged through the stands to fight with fans.\n\nUruguay's Jos\u00e9 Maria Gimenez told the broadcast after the game that players were defending their families from a group of Colombia fans who swarmed them. He called for changes in organization and security.\n\nThe consequences of the postgame brawl weren't immediately clear. {"uri": "8220612215", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "14:06:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T14:06:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T14:05:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://wsvn.com/sports/colombia-beats-uruguay-1-0-and-will-face-lionel-messi-and-argentina-in-copa-america-final/", "title": "Colombia beats Uruguay 1-0 and will face Lionel Messi and Argentina in Copa America final - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) -- Colombia is headed to the Copa America championship game for the first time in 23 years after a contentious win over Uruguay in which it played the second half a man short and players brawled with fans in the stands following the final whistle.\n\nJefferson Lerma scored in the 39th minute for a 1-0 win Wednesday night and a matchup with Lionel Messi and defending champion Argentina on Sunday.\n\n\"Until you overcome your weaknesses you cannot grow,\" Colombia coach Nester Lorenzo said through a interpreter. \"And when you overcome those obstacles you can grow.\"\n\nDaniel Mu\u00f1oz was ejected in first-half stoppage time for an elbow that led to his second yellow card. Despite Uruguay having 61.9% possession, Colombia held on to reach the championship for the first time since winning its only Copa title as host in 2001.\n\nColombia extended its unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games, one more than from 1992-94 and the longest current streak in men's international soccer.\n\n\"They are very hungry as players and very eager and they really add many elements to their game beyond the tactical side,\" Lorenzo said.\n\nIn a match that included seven yellow cards in addition to the red, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle. Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez and about a dozen Uruguay teammates went into the stands as fans brawled.\n\nA video showed N\u00fa\u00f1ez hitting a fan in Colombian team colors.\n\nCONMEBOL released a statement after the game saying that it strongly condemns any act of violence that affects the game.\n\n\"Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values,\" the organization said. \"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all of their passion into cheering on their national teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nDefending champion Argentina and Colombia meet at Miami Gardens, Florida, in the tournament finale. The Albiceleste are seeking a record 16th Copa title and are looking to join Spain from 2008-12 as the only countries to win three straight major championships.\n\nUruguay stays in Charlotte to meet Canada in Saturday night's third-place match.\n\nBefore an overwhelmingly pro-Colombia crowd of 70,644 that filled Bank of America Stadium with yellow jerseys and flags, Uruguay fell behind for the first time in the tournament.\n\nJames Rodr\u00edguez's corner kick was headed in from short range by Lerma, who outjumped Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez for his third international goal and second of the tournament. Rodr\u00edguez has six assists in the tournament -- triple the total of any other player.\n\nMu\u00f1oz received his first yellow card from Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos in the 31st minute for a reckless slide tackle on Maximiliano Ara\u00fajo and his second for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the stomach.\n\nRodr\u00edguez was given a yellow card in the 55th minute for arguing with Ramos when the referee failed to stop play after Richard R\u00edos was kicked on a shin by Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez.\n\nR\u00edos was removed on a stretcher, re-entered the match, then went down in another challenge and was substituted in the 62nd minute. Rodr\u00edguez was removed at the same time to keep him eligible for the final.\n\nColombia goalkeeper Camilo Vargas didn't have to make his first save until he stopped Nicol\u00e1s de la Cruz in the 68th minute.\n\nLuis Su\u00e1rez, Uruguay's career leader with 68 goals, entered in the 66th minute and hit the outside of a post with a shot in the 71st. He grasped his head in his hands in disgust.\n\n\"The moments in which we could unbalance the game, we did not succeed,\" Uruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa said. \"We should have generated more goal situations than we did.\"\n\nColombia's Mateus Uribe, another second-half sub, put an open shot wide in the 88th, and Uribe's open shot in the fourth minute of stoppage time ricocheted off the body of sliding goalkeeper Sergio Rochet and then the crossbar.\n\nUruguay moved Rochet up to the attacking half of the field in the final minute, desperate for a goal.\n\nThe match was played in 90-degree heat on a surface that was converted from artificial turf to grass in the weeks leading up the game.\n\nPlayers on the NFL's Carolina Panthers have been outspoken about soccer teams having the luxury of playing on grass on their home field. Players say NFL games on artificial turf leave them more susceptible to injuries.\n\nWith two games left, attendance of 1.48 million is just 1,663 shy of the total for the 2016 tournament in the United States.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. Gimenez said on TV after the incident that the families of players, who were seated near the fans, were \"overrun\" by supporters. He explained that they intervened to protect their loved ones.\n\nUgly Scenes at the Stands\n\n\"This is an embarrassment, there wasn't one police officer to control there. Colombia appeared more likely to create the first big chance, but it was Uruguay's Darwin Nunez who came close.\n\nNunez battled past multiple Colombian defenders in the penalty area and unleashed a powerful shot to the bottom left corner, narrowly missing. Despite several chances, the Uruguayan striker couldn't score.\n\nAfter losing center back Ronald Araujo to injury against Brazil, Uruguay suffered another blow as Rodrigo Bentancur went off injured in the 35th minute with Guillermo Varela replacing him.\n\nIn the 40th minute, Colombia finally broke through as James Rodriguez's set-piece delivery leading to a headed goal. The win secures Colombia's spot in the Copa America final against Argentina. Colombia played with just ten men throughout the second half, yet held on to secure a place in the final against Argentina.\n\nColombia's winning goal came from James Rodr\u00edguez's corner kick, which Lerma headed in, outjumping Uruguay's Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez. Despite losing Daniel Mu\u00f1oz to a red card in first-half stoppage time, Colombia extended its unbeaten streak to 28 matches, a team record.\n\nThe match was contentious, featuring seven yellow cards and one red. He achieved the feat in 2021, during Albiceleste's title-winning campaign.\n\nThe 32-year-old attacking midfielder kicked off his campaign by bagging two assists against Paraguay in Colombia's opening group game.\n\nHe went on to register one against Costa Rica and two again in Colombia's quarterfinal clash against Panama.\n\nDespite taking a lead, Colombia's task to defend their slender one-goal advantage became an intricate affair. Defender Daniel Munoz swung his elbow at Uruguay's Manuel Ugarte, was shown a second yellow card and got sent off the field in the first-half stoppage time.\n\nWith time running out, Uruguay decided to introduce one of their most prolific strikers, Luis Suarez, into the thick of the action.\n\nIn the 71st minute, he had the opportunity to bring the game back on level terms but failed to deliver in the decisive moment.\n\nColombia struck the crossbar in the final minutes of the game, but one goal turned out to be sufficient to seal their date with Argentina in the final.\n\nAfter the game, a scuffle broke out between the Uruguay players and Colombia fans. In the video that went viral on social media, Liverpool striker Darwin Nunez and some Uruguay players allegedly climbed into the stands, had an altercation and clashed with each other. Nunez was allegedly at the forefront of the incident.\n\nUruguay will face Canada in the third-place playoff on Saturday. Colombia will take on Argentina in the final at Hard Rock Stadium on Sunday. {"uri": "8219661636", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "02:50:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T02:50:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T02:49:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/copa-america-uruguay-players-including-darwin-nunez-brawl-with-fans-after-loss-to-colombia-023049246.html", "title": "Copa Am\u00e9rica: Uruguay players, including Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez, brawl with fans after loss to Colombia", "body": "Uruguay's time in the 2024 Copa Am\u00e9rica ended in ugly fashion, and not just because they lost to a short-handed Colombia squad in the semifinals.\n\nThe postgame scene between Uruguay and Colombia descended into chaos in Charlotte when a group of La Celeste players entered the stands at Bank of America Stadium and brawled with a group of Colombian fans. The charge appeared to be spearheaded by Liverpool striker Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez, who could be seen throwing punches in the middle of the fracas.\n\nMore angles:\n\nUruguay's Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez spoke to the broadcast after the incident, claiming the brawl was preceded by the Uruguay players' families being harassed by a group of Colombia fans and urging the tournament organizers to make changes with security.\n\nThe violence was preceded by a frustrating loss for Uruguay, which was playing for a chance to face Argentina in the final for its first Copa Am\u00e9rica title since 2011. Instead, it will face Canada in the third-place game on Saturday, and it will almost certainly be missing a few players as discipline for the brawl is handed out.\n\nUruguay was favored to defeat Los Cafeteros in the semifinal, but fell behind in the 40th minute on a beautiful corner kick from James Rodriguez that Jefferson Lerma headed into the net. Their hopes for a comeback were bolstered early in the second half when Colombia's Daniel Mu\u00f1oz hit Manuel Ugarte, leading to a second yellow card and leaving his team in a 10-vs.-11 situation.\n\nUruguay kept up the pressure and had some real scoring chances, but just couldn't get the ball in the net by the time expired. (AP) -- Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez and about a dozen Uruguay teammates went into the stands as fans brawled at Bank of America Stadium following a 1-0 loss to Colombia in a Copa America semifinal on Wednesday night.\n\nAfter a physical and contentious match, a melee broke out behind the Uruguay bench after Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos' final whistle.\n\nThe crowd of 70,644 was about 90% in favor in Colombia, but a small patch of Uruguay fans fought with Colombia supporters as beverages were thrown.\n\nN\u00fa\u00f1ez and teammates then climbed a staircase into the crowd. A video showed N\u00fa\u00f1ez hitting a fan in Colombian team colors.\n\nUruguay captain Jos\u00e9 Gim\u00e9nez said players went in the crowd to protect their families.\n\n\"This is a disaster. Colombia edge Uruguay 1-0 to book Copa America final against Argentina", "body": "(Reuters) - Colombia beat Uruguay 1-0 in their Copa America semi-final on Thursday despite being reduced to 10 men for 45 minutes to book a title decider against defending champions Argentina thanks to a first-half header from Jefferson Lerma.\n\nUruguay's Darwin Nunez missed several chances in the first half and Colombia made them pay when Lerma rose above the defence on a corner in the 39th minute and squeezed his header past goalkeeper Sergio Rochet.\n\nColombia went down to 10 men just before halftime when Daniel Munoz lost his cool and got himself sent off, with the right back receiving a second yellow card for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the chest when play was stopped.\n\nUruguay dominated possession in the second half and veteran striker Luis Suarez nearly equalised when he hit the post but Colombia bravely held on for a famous win and will play Argentina in Sunday's final.\n\nUruguay will play Canada a day earlier in the third-place playoff.\n\n(Reporting by Rohith Nair in Bengaluru; Editing by Peter Rutherford)", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com.my", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Star
