(AP) -- Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez and about a dozen Uruguay teammates went into the stands as fans brawled at Bank of America Stadium following a 1-0 loss to Colombia in a Copa America semifinal on Wednesday night.\n\nAfter a physical and contentious match, a melee broke out behind the Uruguay bench after Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos' final whistle.\n\nThe crowd of 70,644 was about 90% in favor in Colombia, but a small patch of Uruguay fans fought with Colombia supporters as beverages were thrown.\n\nN\u00fa\u00f1ez and teammates then climbed a staircase into the crowd. A video showed N\u00fa\u00f1ez hitting a fan in Colombian team colors.\n\nUruguay captain Jos\u00e9 Gim\u00e9nez said players went in the crowd to protect their families.\n\n\"This is a disaster. Our family is in danger. We had to get into the stands to take out our loved ones with small babies, newborns,\" he told TUDN. \"Everything was a disaster. There was not a single police officer.\"\n\nIt took more than 10 minutes for police to arrive on the scene and to restore order. The public address announcer asked for fans to leave the stadium, but several supporters remained.\n\nAbout 100 Uruguayan fans and and members of the federation staff remained on the field more than 20 minutes after the game, while Colombia fans made their way out to celebrate.\n\n\"There was some argument in the midfield, and when I saw that happening, I went to the locker room. I thought they were thanking the fans for their support,\" Uruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa said. \"But then I learned there were some problems over there unfortunately.\"\n\nAP Copa America coverage: {"uri": "8219847204", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "05:53:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T05:53:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T05:53:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.timesfreepress.com/news/2024/jul/10/colombia-beats-uruguay-faces-argentina-in-copa/", "title": "Colombia beats Uruguay, faces Argentina in Copa America final", "body": "CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- Colombia is headed to the Copa America championship game for the first time in 23 years after a contentious semifinal win over Uruguay in which it played the second half a man short and players brawled with fans in the stands after the final whistle.\n\nJefferson Lerma scored in the 39th minute for a 1-0 win Wednesday night at Bank of America Stadium, the home of the NFL's Carolina Panthers, to set up a showdown with reigning Copa America champion Argentina and star forward Lionel Messi on Sunday night at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Florida.\n\n\"Until you overcome your weaknesses, you cannot grow,\" Colombia coach Nester Lorenzo said through a interpreter. \"And when you overcome those obstacles, you can grow.\"\n\nDaniel Mu\u00f1oz was ejected in first-half stoppage time for an elbow that led to his second yellow card of the night. And despite Uruguay having 61.9% possession, Colombia held on to reach the title match of CONMEBOL's championship event for South American national men's soccer teams for the first time since winning its only Copa America title as host in 2001.\n\nArgentina beat Canada 2-0 in the first semifinal on Tuesday night at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey, the site of the 2026 World Cup final. Also the reigning World Cup champion, Argentina will be seeking a record-breaking 16th Copa America title this weekend and trying to join Spain as the only men's national soccer teams to win three straight major titles. La Roja sandwiched its 2010 World Cup title with the 2008 and 2012 UEFA European Championship tournament crowns.\n\nUruguay will remain in Charlotte to meet Canada in Saturday night's third-place match.\n\nColombia extended its unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games, one more than its from 1992 to 1994 and the longest current streak in international men's soccer.\n\n\"They are very hungry as players and very eager, and they really add many elements to their game beyond the tactical side,\" Lorenzo said.\n\nIn a match that included seven yellow cards in addition to the red for Mu\u00f1oz, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle. Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez and about a dozen Uruguay teammates went into the stands as fans brawled, and a video showed N\u00fa\u00f1ez hitting a fan in Colombian team colors.\n\nCONMEBOL released a statement after the game saying that it strongly condemns any act of violence that affects the game.\n\n\"Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values,\" the organization's statement read. \"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all of their passion into cheering on their national teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nBefore an overwhelmingly pro-Colombia crowd of 70,644 that filled Bank of America Stadium with yellow jerseys and flags, Uruguay fell behind for the first time in the tournament.\n\nJames Rodr\u00edguez's corner kick was headed in from short range by Lerma, who outjumped Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez for his third international goal and second of the tournament. Rodr\u00edguez has six assists in the tournament, triple the total of any other player.\n\nMu\u00f1oz received his first yellow card from Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos in the 31st minute for a reckless slide tackle on Maximiliano Ara\u00fajo and his second for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the stomach.\n\nRodr\u00edguez was given a yellow card in the 55th minute for arguing with Ramos when the referee failed to stop play after Richard R\u00edos was kicked on a shin by Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez.\n\nR\u00edos was removed on a stretcher, reentered the match, then went down in another challenge and was substituted in the 62nd minute. Rodr\u00edguez was removed at the same time to keep him eligible for the final.\n\nColombia goalkeeper Camilo Vargas didn't have to make his first save until he stopped Nicol\u00e1s de la Cruz in the 68th minute.\n\nLuis Su\u00e1rez, Uruguay's career leader with 68 goals, entered in the 66th minute and hit the outside of a post with a shot in the 71st. He grasped his head in his hands in disgust.\n\n\"The moments in which we could unbalance the game, we did not succeed,\" Uruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa said. \"We should have generated more goal situations than we did.\"\n\nColombia's Mateus Uribe, another second-half sub, put an open shot wide in the 88th, and Uribe's open shot in the fourth minute of stoppage time ricocheted off the body of sliding goalkeeper Sergio Rochet and then the crossbar.\n\nUruguay moved Rochet up to the attacking half of the field in the final minute, desperate for a goal.\n\nThe match was played in 90-degree heat on a surface that was converted from synthetic turf to grass in the weeks leading up the game.\n\nPanthers players have been outspoken about soccer teams having the luxury of playing on grass on their home field. Players from teams around the NFL have expressed concerns that games played on synthetic turf leave them more susceptible to injuries.\n\nWith two games left in this year's Copa America, attendance of 1.48 million is just 1,663 shy of the total for the 2016 tournament in the United States, which set the event's record.", "source": {"uri": "timesfreepress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8220015883", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "07:59:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T07:59:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T07:58:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/uruguayan-soccer-team-explains-clash-074600980.html", "title": "Uruguayan Soccer Team Explains Clash With Colombia Fans", "body": "Uruguay forward Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez engages with hostile fans in the stands after the CONMEBOL Copa America semifinal between Uruguay and Colombia at Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, NC, on July 10, 2024. Credit - Nick Tre. Smith -- Icon Sportswire/Getty Images\n\nThe Copa Am\u00e9rica soccer tournament held in the U.S. this summer has been characterized by intense physicality on the field. But while seven yellow cards and one red card were issued during the semifinal on Wednesday night, it ended up being action off the field that grabbed the most attention.\n\nA sea of yellow filled the Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, N.C. -- as supporters of Colombia far outnumbered those of their blue-wearing rivals Uruguay -- but tensions quickly turned red-hot after the full-time whistle sent Uruguay home and Colombia to the final.\n\nIn videos of the scene that quickly went viral on social media, opposing spectators threw punches and beverages at one another, while Uruguayan players -- including Liverpool forward Darwin Nu\u00f1ez and Barcelona defender Ronald Ara\u00fajo -- climbed into the stands to join in the brawl.\n\nNu\u00f1ez could be seen taking several swings at Colombia fans as his teammates attempted to hold him back before security officials appeared to separate the two sides.\n\nThe tussle in the stands took place after a brief scuffle between the opposing players on the pitch, following a testy match that saw favorites Uruguay lose to Colombia, 1-0, despite being a man up for the entire second half after Colombia's Daniel Mu\u00f1oz was sent off for elbowing an opponent. Colombia has now extended its record unbeaten streak to 28 games as it heads to Miami next to take on Lionel Messi and Argentina for the South American title on Sunday.\n\nAfter the melee had subsided, Uruguayan captain Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez told reporters that his teammates had acted in response to a group of Colombia fans attacking the Uruguayan players' families, who were seated in a section near the touchline. \"They stormed all our families,\" Gim\u00e9nez said, complaining about the lack of official security intervention. \"This is a disaster. Our family is in danger. We had to get on top of the stands ASAP to rescue our loved ones.\"\n\nIgnacio Alonso, president of the Uruguayan Football Association, reiterated the explanation, telling reporters after the game: \"Uruguay's players had an instinctive reaction that is natural, which is to defend and protect the children who were in that area of the stadium and were suffering attacks on the women, on the parents, on the closest family members, siblings. And it's a father's reaction that is intuitively natural and was very rational given the events that surrounded them.\"\n\nESPN commentator and former U.S. national team player Herculez Gomez echoed the frustrations of the Uruguayans, calling the lack of security at the stadium \"dangerously pathetic,\" as he shared on X footage of Nu\u00f1ez consoling his young son in the aftermath of the altercation.\n\nCONMEBOL, the South American soccer body that organizes the Copa Am\u00e9rica, condemned the violence in a statement, saying fans should channel their passion into cheering and that \"there is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field.\"", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": They were jumping over in an effort to try and separate the Colombia fans from them.\"\n\nNunez was among the first players to scale the stand, and fists were thrown at him and from him, with one clearly shown to make contact with his face.\n\nHis partner and young son were in the crowd and there was no stopping him, with the desperation of the situation voiced by Uruguay captain Jose Gimenez to TUDN: \"This is a disaster. Our family is in danger.\n\n\"We had to get into the stands to take out our loved ones with small babies, newborns. Everything was a disaster. There was not a single police officer.\"\n\nEl Observador, a Uruguayan newspaper, says Ronald Araujo, Matias Vina and Mathias Olivera were with Nunez as the first group scaled the stand, with the fight lasting at least 10 minutes.\n\nJose Maria Gimenez, Brian Rodriguez and Sebastian Caceres also \"participated to defend their families,\" most of whom ended up on the pitch, including Nunez's son and partner.\n\nIt took more than 10 minutes for police to arrive at the scene and PA stated that \"about 100 Uruguayan fans and members of the federation staff remained on the field for their own protection more than 20 minutes after the game.\"\n\nThe match becomes the second-most important thing after events like that, but it was Colombia who won to set up a meeting with Argentina in the {"uri": "8219710146", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "03:46:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T03:46:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T03:45:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/3013003-chaos-erupts-post-copa-america-uruguay-vs-colombia", "title": "Chaos Erupts Post Copa America: Uruguay vs Colombia | Sports-Games", "body": "After Uruguay's defeat to Colombia in the Copa America semi-final, chaos ensued as Uruguay players clashed with fans in the stands. With security intervening, the incident has sparked an investigation by CONMEBOL. Captain Jose Maria Gimenez voiced concerns about player safety, while Coach Marcelo Bielsa expressed his surprise in a press conference.\n\nUruguay players clashed with Colombia fans following their Copa America semi-final defeat, leading to security personnel stepping in to restore order.\n\nAfter Colombia's 1-0 victory in Charlotte, videos on social media showed Uruguay players climbing into the stands and exchanging blows with opposition fans. South America's football governing body, CONMEBOL, is investigating the incident.\n\nAmong those involved were Uruguay's Darwin Nunez and Ronald Araujo, with Captain Jose Maria Gimenez stating the players were defending their families.\n\n\"Our families are in the stands, and there are newborn babies. There was no police presence, so we had to defend our families,\" Gimenez said on the official broadcast, labeling the event a disaster. He blamed a few intoxicated individuals for the chaos.\n\nPlayers and staff from both teams converged on the field after the final whistle. Uruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa remarked that he initially thought the incident was a show of thanks to the fans.\n\nJefferson Lerma's header secured Colombia's place in Sunday's final, while Uruguay "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.tbsnews.net/sports/uruguay-coach-bielsa-takes-responsibility-copa-america-exit-897076", "title": "Uruguay coach Bielsa takes responsibility for Copa America exit", "body": "Jefferson Lerma scored the winner as 10-man Colombia claimed a 1-0 win over Uruguay at the Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, North Carolina to progress to Sunday's final.\n\nUruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa said his side had more talent in their ranks than Colombia and therefore he should be the one taking responsibility for Wednesday's Copa America semifinal defeat.\n\nJefferson Lerma scored the winner as 10-man Colombia claimed a 1-0 win over Uruguay at the Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, North Carolina to progress to Sunday's final.\n\nUruguay, 15-times champions, had been one of the pre-tournament favourites and beat hosts United States and five-times World Cup champions Brazil en route to the last four.\n\n\"Uruguay was in a clear condition to win this match if you assess the individual talent in each squad,\" Bielsa told reporters.\n\n\"I manage the team that, in my opinion, had the stronger individual talent vis-\u00e0-vis the opponent, and we weren't able to make the difference that I thought we were going to make if you compared both formations.\n\n\"I am personally liable for not achieving the result, despite having these players that were capable of being superior than the opponent.\n\n\"We were not able to seize our extra man advantage, and when a team wins with less individual talent, logically, the manager that is coaching the weaker team shows that he is superior than the coach that had the best players.\"\n\nUruguay had a number of chances to score in the first half but struggled to create opportunities after Colombia's Daniel Munoz was sent off just before halftime.\n\n\"The first half, even if we didn't dominate possession, it was very even, and we should have made the difference. With one man down in the second half for Colombia, the match was completely interrupted,\" Bielsa said.\n\n\"It was constantly start and stop. We should have created more chances and caused damage to the opponent. In the last minutes, they could have scored because they had clear chances.\n\n\"But we tried every possible way, every possible path.\"\n\nAfter the match, Uruguay players clashed with Colombia fans before a scuffed shot and another curling strike failed to find the target as he sat on his haunches wondering how he had missed.\n\nUruguay were made to pay for those missed chances when Lerma rose above the defence at a corner and squeezed his header past goalkeeper Sergio Rochet as James Rodriguez claimed his sixth assist of the tournament.\n\nColombia were then reduced to 10 men when right time.\n\nColombia, who extended their unbeaten run to 28 games, held on for a famous win and will play Argentina in Sunday's final.\n\nUruguay will play Canada a day earlier in the third-place Their last title was in 2001. The match, held Wednesday night in Miami Gardens, saw seven yellow cards and player-fan scrums.Jefferson Lerma scored in the 39th minute, and Colombia played a man short the entire second half in a 1-0 win over Uruguay on Wednesday night to reach the Copa America final against Lionel Messi and Argentina.\n\nDaniel Munoz was ejected in first-half stoppage time for his second yellow card, but Colombia held on to reach the championship for the first time since winning its only Copa title as host in 2001. Colombia extended its unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games, one more than from 1992-94 and the longest current streak in men's soccer.\n\nIn a contentious match that included seven yellow cards and one red, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle and some players went into the stands to scrap with fans.\n\nDefending champion Argentina and {"uri": "2024-07-418077670", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "02:33:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T02:33:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T01:58:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.aol.com/copa-am-rica-colombia-upends-015800981.html", "title": "Copa Am\u00e9rica: Colombia upends Uruguay a man down in tense semifinal, sets up final against Argentina", "body": "Copa Am\u00e9rica: Colombia upends Uruguay a man down in tense semifinal, sets up final against Argentina\n\nJason Owens\n\nJuly 11, 2024 at 3:58 AM\n\nPlaying shorthanded for more than a half, Colombia upended Uruguay, 1-0 in a tense Copa Am\u00e9rica semifinal Wednesday night.\n\nWith the win, Colombia advances to its first Copa Am\u00e9rica final and its second ever since winning the championship in 2001. There, it will face a stiff task against Lionel Messi and reigning World Cup champion Argentina, which cruised through its half of the field while allowing a single goal in five games.\n\nColombia and Argentina will face off Sunday night in Miami. Canada and\n\nWednesday's semifinal was played in Charlotte, but might as well have been hosted in Bogot\u00e1. The Bank of America stands were packed with fans sporting yellow Colombia jerseys eager to cheer their team on. Colombia delivered for those fans in a testy game that tallied six yellow cards saw a red-card ejection.\n\nColombia entered Wednesday's game as the highest-scoring team in the tournament (11 goals), fresh off a 5-0 quarterfinal win over Panama. It struck first on a corner kick in the 38th minute. James Rodr\u00edguez sent the ball to the back post on the corner kick, where Jefferson Lerma leapt high in the air and squeezed the ball between the post and goalkeeper Sergio Rochet.\n\nThe goal was just the second allowed by Uruguay all tournament.\n\nColombia's defense, meanwhile, stifled a Uruguay offense that scored nine goals in four games en route to Wednesday's matchup. Uruguay didn't put any of its four first-half shots on goal.\n\nThe tide threatened to shift late in the second half. Colombia's Daniel Mu\u00f1oz, who picked up a yellow card earlier in the half on a tackle, picked up his second just before the half. After a scuffle following a foul on Colombia's Davinson S\u00e1nchez, Uruguay's Manuel Ugarte grabbed Mu\u00f1oz's jersey from behind.\n\nMu\u00f1oz responded with an elbow to the chest that knocked Ugarte to the turf, drawing his second yellow and ultimately a red card that led to his ejection.\n\nHead coach N\u00e9stor Lorenzo protested to no avail. Mu\u00f1oz was tossed, and Colombia was set to play the second half a man down.\n\nUruguay's offense was much improved after halftime as it controlled the ball and put two of its seven shots on goal. But it didn't convert on the scoreboard as Colombia held on for victory.\n\nThe tension that marked the game throughout carried over at midfield after the final whistle. Players traded shoves and blows at midfield in the moments after the game.\n\nThe scuffle was eventually subdued on the field, but carried over into the stands, where Uruguayan players including one Minutes after the final whistle sounded on a 1-0 defeat to a Colombia side that played most of the match with 10 men, several Uruguay players entered into the stands at Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte as fans brawled.\n\nStar striker Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez and about a dozen Uruguay teammates went into the stands as fans brawled, with N\u00fa\u00f1ez and defender Ronald Araujo among those at the forefront seemingly attempting to fight Colombia fans while being held back by several others.\n\nAfter a physical and contentious match, a melee broke out behind the Uruguay bench after Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos' final whistle.\n\nThe crowd of 70,644 was about 90% in favor in Colombia, but a small patch of Uruguay fans fought with Colombia supporters as beverages were thrown.\n\nN\u00fa\u00f1ez and teammates then climbed a staircase into the crowd. A video showed N\u00fa\u00f1ez hitting a fan in Colombian team colors.\n\nIt took more than 10 minutes for police to restore order. The public address announcer asked for fans to leave the stadium, but several supporters remained.\n\nAbout 100 Uruguayan fans and and members of the federation staff remained on the field more than 20 minutes after the game, while Colombia fans made their way out to celebrate.\n\nSeveral other Uruguay players, including goalkeeper Sergio Rochet, were among the fracas.\n\nIt's unknown at this time what provoked N\u00fa\u00f1ez and his teammates to enter the stands. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all their passion into cheering on their teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nGimenez said the Uruguay players had acted to \"defend their families\" after blaming the violent exchanges on a small number of Colombian fans that he claimed had too much to drink.\n\n\"Let me say something before they cut you off because they won't let us speak into the microphone, they don't want me to say anything about what's going on but this is a disaster,\" Gimenez said in a television interview.\n\n\"Please be careful, our families are in the stands, there are little newborn babies. It was a disaster; there was no police and we had to defend our families.\n\n\"This is the fault of two or three people who had a few too many drinks and don't know how to drink.\"\n\nUruguayan Football Association president Ignacio Alonso also insisted that players had reacted to defend their loved ones in the crowd.\n\n\"Uruguay's players had an instinctive reaction, which is natural, which is going to defend and protect the children who were on that side of the stands, who were suffering attacks, the women, the parents, the closest family members, siblings,\" he said.\n\nColombia {"uri": "2024-07-418659487", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "12:50:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T12:50:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T22:40:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/sports/articles/2024-07-11/darwin-nunez-uruguay-teammates-enter-stands-as-fans-fight-after-copa-america-loss-to-colombia", "title": "Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez, Uruguay Teammates Enter Stands as Fans Fight After Copa America Loss to Colombia", "body": "CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) -- Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez and about a dozen Uruguay teammates went into the stands as fans brawled at Bank of America Stadium following a 1-0 loss to Colombia in a Copa America semifinal on Wednesday night.\n\nAfter a physical and contentious match, a melee broke out behind the Uruguay bench after Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos' final whistle.\n\nThe crowd of 70,644 was about 90% in favor in Colombia, but a small patch of Uruguay fans fought with Colombia supporters as beverages were thrown.\n\nN\u00fa\u00f1ez and teammates then climbed a staircase into the crowd. A video showed N\u00fa\u00f1ez hitting a fan in Colombian team colors.\n\nUruguay captain Jos\u00e9 Gim\u00e9nez said players went in the crowd to protect their families.\n\n\"This is a disaster. Our family is in danger. We had to get into the stands to take out our loved ones with small babies, newborns,\" he told TUDN. \"Everything was a disaster. There was not a single police officer.\"\n\nIt took more than 10 minutes for police to arrive on the scene and to restore order. The public address announcer asked for fans to leave the stadium, but several supporters remained.\n\nAbout 100 Uruguayan fans and and members of the federation staff remained on the field for their own protection more than 20 minutes after the game, while Colombia fans made their way out to celebrate.\n\nCONMEBOL released a statement after the game saying that it strongly condemns any act of violence that affects the game.\n\n\"Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values,\" the organization said. \"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all of their passion into cheering on their national teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nUruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa said he didn't see what was happening right away.\n\n\"There was some argument in the midfield, and when I saw that happening, I went to the locker room. I thought they were thanking the fans for their support,\" Beilsa said. \"But then I learned there were some problems over there unfortunately.\"\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. Messi and Argentina wait for Colombia in Miami. This Sunday will be the first major final the Cafeteros have played in since they won the Copa at home in 2001.\n\nWhat a half of football the first period of this game was. A goal, an injury and of course some red card drama were all on the menu in the first 45 minutes of this semifinal.\n\nColombia came out of the blocks firing, like they have done all tournament, but at times their pressing game left them way too open at the back, and Liverpool forward Darwin Nu\u00f1ez had some fantastic chances. He took advantage of the space behind the Colombia defence, but he failed to convert on various occasions.\n\nDaniel Mu\u00f1oz was menacing down the right flank for Colombia, and had a good header at goal bounce just wide. Richard Rios had a decent strike saved and striker Jhon C\u00f3rdoba scuffed at another effort. They went into the break 1-0 up thanks to a Jefferson Lerma header from a fine James Rodr\u00edguez corner, a deserved goal for a strong front-footed performance.\n\nColombia also went into the break one man down though, as Crystal Palace fullback Mu\u00f1oz saw all of his positive energy misplaced in a moment of rage. He struck Manuel Ugarte with an elbow off the ball and was rightfully dismissed upon a VAR review of the incident. After such a great half for Colombia, Mu\u00f1oz would leave his team disadvantaged and miss the final in case of victory.\n\nAt the start of the second half Colombia made a defensive change and set up in a 4-3-2 shape to try and seal the defence without completely losing all attacking options. D\u00edaz and Cordoba were the outlets for a team that went from a high press to a low block during the break.\n\nAfter an hour of the game James had to be substituted. He was beginning to see red after receiving a yellow card from the referee. Richard Rios was injured and had to come off himself, and captain James was booked in the aftermath. Those were tough minutes for Los Cafeteros, and after that Luis Suarez entered the fray for Uruguay who began to apply more and more pressure.\n\nWith 20 minutes left of normal time Luis Diaz found himself with an opening on the counter but couldn't pick the correct shot or pass to give Colombia a vital second. Seconds later Suarez struck the woodwork for Uruguay after a fine move down the right.\n\nThese two sides met in Colombia last year and drew 2-2, and names like James and Suarez would tempt you to reminisce about their World Cup knock-out battle back in 2014 when James Rodriguez took the World by storm. This Copa Am\u00e9rica semifinal became a classic of its own.\n\nWith the man advantage Uruguay dominated the ball in the second half and did apply pressure on Colombia, but they didn't really create much in the way of clear chances. Tangles between players from both sides, great Colombia defending and the odd dangerous counter attack made for an incredible spectacle nonetheless. Not to mention the tension in the air.\n\nSeven minutes of stoppage time saw Colombia hit the crossbar on yet another break. As if they were throwing away their own final confirmation, but at the other end Uruguay were being just as wasteful in what was a truly thrilling tie with an emotional atmosphere.\n\nThe final whistle went after what felt like an eternity and sparked scenes of jubilation amongst Colombia players and fans alike. It also means they are a record 28 games without defeat in international football and as mentioned they have a date with destiny this weekend, against World Cup winners Argentina and Lionel Messi.", {"uri": "8220278440", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "10:44:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T10:44:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T10:44:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://talksport.com/football/1958300/darwin-nunez-uruguay-teammate-family-copa-america-brawl/", "title": "Darwin Nunez defended for protecting family in Copa America brawl", "body": "Darwin Nunez has been defended for his part in an explosive altercation with Colombia fans following Uruguay's Copa America defeat.\n\nUruguay were beaten 1-0 by Colombia in the semi-final on Wednesday night with Crystal Palace midfielder Jefferson Lerma scoring the winner shortly before half time.\n\nHowever, chaos broke out in the stands after the final whistle in a section of the stadium close to where the players' families were located.\n\nDrinks were launched into the crowd and punches were thrown in the melee which saw players intervene to confront fans.\n\nUruguay players were heard shouting 'with family no' as tension rose in the stands.\n\nStars including Liverpool striker Nunez, Tottenham's Rodrigo Bentancur and Barcelona's Ronald Araujo were at the centre of the exchange.\n\nTelevision cameras showed Nunez hitting a Colombia fan who had slapped him first but his actions have since been defended by teammate Jose Maria Gimenez.\n\nThe centre-back, who was also involved in the brawl, explained that Uruguay players were simply defending their families in the face of provocation.\n\n\"Please, be careful, because our families are in the stands,\" said the Atletico Madrid star in a post-match interview.\n\n\"They rained things down on our families, a certain section of the Colombia fans. And they don't let you speak, so I'm going to say it now. This is a disaster. Our families were in danger.\n\n\"We had to go into the stands to get our loved ones out, there were small children, a newborn baby. It was all a disaster. There was not a single police officer, for half an hour not one arrived. It was all a disaster and we were there standing up for our loved ones.\"\n\n\"I hope that those who are organising this are a little more careful, with the families, with the people and with the surroundings of the stadiums, because this is a disaster, because the same thing happens every game.\n\n\"Our families are suffering because of those who take a few sips of alcohol, they don't know how to drink, and then behave like children who have no sense of respect. I hope they are careful and it doesn't happen again, because this is a disaster.\"\n\nIt remains to be seen what sanctions tournament organiser CONMEBOL will inflict on Uruguay but Nunez is at risk of a lengthy ban for his actions.\n\n\"CONMEBOL strongly condemns any act of violence that affects football. Our work is based on the conviction that football connects us and unites us, through its positive values,\" it said in a statement after the match.\n\n\"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. {"uri": "8220177721", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "09:42:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T09:42:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T09:42:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.dailysabah.com/sports/football/colombia-edge-uruguay-to-secure-copa-america-final-with-argentina", "title": "Colombia edge Uruguay to secure Copa America final with Argentina", "body": "Colombia have secured a berth in the Copa America championship game for the first time in 23 years, despite playing the second half with ten men and encountering post-game altercations with fans.\n\nJefferson Lerma's 39th-minute goal sealed a dramatic 1-0 victory on Wednesday night, setting up a thrilling showdown against Lionel Messi's Argentina, the defending champions, this Sunday.\n\n\"Until you overcome your weaknesses, you cannot grow,\" Colombia coach Nestor Lorenzo said through an interpreter. \"And when you overcome those obstacles, you can grow.\"\n\nDaniel Munoz was ejected in first-half stoppage time for an elbow that led to his second yellow card. Despite Uruguay holding 61.9% possession, Colombia held firm to reach the championship for the first time since winning its only Copa title as host in 2001.\n\nColombia extended its unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games, one more than from 1992-94 and the longest current streak in men's international soccer.\n\n\"They are very hungry as players and very eager, and they really add many elements to their game beyond the tactical side,\" Lorenzo added.\n\nIn a match that included seven yellow cards in addition to the red, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle. Darwin N\u00fanez and about a dozen Uruguay teammates entered the stands as fans brawled.\n\nA video showed N\u00fanez striking a fan in Colombian team colors.\n\nCONMEBOL released a statement after the game condemning any act of violence that affects the game.\n\n\"Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values,\" the organization said. \"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all of their passion into cheering on their national teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nDefending champions Argentina and Colombia will meet in the tournament finale at Miami Gardens, Florida.\n\nThe Albiceleste seek a record 16th Copa title and aim to join Spain (2008-12) as the only countries to win three straight major championships.\n\nUruguay remains in Charlotte to face Canada in Saturday night's third-place match.\n\nBefore an overwhelmingly pro-Colombia crowd of 70,644 clad in yellow jerseys and flags, Uruguay fell behind for the first time in the tournament.\n\nJames Rodriguez's corner kick was headed in from short range by Lerma, who outjumped Jose Maria Gimenez for his third international goal and second of the tournament. Rodriguez has six assists in the tournament -- triple the total of any other player.\n\nMunoz received his first yellow card from Mexican referee Cesar Ramos in the 31st minute for a reckless slide tackle on Maximiliano Ara\u00fajo and his second for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the stomach.\n\nRodriguez was cautioned in the 55th minute for disputing with Ramos after the referee did not halt play when Richard Rios was kicked on the shin by Darwin N\u00fanez.\n\nRios was taken off on a stretcher, re-entered the match, then went down in another challenge and was substituted in the 62nd minute. Rodriguez was also substituted at the same time to maintain his eligibility for the final.\n\nColombia goalkeeper Camilo Vargas did not need to make his first save until he denied Nicol\u00e1s de la Cruz in the 68th minute.\n\nLuis Su\u00e1rez, Uruguay's career leader with 68 goals, entered in the 66th minute and hit the outside of a post with a shot in the 71st. He clutched his head in frustration.\n\n\"The moments in which we could unbalance the game, we did not succeed,\" Uruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa said. \"We should have generated more goal situations than we did.\"\n\nColombia's Mateus Uribe, another second-half substitute, missed an open shot wide in the 88th minute, and Uribe's open shot in the fourth minute of stoppage time struck the body of sliding goalkeeper Sergio Rochet and then the crossbar.\n\nUruguay moved Rochet up to the attacking half of the field in the final minute, desperate for a goal.\n\nThe match was played in 90-degree heat on a surface converted from artificial turf to grass in the weeks before the game.\n\nPlayers from the NFL's Carolina Panthers have been vocal about soccer teams enjoying the privilege of playing on grass at their home ground. Players argue that NFL games on artificial turf leave them more prone to injuries.\n\nWith two games left, attendance of 1.48 million is just 1,663 shy of the total for the 2016 tournament in the {"uri": "8220016943", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "08:00:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T08:00:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T07:59:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://theeagleonline.com.ng/copa-america-colombia-beat-uruguay-for-final-match-spot/", "title": "Copa America: Colombia beat Uruguay for final match spot |", "body": "Colombia beat Uruguay 1-0 in their Copa America semi-final match on Wednesday in spite of playing the second half with only 10 men.\n\nJefferson Lerma's first-half header at the Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, North Carolina set up the title decider.\n\nThis will be against defending champions Argentina on Sunday.\n\nColombia's Daniel Munoz was sent off at the end of the first half and, while Uruguay dominated possession, they could not make the man-advantage count.\n\nThis was as Darwin Nunez missed three good opportunities to score early on.\n\nThe Liverpool forward had a great chance in the penalty box in the 17th minute, but he curled his effort inches wide before a scuffed shot.\n\nAnother curling strike failed to find the target as he sat on his haunches wondering how he had missed.\n\nUruguay were made to pay for those missed chances when Lerma rose above the defence at a corner-kick and squeezed his header past goalkeeper Sergio Rochet.\n\nIt helped James Rodriguez to claim his sixth assist of the tournament.\n\nColombia were then reduced to 10 men when right-back Munoz received a second yellow card for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the chest when play was {"uri": "8219883831", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "06:22:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T06:22:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T06:22:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.dailystar.co.uk/sport/football/darwin-nunez-fights-fans-defending-33216634", "title": "Nunez fights fans defending his family as Liverpool ace in Copa America brawl", "body": "Liverpool ace Darwin Nunez was caught up in a shocking brawl with fans after Uruguay's Copa America defeat to Colombia as he fought to defend his family.\n\nThe chaos unfolded at the Bank of America Stadium, in Charlotte, North Carolina, as Nunez and his team-mates climbed into the stands where punches were thrown. The tension between the two nations hit fever pitch following Colombia's narrow 1-0 victory, courtesy of Jefferson Lerma's 39th-minute header.\n\nOnce the on-field commotion had subsided, the Uruguay players headed towards the stands. Nunez led a group of Uruguay players into the crowd, where they were met with hostility from Colombian fans, sparking an all-out brawl between the players and supporters. Nunez was struck by a fan and was seen defending himself, retaliating against several supporters.\n\nREAD MORE: Harry Kane shows true colours with Ollie Watkins comment after England beat Netherlands\n\nREAD MORE: Model with 'perfect bum' gets England star Jude Bellingham tattooed on 'intimate place'\n\nBarcelona's Ronald Araujo also found himself in the thick of the fight, with thousands of fans capturing the shocking scenes on their phones. Security staff intervened to separate the two groups, swiftly escorting the Uruguay players towards the dressing room.\n\nAs reported by Uruguayan news outlet El Pais, the Uruguay players had ventured into the crowd to support family and friends seated behind the team bench. With the stadium largely filled with Colombian fans, the relatives of the Uruguay players were subjected to abuse, reports the Express.\n\nNunez was seen spearheading the charge of players into the chaotic stands as their family members were swiftly ushered onto the pitch for safety. Despite this, things quickly got out of hand and spiralled into violence.\n\nDuring the mayhem, Uruguay's national team director Jorge Giordano and press officer Felipe Cotelo found themselves in the thick of it. Confusion reigned supreme, with reports coming in that Uruguayan midfielder Manuel Ugarte sprinted to the pitch to assist his injured relatives.\n\nOutnumbered by Columbian supporters, a group of Uruguayan fans bore the brunt of the chaos, sustaining severe injuries in the fracas. Uruguay defender Jose Maria Gimenez minced no words while slamming the events, dubbing it a \"disaster\" following the apparent absence of police control.\n\nGimenez lambasted the lackadaisical security arrangement, stating: \"It was a disaster; there was no police and we had to defend our families,\" The player suggested a handful of overzealous fans were to blame, adding, \"This is because of two or three who have one drink too many. A certain sector of the Colombian fans made an avalanche where our loved ones were.\"\n\nCONMEBOL, which leads South American football, responded in the aftermath of the violent incidents by announcing its intent to conduct a thorough evaluation prior to Sunday's Copa America final. Colombia, currently relishing an impressive 28-match unbeaten run spanning over two years, will face Argentina in Miami despite being considered the underdogs.\n\nArgentina, under the leadership of football wizard Lionel Messi, is eager to clinch a third consecutive title following their victories in the Copa America 2021 and last year's World Cup. Despite not winning an international trophy until 2020, Messi, who now plays for MLS's Inter Miami after his transfer last year, is keen to bolster his impressive legacy this coming Sunday in his new {"uri": "8219810422", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "05:22:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T05:22:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T05:22:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://worldsoccertalk.com/copa-america/colombia-survive-uruguay-attacks-to-advance-to-finals/", "title": "Colombia survive Uruguay attack to advance to finals", "body": "The streak continues. Despite several injuries, contentious refereeing decisions, and a second half filled with valiant defending, Colombia extended its unbeaten streak to 27 games straight with their win over Uruguay. They looked terrifying in transition, divebombing their pitiable opponents with their fluid, dribble-heavy front four. James Rodriguez, now 32 and playing with Sao Paulo, looked like he was 23 again lighting up Real Madrid.\n\nColombia showed why they were the most dominant team in South America, even over Brazil and Argentina, with their first-half performance against Uruguay. The attack looked beautiful to watch, often connecting, drawing themselves out of position, and beating their markers one-on-one.\n\nJames, who has found his rhythm this Copa America, created three chances throughout the match. Luis Diaz looked electric down the left, holding the ball up at times, but drifting into the middle other times to set up teams. Colombia is a team full of experience, both with their clubs and each other. They seem poised yet patient, thrillingly intense in attack but solid on defense.\n\nThe first big moment was a rough tackle on Colombia striker Jhon Cordoba, which injured Cordoba's tackler. While putting in a tackle on Cordoba, key anchoring midfielder Rodrigo Bentacur collided with Mathias Olivera. It took Bentacur several minutes to get up, and when he did, he was accompanied by a pained grimace and a clutched thigh. Bentacur eventually had to leave the game early.\n\nThe first big moment in their high-tempo match came through the speedy Darwin Nunez. After a give-and-go with Mathias Olivera, Nunez danced past center-back Carlos Cuesta. The Liverpool striker got the ball to the top of the box, and with keeper Camilo Vargas off his line, he had a fair shot on goal. But, his curling effort spun just over the crossbar.\n\nJames created something out of nothing with his set-piece magic. Rodriguez floated a cross towards the back post, meeting a powerful header from Jefferson Lerma. Lerma's effort narrowly squeaked past keeper Sergio Rochet, and just like that, Colombia had their opener.\n\nAnd then, tremors. The sound and feel of Colombia fans jumping in their seats could have passed for an earthquake. Bank of America Stadium looked vibrant with the yellow jerseys that scattered the stadium.\n\nIt seemed only moments later that the excitement would turn to dread. After Daniel Munoz had a brief argument with a Uruguay defender, Manuel Ugarte put his hand on Munoz's shoulder and another in Munoz's rib cage. Munoz turned around and gave Ugarte a reactionary elbow.\n\nAlthough the conflict was brief, it was enough for the referee to give Munoz a yellow card, his second of the day. Despite protests from Colombia staff and players, Munoz took the walk of shame as halftime neared. Colombia would have to defend their one-goal lead with ten men.\n\nAround 10 minutes after halftime, Colombia's skillful midfielder Richard Rios took a tough tackle from Maximiliano Araujo. Rios, who looked injured and begged for treatment, was initially disregarded by the ref until the protests of James delayed the game. James got booked, but Rios got treatment and eventually left out of the game. The scenario showed questionable refereeing and set the tone for a physical first half.\n\nIt took several valiant efforts to keep Uruguay from equalizing. Vargas came up with an incredible stop against Nunez in the 65th minute, selflessly shielding the near post by sacrificing his body. Luis Suarez hit the post after receiving a well-hit Federico Valverde pass. The Inter Miami striker seemed dumbfounded and frustrated that his shot pinged off the woodwork -- Suarez hasn't scored for Uruguay since March 2022.\n\nDespite going down a man, Colombia was still lethal in transition. In the 89th minute, with fatigue setting in, super-sub Luis Sinisterra scampered onto a clumsily-hit Rochet pass in the box. Sinisterra shoved it towards teammate Kevin Castano. Castano passed to Matheus Uribe at the edge of the box, but his shot rolled narrowly wide of the post.\n\nUribe had a chance to redeem himself in stoppage time after Castano played Sinisterra through on goal. Sinisterra squared the ball to Uribe with only the keeper to beat from 12 yards out, but Uribe sent his shot flying into Rochet. The shot bounced off the inside of the crossbar and outside of the net, to the dismay of Uribe. Luckily, it didn't matter. Despite the embarrassing miss, the referee blew his full-time whistle to the excited whoops of Colombian fans.\n\nThe customary pitch invasion from the players and the half-field celebrations were marred by antics from the Uruguayan players. Uruguay and Colombia got into a brawl after the game, with Suarez one of the players having to be separated. Darwin Nunez led a fight in the stands, with Uruguayan players fighting Colombia fans in a scene resembling Malice at the Palace. However, reports emerged that Colombia fans 'avalanched' the section of the players' families. Nunez was seen consoling his distraught two-year-old son after the scene.\n\nColombia will travel to Miami to face Argentina on Sunday. If Colombia wins, it will be their first Copa America title since beating Mexico on home turf in 2001. It would be a deserved victory for a Colombia side that has looked dominant throughout the tournament. Uruguay will stay in Charlotte to take on Canada in the third-place game.", "source": {"uri": "worldsoccertalk.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "World Soccer Talk"}, "authors": [], "concepts": There were no police and we had to defend our families.\n\n\"This is because of two or three who have one drink too many.\n\n\"A certain sector of the Colombian fans made an avalanche where our loved ones were.\"\n\nThe Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte was packed with Colombia supporters, who watched a hot-headed contest that featured six yellow cards and one red.\n\nBEST FREE BET SIGN UP from the rival fans.\n\nAccording to journalist Favian Renkel, Uruguay players' families were escorted out of the stadium in a separate exit to ensure their safety.\n\nAtletico Madrid defender Giminez {"uri": "8219733410", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "04:10:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T04:10:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T04:10:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/07/11/sports/copa-america-colombia-uruguay-brawl/", "title": "Colombia wins contentious Copa Am\u00e9rica semifinal to set up Lionel Messi showdown; Uruguay players brawl in crowd - The Boston Globe", "body": "\"Until you overcome your weaknesses you cannot grow,\" Colombia coach Nester Lorenzo said through a interpreter. \"And when you overcome those obstacles you can grow.\"\n\nDaniel Mu\u00f1oz was ejected in first-half stoppage time for an elbow that led to his second yellow card. Despite Uruguay having 61.9 percent possession, Colombia held on to reach the championship for the first time since winning its only Copa title as host in 2001.\n\nColombia extended its unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games, one more than from 1992-94 and the longest current streak in men's international soccer.\n\n\"They are very hungry as players and very eager and they really add many elements to their game beyond the tactical side,\" Lorenzo said.\n\nIn a match that included seven yellow cards in addition to the red, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle. Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez and about a dozen Uruguay teammates went into the stands as fans brawled.\n\nA video showed N\u00fa\u00f1ez hitting a fan in Colombian team colors. Uruguay captain Jos\u00e9 Gim\u00e9nez said players went in the crowd to protect their families.\n\n\"This is a disaster. Our family is in danger. We had to get into the stands to take out our loved ones with small babies, newborns,\" he told TUDN. \"Everything was a disaster. There was not a single police officer.\"\n\nIt took more than 10 minutes for police to arrive on the scene and to restore order. The public address announcer asked for fans to leave the stadium, but several supporters remained.\n\nDefending champion Argentina and Colombia meet at Miami Gardens, Fla., in the tournament finale. The Albiceleste are seeking a record 16th Copa title and are looking to join Spain from 2008-12 as the only countries to win three straight major championships.\n\nUruguay stays in Charlotte to meet Canada in Saturday night's third-place match.\n\nBefore an overwhelmingly pro-Colombia crowd of 70,644 that filled Bank of America Stadium with yellow jerseys and flags, Uruguay fell behind for the first time in the tournament.\n\nJames Rodr\u00edguez's corner kick was headed in from short range by Lerma, who outjumped Gim\u00e9nez for his third international goal and second of the tournament. Rodr\u00edguez has six assists in the tournament -- triple the total of any other player.\n\nMu\u00f1oz received his first yellow card from Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos in the 31st minute for a reckless slide tackle on Maximiliano Ara\u00fajo and his second for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the stomach.\n\nRodr\u00edguez was given a yellow card in the 55th minute for arguing with Ramos when the referee failed to stop play after Richard R\u00edos was kicked on a shin by Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez.\n\nR\u00edos was removed on a stretcher, re-entered the match, then went down in another challenge and was substituted in the 62nd minute. Rodr\u00edguez was removed at the same time to keep him eligible for the final.\n\nColombia goalkeeper Camilo Vargas didn't have to make his first save until he stopped Nicol\u00e1s de la Cruz in the 68th minute.\n\nLuis Su\u00e1rez, Uruguay's career leader with 68 goals, entered in the 66th minute and hit the outside of a post with a shot in the 71st. He grasped his head in his hands in disgust.\n\n\"The moments in which we could unbalance the game, we did not succeed,\" Uruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa said. \"We should have generated more goal situations than we did.\"\n\nColombia's Mateus Uribe, another second-half sub, put an open shot wide in the 88th, and Uribe's open shot in the fourth minute of stoppage time ricocheted off the body of sliding goalkeeper Sergio Rochet and then the crossbar.\n\nUruguay moved Rochet up to the attacking half of the field in the final minute, desperate for a goal.\n\nThe match was played in 90-degree heat on a surface that was converted from artificial turf to grass in the weeks leading up the game.\n\nPlayers on the NFL's Carolina Panthers have been outspoken about soccer teams having the luxury of playing on grass on their home field. Players say NFL games on artificial turf leave them more susceptible to injuries.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston Globe"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8219652304", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "02:39:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T02:39:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T02:37:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://deadspin.com/10-man-colombia-edges-uruguay-advances-to-copa-final/", "title": "Deadspin | 10-man Colombia edges Uruguay, advances to Copa final", "body": "Jefferson Lerma headed in James Rodriguez's corner kick late in the first half and 10-man Colombia held on to reach its first Copa America final in 23 years with a 1-0 victory over Uruguay on Wednesday in Charlotte.\n\nColombia was considerably the better team for the opening 45 minutes, only to be forced to hold on after Daniel Munoz received his second booking for an elbow thrown into Manuel Ugarte's torso in first-half stoppage time.\n\nLos Cafeteros set a national record by completing a 28th consecutive match without defeat, pushed on through the second half by a significantly pro-Colombian crowd of more than 70,000. Colombia advances to face defending champion Argentina in Miami Gardens, Fla., in the final on Sunday night.\n\nRodriguez now has six assists, the most in a single Copa America since the stat was first kept in 2011. The 2014 World Cup Golden Boot winner will try to deliver his nation its second-ever Copa America title after it hosted and won the 2001 event.\n\nUruguay will remain in Charlotte to face Canada in Saturday's third-place match, in what will be La Celeste's best finish at the tournament since winning the 2011 title.\n\nAfter winning all three of its group-stage games, Uruguay did not score in either of its knockout-phase matches, ending influential manager Marcelo Bielsa's latest bid at a first major title in international play.\n\nLerma put Colombia in front in the 39th minute after Rodriguez delivered the latest in a tournament full of perfectly struck set pieces.\n\nThis one came from a corner dropped onto Lerma's head at the back post. Lerma outjumped Jose Maria Gimenez to send his header downward, narrowly inside the left post before Uruguay goalkeeper Sergio Rochet could react.\n\nA great start for Los Cafeteros became far more complicated seven minutes later when Munoz rightly received his second caution from referee Cesar Ramos.\n\nUruguay all-time leading scorer Luis Suarez entered in the 67th minute and immediately made his presence felt in the 71st, striking the outside of the right post with a shot from just inside the penalty area.\n\nHowever, the insertion of center back Yerry Mina and switch to a five-man back line by Colombia manager Nestor Lorenzo helped limit Uruguay from there.\n\nColombia's Mateus Uribe missed the game's two best late chances, dragging an 88th-minute opportunity low and wide of the left post and seeing another effort in stoppage time deflect off a charging Rochet and then the crossbar.", "source": {"uri": "deadspin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Deadspin"}, "authors": [], over Uruguay to reach Copa America final", "body": "CHARLOTTE: Ten-man Colombia defeated Uruguay 1-0 to reach the final of the Copa America for the first time in 23 years after an ill-tempered semi-final on Wednesday.\n\nA 39th-minute Jefferson Lerma header sealed victory for the Colombians, who will now face holders Argentina in Sunday's final in Miami.\n\nIt was an anarchic semi-final played in front of a packed and passionate crowd which ended with scuffles on the field and fighting in the stands, including several players who had climbed in among supporters amid the flying punches.\n\nColombia, despite having Daniel Munoz sent off just before the interval and facing plenty of Uruguay pressure, hung on for a famous victory to the delight of their massive following of fans.\n\nThe win was the 28th game without defeat for Colombia, setting a new record for the team.\n\nThe downtown streets of the North Carolina city were packed with partying fans in bright yellow Colombia jerseys hours before the kick-off.\n\nNot surprisingly in such an atmosphere, Colombia started strongly with their livewire Liverpool winger Luis Diaz doing well to wriggle some space for a cross on the left, finding Daniel Munoz at the back post but the full-back's header was off target.\n\nUruguay were, as always, a threat on the counter-attack and their Liverpool star, Darwin Nunez, was close to finishing off one break when Rodr go Bentancur found him with a clever pass but the forward poked his shot wide.\n\nNunez had another opening when Maximiliano Araujo played him clear in the inside-right channel but the striker rushed his shot, blasting high and wide.\n\nAt the other end, Colombia forced a turnover which led to James Rodriguez curling in a cross from the right but "body": "Yaser Asprilla and his Colombia teammates have reached the final of the Copa America after beating Uruguay 1-0 in a bad-tempered semi-final on Wednesday night.\n\nMidfielder Jefferson Lerma headed the only goal of the game in the 39th minute but his Crystal Palace teammate Daniel Munoz was sent off before half-time for a second bookable offence.\n\nThere were ugly scenes after the final whistle as players and fans clashed in the stands.\n\nColombia now go through to face Argentina in the final, which kicks off at 1am UK time on Monday morning.\n\nIronically, Argentina are the last side to beat Colombia and that was way back in February 2022.\n\nSince then the Colombians have gone on a 29-game unbeaten run which saw them beat the likes of Germany, Brazil and Spain in friendlies.\n\nThey also drew with Brazil in the group stage of Copa America, and have beaten Paraguay, Costa Rica, Panama and now Uruguay on their way to the final.\n\nAsprilla's own involvement has been limited: he came on for the final 18 minutes of the 3-0 group win over Costa Rica but has been an unused sub in each of the other games so far.\n\nHowever, the 19-year-old now has six full caps Colombia fans as others tried to restrain him.\n\nUruguay's Luis Suarez said: \"Obviously if someone is attacking your family you want to go and defend them but that doesn't justify the image that it Players, referees, camera crews, and business executives became entangled in a scrum.\n\nAmid it all, the Uruguayan legend was seen towering over rival players and shoving members believed to be part {"uri": "2024-07-418085835", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "02:49:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T02:49:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T02:13:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.seattletimes.com/sports/colombia-beats-uruguay-1-0-and-will-face-lionel-messi-and-argentina-in-copa-america-final/", "title": "Colombia beats Uruguay 1-0 and will face Lionel Messi and Argentina in Copa America final", "body": "CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) -- Jefferson Lerma scored in the 39th minute, and Colombia played a man short the entire second half in a 1-0 win over Uruguay on Wednesday night to reach the Copa America final against Lionel Messi and Argentina.\n\nDaniel Mu\u00f1oz was ejected in first-half stoppage time for his second yellow card, but Colombia held on to reach the championship for the first time since winning its only Copa title as host in 2001. Colombia extended its unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games, one more than from 1992-94 and the longest current streak in men's international soccer.\n\nIn a contentious match that included seven yellow cards and one red, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle. Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez and about a dozen Uruguay teammates went into the stands as fans brawled. A video showed N\u00fa\u00f1ez hitting a fan in Colombian team colors.\n\nDefending champion Argentina and Colombia meet Sunday night at Miami Gardens, Florida. The Albiceleste are seeking a record 16th Copa title and are looking to join Spain from 2008-12 as the only countries to win three straight major championships.\n\nUruguay stays in Charlotte to meet Canada in Saturday night's third-place match.\n\nBefore an overwhelmingly pro-Colombia crowd of 70,644 that filled Bank of America Stadium with yellow jerseys and flags, Uruguay fell behind for the first time in the tournament.\n\nJames Rodr\u00edguez's corner kick was headed in from short range by Lerma, who outjumped Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez for his third international goal and second of the tournament. Rodr\u00edguez has six assists in the tournament -- triple the total of any other player.\n\nMu\u00f1oz received his first yellow card from Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos in the 31st minute for a reckless slide tackle on Maximiliano Ara\u00fajo and his second for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the stomach.\n\nRodr\u00edguez was given a yellow card in the 55th minute for arguing with Ramos when the referee failed to stop play after Richard R\u00edos was kicked on a shin by Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez.\n\nR\u00edos was removed on a stretcher, re-entered the match, then went down in another challenge and was substituted in the 62nd minute. Rodr\u00edguez was removed at the same time to keep him eligible for the final.\n\nColombia goalkeeper Camilo Vargas didn't have to make his first save until he stopped Nicol\u00e1s de la Cruz in the 68th minute.\n\nLuis Su\u00e1rez, Uruguay's career leader with 68 goals, entered in the 66th minute and hit the outside of a post with a shot in the 71st. He grasped his head in his hands in disgust.\n\nColombia's Mateus Uribe, another second-half sub, put an open shot wide in the 88th, and Uribe's open shot in the fourth minute of stoppage time ricocheted off the body of sliding goalkeeper Sergio Rochet and then the crossbar.\n\nUruguay moved Rochet up the field in the final minute, desparate for a goal.\n\nThe match was played in 90-degree heat on a surface that was converted from artificial turf to grass in the weeks leading up the game.\n\nPlayers on the NFL's Carolina Panthers have been outspoken about soccer teams having the luxury of playing on grass on their home field. NFL games at venue are played on artificial turf, which players say leaves them more susceptible to injuries.\n\n___\n\nAP Copa America coverage: https://apnews.com/hub/copa-america", "source": Bielsa takes responsibility for Copa America exit", "body": "Uruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa said his side had more talent in its ranks than Colombia and therefore he should be the one taking Carolina to progress to Sunday's final.\n\nUruguay, 15-time champion, had been one of the pre-tournament favourites and beat hosts United States and five-times World Cup champion Brazil en route to the last four.\n\n\"Uruguay was in a clear condition to win this match if you assess the individual talent in each squad,\" Bielsa told reporters.\n\n\"I manage the team that, in my opinion, had the stronger individual talent vis-\u00e0-vis the opponent, and we weren't able to make the difference that I thought we were going to make if you compared both formations.\n\n\"I am personally liable for not achieving the result, despite having these players that were capable of being superior than the opponent.\n\n\"We were not able to seize our extra man advantage, and when a team wins with less individual talent, logically, the manager that is coaching the weaker team shows that he is superior than the coach that had the best players.\"\n\nUruguay had a number of chances to score in the first half but struggled to create opportunities after Colombia's Daniel Munoz was sent off just before halftime.\n\n\"The first half, even if we didn't dominate possession, it was very even, and we should have made the difference. With one man down in the second half for Colombia, the match was completely interrupted,\" Bielsa said.\n\n\"It was constantly start and stop. We should have created more chances and caused damage to the opponent. Uruguay's charge was led by forward Darwin Nunez as the Liverpool star was seen throwing punches at the crowd.\n\nAccording to a USA Today report, Uruguay defender Jose Maria Gimenez alleged that family members of the Uruguayan squad were troubled by the Colombian supporters, and as a matter of consequence, the players were left with no option but to intervene for their safety.\n\n\"This is a disaster, our family was in danger. Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values,\" the statement read.\n\n\"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. {"uri": "8219671849", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "03:02:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T03:02:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T03:02:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.jamaicaobserver.com/2024/07/10/colombia-defeat-uruguay-1-0-reach-copa-america-final/", "title": "Colombia defeat Uruguay 1-0 to reach Copa America final - Jamaica Observer", "body": "CHARLOTTE, United States (AFP) -- Ten-man Colombia defeated Uruguay 1-0 to reach the final of the Copa America for the first time in 23 years after an ill-tempered semi-final on Wednesday.\n\nA 39th-minute Jefferson Lerma header sealed victory for the Colombians, who will now face holders Argentina in Sunday's final in Miami.\n\nIt was an anarchic semi-final played in front of a packed and passionate crowd which ended with scuffles on the field and fighting in the stands, including several players who had climbed in among supporters amid the flying punches.\n\nColombia, despite having Daniel Munoz sent off just before the interval and facing plenty of Uruguay pressure, hung on for a famous victory to the delight of their massive following of fans.\n\nThe downtown streets of the North Carolina city were packed with partying fans in bright yellow Colombia jerseys hours before the kick-off.\n\nInside the 74,800 capacity Bank of America Stadium, it was like a home game in Bogota with only pockets of Uruguayan supporters breaking up the wall of yellow on all four sides of the venue.\n\nNot surprisingly in such an atmosphere, Colombia started strongly with their livewire Liverpool winger Luis Diaz doing well to wriggle some space for a cross on the left, finding Daniel Munoz at the back post but the full-back's header was off target.\n\nUruguay were, as always, a threat on the counter-attack and their Liverpool star, Darwin Nunez, was close to finishing off one break when Rodrigo Bentancur found him with a clever pass but the forward poked his shot wide.\n\nNunez had another opening when Maximiliano Araujo played him clear in the inside-right channel but the striker rushed his shot, blasting high and wide.\n\nAt the Liverpool are set to reach out to the 25-year-old when the time difference allows them to check in on his and his family's welfare after a distressing evening in Charlotte.\n\nThe club will also speak directly to the Uruguay Football Federation to get their version of events and it's understood no official statement will be imminent with Anfield officials keen to establish all the facts around the incident before determining the best course of action.\n\nWhile what happens next is unclear at this current time, should Nunez not be handed a swift suspension, his tournament is not actually over.\n\nUnlike the European Championship, the Copa America has a third-place play-off, with Uruguay next in action against Canada in the early hours of Sunday morning (UK time). As things stand, Nunez is free to play in the game.\n\nLiverpool traditionally give their international players a three-week break following close-season excursions with their countries. Therefore, Nunez is not expected back to start pre-season until the start of August. Consequently, he is set to miss the Reds' tour of the United States.\n\nWhether such an absence is extended should he be handed a suspension, and it is extended to club football, remains to be seen. But given the unsavoury end to Uruguay's Copa America hopes and the current cloud hanging over Nunez's head, it is somewhat surreal that he has one game still to participate in.\n\nNunez has started As Colombia celebrated their narrow 1-0 win, pandemonium broke out.\n\nThe pitch became a whirlwind of players, officials, and staff in a chaotic tangle that was hard to unravel. Predictably, however, ex-Liverpool star Suarez, wearing his famous No. 9 shirt, stood out in the middle as he loomed over opponents and appeared to shove a member of the Colombian coaching team.\n\nREAD MORE: Darwin Nunez and Luis Diaz shared exchange moments before ugly Copa America brawl\n\nREAD MORE: Darwin Nunez shares emotional moment with son as Copa America brawl explained\n\nHis actions set off a chain reaction, with a Uruguayan substitute player jumping into the fray in response. The commentators didn't miss a beat, highlighting Suarez's involvement.\n\n\"I'll give you one guess who sparked this originally,\" they remarked as the camera focused on the controversial figure. \"And now it's boiling over,\" they added, capturing the escalating situation as more individuals joined the commotion.\n\nBut the conflict wasn't confined to the field; it exploded into the stands, where Darwin Nunez was among several Uruguayans who confronted Colombian supporters. Nunez was caught in the middle of the fracas, trading blows with fans as he defended himself.\n\nUruguay's Jose Maria Gimenez offered an explanation after the game, claiming they had to protect their families from aggressive Colombia fans. Nunez was later seen consoling his son on the pitch in emotional pictures.\n\nGimenez said: \"It was a disaster; there was no police and we had to defend our families.\"\n\nColombia narrowly edged out Uruguay with a 1-0 win, thanks to Jefferson Lerma's first-half header off a superb cross by James Rodriguez. The victory was made more difficult when Daniel Munoz got sent off for a second bookable offence after elbowing Manuel Ugarte, leaving Colombia with ten men.\n\nDespite being a man down, Uruguay couldn't muster a significant threat, managing only two shots on target the entire match. They pushed for a late equaliser, winning free kicks in critical moments, yet failed to capitalise, with the game slipping away.\n\nAs of now, CONMEBOL has stayed silent on the chaotic semifinal footage and has not disclosed any disciplinary measures. However, the organisation has previously acted swiftly against violence, as seen last year when it condemned an altercation in Rio de Janeiro before the Copa Libertadores final, resulting in three Their last defeat dates back to February 2022, served to them by the opposition that awaits them in the final of the ongoing tournament on Sunday.\n\nUruguay had their chances to go in front throughout the 90 minutes but struggled to guide the ball into the back of the net.\n\nLiverpool's ace Darwin Nunez attempted to side-foot the ball inside the back of the net, but his shot was a whisker away from his target in the 19th minute.\n\nIt was Rodriguez who carried the attacking threat and paved the way for Colombia to lift their first Copa America title since 2001.\n\nIn front of an avid atmosphere created by the ecstatic fans, he served the ball to Jefferson Lerma, who headed the ball into the net in the 39th minute of the game.\n\nDespite going in front, Colombia's task to defend their slender one-goal advantage became an intricate affair. Defender Daniel Munoz swung his elbow at Uruguay's Manuel Ugarte, was shown a second yellow card and got sent off the field in the first-half stoppage time.\n\nWith time running out, Uruguay decided to introduce one of their most prolific strikers, Luis Suarez, into the thick of the action.\n\nIn the 71st minute, he had the opportunity to bring the game back on level terms but failed to deliver in the decisive moment.\n\nColombia struck the crossbar in the final minutes of the game, but one goal turned out to be sufficient to seal their date with Argentina in the final. With one man down in the second half for Colombia, the match was completely interrupted,\" Bielsa said.\n\n\"It was constantly start and stop. We should have created more chances and caused damage to the opponent. There, it will face a stiff task against Lionel Messi and reigning World Cup champion Argentina, which cruised through its half of the field while allowing a single goal in five games.\n\nColombia and Argentina will face off Sunday night in Miami. Canada and\n\nWednesday's semifinal was played in Charlotte, but might as well have been hosted in Bogot\u00e1. The Bank of America stands were packed with fans sporting yellow Colombia jerseys eager to cheer their team on. Colombia delivered for those fans in a testy game that tallied six yellow cards saw a red-card ejection.\n\nColombia entered Wednesday's game as the highest-scoring team in the tournament (11 goals), fresh off a 5-0 quarterfinal win over Panama. It struck first on a corner kick in the 38th minute. James Rodr\u00edguez sent the ball to the back post on the corner kick, where Jefferson Lerma leapt high in the air and squeezed the ball between the post and goalkeeper Sergio Rochet.\n\nThe goal was just the second allowed by Uruguay all tournament.\n\nColombia's defense, meanwhile, stifled a Uruguay offense that scored nine goals in four games en route to Wednesday's matchup. Uruguay didn't put any of its four first-half shots on goal.\n\nThe tide threatened to shift late in the second half. Colombia's Daniel Mu\u00f1oz, who picked up a yellow card earlier in the half on a tackle, picked up his second just before the half. After a scuffle following a foul on Colombia's Davinson S\u00e1nchez, Uruguay's Manuel Ugarte grabbed Mu\u00f1oz's jersey from behind.\n\nMu\u00f1oz responded with an elbow to the chest that knocked Ugarte to the turf, drawing his second yellow and ultimately a red card that led to his ejection.\n\nHead coach N\u00e9stor Lorenzo protested to no avail. Mu\u00f1oz was tossed, and Colombia was set to play the second half a man down.\n\nUruguay's offense was much improved after halftime as it controlled the ball and put two of its seven shots on goal. But it didn't convert on the scoreboard as Colombia held on for victory.\n\nThe tension that marked the game throughout carried over at midfield after the final whistle.
