{"uri": "8220011425", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "07:55:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T07:55:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T07:55:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://time.com/6997307/uruguay-colombia-fans-families-fight-darwin-nunez-copa-america-semifinal/", "title": "Uruguayan Soccer Team Explains Clash With Colombia Fans", "body": "The Copa Am\u00e9rica soccer tournament held in the U.S. this summer has been characterized by intense physicality on the field. But while seven yellow cards and one red card were issued during the semifinal on Wednesday night, it ended up being action off the field that grabbed the most attention.\n\nA sea of yellow filled the Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, N.C. -- as supporters of Colombia far outnumbered those of their blue-wearing rivals Uruguay -- but tensions quickly turned red-hot after the full-time whistle sent Uruguay home and Colombia to the final.\n\nIn videos of the scene that quickly went viral on social media, opposing spectators threw punches and beverages at one another, while Uruguayan players -- including Liverpool forward Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez and Barcelona defender Ronald Ara\u00fajo -- climbed into the stands to join in the brawl.\n\nN\u00fa\u00f1ez could be seen taking several swings at Colombia fans as his teammates attempted to hold him back before security officials appeared to separate the two sides.\n\nThe tussle in the stands took place after a brief scuffle between the opposing players on the pitch, following a testy match that saw favorites Uruguay lose to Colombia, 1-0, despite being a man up for the entire second half after Colombia's Daniel Mu\u00f1oz was sent off for elbowing an opponent. Colombia has now extended its record unbeaten streak to 28 games as it heads to Miami next to take on Lionel Messi and Argentina for the South American title on Sunday.\n\nAfter the melee had subsided, Uruguayan captain Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez told reporters that his teammates had acted in response to a group of Colombia fans attacking the Uruguayan players' families, who were seated in a section near the touchline. \"They stormed all our families,\" Gim\u00e9nez said, complaining about the lack of official security intervention. \"This is a disaster. Our family is in danger. We had to get on top of the stands ASAP to rescue our loved ones.\"\n\nIgnacio Alonso, president of the Uruguayan Football Association, reiterated the explanation, telling reporters after the game: \"Uruguay's players had an instinctive reaction that is natural, which is to defend and protect the children who were in that area of the stadium and were suffering attacks on the women, on the parents, on the closest family members, siblings. And it's a father's reaction that is intuitively natural and was very rational given the events that surrounded them.\"\n\nESPN commentator and former U.S. national team player Herculez Gomez echoed the frustrations of the Uruguayans, calling the lack of security at the stadium \"dangerously pathetic,\" as he shared on X footage of N\u00fa\u00f1ez consoling his young son in the aftermath of the altercation.\n\nCONMEBOL, the South American soccer body that organizes the Copa Am\u00e9rica, condemned the violence in a statement, saying fans should channel their passion into cheering and that He was also seen throwing a chair towards supporters while still on the pitch.\n\nUruguay captain Jose Maria Gimenez revealed his fury at how these incidents were allowed to occur, blaming a lack of security.\n\n\"Colombian fans in a certain section descended on all our families,\" he said.\n\n\"They they won't let us speak on the microphone. This is a disaster, our families were in danger. We had to rush into the stands to remove our loved ones with tiny newborn babies.\n\n\"It's a total disaster. There wasn't a single police officer. They showed up half an hour later. A disaster. And we were there, standing up for ourselves, for our loved ones.\n\n\"Hopefully organisers take a little more precautions with our families, with the people and those around the stadiums. Because this happens every game.\n\n\"Our families are suffering because of some people who have a few drinks and don't know how to drink, who act like children. Hopefully, they'll take more precautions for the next game so this doesn't happen again, because this is a disaster.\"\n\nLuis Suarez, who consoled Nunez after he returned from the stands, added: \"Some of the players had wives, small children, their parents, older relatives. After Colombia sealed a 1-0 victory in the semi-finals, videos flooded of Uruguay's forward Darwin Nunez climbing up the stands and exchanging proper blows. Nunex was hit on his head by one of the fans as the incident escalated further before the security personnel had to intervene strongly to stop because the incident marred what was a thrilling semi-final.\n\nSouth American football's governing body CONMEBOL condemned the episode saying that it is investigating the matter and will not tolerate any form of violence that affects the game.\n\n\"Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values,\" CONMEBOL said. \"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field.\"\n\nUruguay's captain Jose Maria Gimenez reckoned that the players were trying to defend their families while calling the whole episode a disaster. \"Let me say something before they cut you off because they won't let us speak into the microphone, they don't want me to say anything about what's going on but this is a disaster,\" Gimenez said on the official broadcast.\n\n\"Please be careful, our families are in the stands, there are little newborn babies. {"uri": "8220002757", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "07:49:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T07:49:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T07:49:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/football/story/uruguay-coach-marcelo-bielsa-takes-responsibility-for-copa-america-exit-2565208-2024-07-11", "title": "Uruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa takes responsibility for Copa America exit", "body": "Uruguay failed to capitalise on their advantages in the semi-final\n\nUruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa has taken full responsibility for his team's exit from the Copa Am\u00e9rica, following a 1-0 semi-final defeat to Colombia. Bielsa acknowledged that Uruguay had more talent on paper but failed to capitalize on their advantages, ultimately falling to a decisive goal by Jefferson Lerma. Colombia progressed to the title clash despite being reduced to 10 men as Lerma's winner secured their spot in Sunday's final, leaving Uruguay to reflect on what could have been.\n\n\"Uruguay was in a clear condition to win this match if you assess the individual talent in each squad,\" Bielsa told reporters post-match. \"I manage the team that, in my opinion, had the stronger individual talent vis- -vis the opponent, and we weren't able to make the difference that I thought we were going to make if you compared both formations.\" Uruguay, a team with a storied history and 15 Copa America titles, entered the tournament as one of the favorites. They had impressive victories over hosts United States and five-time World Cup champions Brazil, but could not replicate that form against Colombia.\n\n\"I am personally liable for not achieving the result, despite having these players that were capable of being superior than the opponent,\" Bielsa continued. \"We were not able to seize our extra man advantage, and when a team wins with less individual talent, logically, the manager that is coaching the weaker team shows that he is superior than the coach that had the best players.\"\n\nUruguay had several opportunities to score in the first half but struggled to create clear chances after Colombia's Daniel Munoz was sent off just before halftime. Bielsa noted the disruption this caused to the match's flow.\n\n\"The first half, even if we didn't dominate possession, it was very even, and we should have made the difference. With one man down in the second half for Colombia, the match was completely interrupted,\" Bielsa explained. \"It was constantly start and stop. We should have created more chances and caused damage to the opponent. In the last minutes, they could have scored because they had clear chances. But we tried every possible way, every possible path.\"\n\nThe aftermath of the match saw clashes between Uruguay players and Colombia fans in the stands, prompting an investigation by CONMEBOL. {"uri": "8220428303", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "12:11:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T12:11:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T12:09:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/conmebol-release-statement-darwin-nunez-33219825", "title": "CONMEBOL statement on Nunez brawl as Uruguayan football president speaks out", "body": "Darwin Nunez could face a significant ban after being involved in a brawl in the stands following Uruguay's defeat to Colombia at Copa America. South American football federation CONMEBOL have released statement condemning the actions and will launch a full scale investigation into what exactly happened.\n\nNunez's Uruguay met with Colombia in the semi-final, vying for a spot in Sunday's final against Argentina. Colombia were the victors, however, clinching a 1-0 victory, thanks to a goal from Jefferson Lerma 40 minutes into the game.\n\nThe Colombians had to play half of the match with only 10 players after Daniel Munoz, Lerma's teammate from Crystal Palace, was sent off after receiving two yellow cards. Despite having an extra player, Nunez and Uruguay couldn't capitalise on the advantage, and Colombia managed to hold their ground in Charlotte, North Carolina, securing the win.\n\nREAD MORE: Luis Diaz and Luis Suarez gestures to Darwin Nunez after Copa America brawl sum them up\n\nREAD MORE: Darwin Nunez outburst speaks volumes as Liverpool star feels pressure\n\nHowever, things took a turn for the worse after the final whistle, when a brawl erupted in the stands - and Nunez was at the heart of it. The Liverpool forward led the Uruguayan squad into the crowd, much to the displeasure of the Colombian fans.\n\nNunez seemed to be struck by one of the fans, before he defended himself. Security quickly intervened and tried to defuse the situation, escorting Nunez and his teammates back to the changing room. The scenes were widely criticised by South America's governing body, CONMEBOL, in the aftermath.\n\nA statement from CONMEBOL disclosed: \"CONMEBOL strongly condemns any act of violence that affects football. Our work is based on the conviction that football connects us and unites us, through its positive values. There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all their passion into cheering on their teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nAUF president Ignacio Alonso also addressed the incident, but defended his players who, he claims acted in the best interest of their families' safety.\n\n\"The Uruguayan players had an instinctive, natural reaction, which was to defend the children who were being attacked, their wives, parents, siblings. It was a natural, instinctive reaction that was rational given the events that were taking place,\" Alonso said (via ESPN).\n\n\"We were in a box, where we had some attacks and we protected some children, opening the area to some kids who were scared and having some crises, but fundamentally what is worrying is what happened down on the field, where there was more diligence in repairs than in precaution.\n\n\"They quickly followed the evacuation protocol and we were able to resolve the situation, not without some inconvenience that you all saw. We are analyzing the images. There is no one who is currently in difficulty and measures were taken so that they could receive transport in appropriate places.\n\n\"Assistance was provided to those who had panic attacks, and now we are going to review them a little more at the hotel. In all tournaments, families are in the stands, there is usually a cordon or something similar, especially for a stadium that was 95% sold out before the start of the cup.\"", "source": {"uri": Jefferson Lerma scored in the 39th minute, and Colombia played a man short the entire second half in a 1-0 win over Uruguay on Wednesday night to reach the Copa America final against Lionel Messi and Argentina.\n\nCharlotte (US), Jul 11 (AP) Jefferson Lerma scored in the 39th minute, and Colombia played a man short the entire second half in a 1-0 win over Uruguay on Wednesday night to reach the Copa America final against Lionel Messi and Argentina.\n\nDaniel Mu\u00f1oz was ejected in first-half stoppage time for his second yellow card, but Colombia held on to reach the championship for the first time since winning its only Copa title as host in 2001. Colombia extended its unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games, one more than from 1992-94 and the longest current streak in men's soccer.\n\nAlso Read | President Droupadi Murmu Plays Badminton with Former Olympic Medallist Saina Nehwal Ahead of Ace-Shuttler's Her Story - My Story' Lecture (Watch Video).\n\nIn a contentious match that included seven yellow cards and one red, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle and some players went into the stands to scrap with fans.\n\nDefending champion Argentina and Colombia meet Sunday night at Miami Gardens, Florida.\n\nAlso Read | Cristiano Ronaldo Yet to Decide on His Retirement From International Football: Report.\n\nBefore an overwhelmingly pro-Colombia crowd at Bank of America Stadium, filled with yellow jerseys and flags, Uruguay fell behind for the first time in the tournament.\n\nJames Rodr\u00edguez's corner kick was headed in from short range by Lerma, who outjumped Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez for his third international goal and second of the tournament. Rodr\u00edguez has six assists in the tournament -- triple the total of any other player.\n\nMu\u00f1oz received his first yellow card from Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos in the 31st minute for a reckless slide tackle on Maximiliano Ara\u00fajo and his second for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the stomach.\n\nRodr\u00edguez was given a yellow card in the 55th minute for arguing with Ramos when the referee failed to stop play when Richard R\u00edos was kicked on a shin by Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez.\n\nR\u00edos was removed on a stretcher, re-entered the match, then went down in another challenge and was substituted in the 62nd minute. Rodr\u00edguez was removed at the same time to keep him eligible for the final.\n\nColombia goalkeeper Federico Valverde did not have to make his first save until he stopped Nicol\u00e1s de la Cruz in the 68th minute.\n\nLuis Su\u00e1rez, Uruguay's career leader with 68 goals, entered in the 66th minute and hit the outside of a post with a shot in the 71st.\n\nColombia's Mateus Uribe, another second-half sub, put an open shot wide in the 88th, and Uribe's open shot in the fourth minute of stoppage time ricocheted off the body of sliding goalkeeper Sergio Rochet and then the crossbar.\n\nThe match was played in 90-degree heat on a surface that was converted from artificial turf to grass in the weeks leading up the game.\n\nArgentina is seeking a record 16th Copa America title and looking to join Spain as the only countries to win three straight major titles. The former secured their spot in the final with a 1-0 victory.\n\nThe situation escalated post-match as Nunez led a group of Uruguay players into the crowd, where they were met with aggression from Colombian supporters. A large-scale fight ensued, with Nunez being hit by a fan while defending himself.\n\nNunez had led the charge of players into the stands to ensure the safety of their families and loved ones, with children lifted onto the pitch and to safety. The Liverpool star and his teammates had entered the crowd to stand by family and friends seated behind the team bench.\n\nREAD MORE: Darwin Nunez consoles son in emotional clip as teammate explains brawl in stands\n\nREAD MORE: Darwin Nunez outburst speaks volumes as Liverpool star feels pressure\n\nIn the aftermath of the incident, Nunez was seen being comforted by both Diaz and Suarez. Diaz had shared an emotional embrace with his Liverpool teammate just moments before the trouble in the stands.\n\n\"It was a disaster; there was no police and we had to defend our families,\" commented Uruguay's defender Jose Maria Gimenez. \"This is because of two or three who have one drink too many. A certain sector of the Colombian fans made an avalanche where our loved ones were.\"\n\nNunez has not yet made a public statement about the incident. CONMEBOL, the governing body for South American football, is expected to carry out an in-depth investigation before Sunday's Copa America final.\n\nA statement from the governing body read: \"CONMEBOL strongly condemns any act of violence that affects football. Our work is based on the conviction that football connects us and unites us, through its positive values.\n\n\"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all their passion into cheering on their teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nColombia are now set to go head-to-head with Argentina in Miami for the final, with Argentina hoping to build on its victory in the 2021 competition and the World Cup the following year. {"uri": "8219749220", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "04:24:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T04:24:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T04:24:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/3013032-colombia-reaches-copa-america-final-after-23-years-amid-controversy", "title": "Colombia Reaches Copa America Final After 23 Years Amid Controversy | Sports-Games", "body": "Colombia has clinched a spot in the Copa America final for the first time in 23 years after a dramatic 1-0 victory over Uruguay. The match, held on Wednesday night, saw Jefferson Lerma score the decisive goal in the 39th minute. Colombia's journey to the final wasn't easy; they played the entire second half a man short after Daniel Mu\u00f1oz was ejected.\n\nThe game was marred by intense altercations, including players from both teams pushing and shoving as the final whistle blew. Uruguay forward Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez even entered the stands and engaged in a brawl with fans clad in Colombian colors.\n\nIn the championship game set for Sunday, Colombia will face Lionel Messi and defending champion Argentina in Miami Gardens, Florida. This final appearance marks Colombia's first since they hosted and won the Copa America in 2001. {"uri": "8219665414", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "02:55:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T02:55:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T02:54:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://toronto.citynews.ca/2024/07/10/colombia-beats-uruguay-will-face-argentina-in-copa-america-final/", "title": "Colombia beats Uruguay, will face Argentina in Copa Am\u00e9rica final", "body": "Jefferson Lerma scored in the 39th minute, and Colombia played a man short the entire second half in a 1-0 win over Uruguay on Wednesday night to reach the Copa Am\u00e9rica final against Lionel Messi and Argentina.\n\nDaniel Mu\u00f1oz was ejected in first-half stoppage time for his second yellow card, but Colombia held on to reach the championship for the first time since winning its only Copa title as host in 2001. Colombia extended its unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games, one more than from 1992-94 and the longest current streak in men's soccer.\n\nIn a contentious match that included seven yellow cards and one red, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle and some players went into the stands to scrap with fans.\n\nDefending champion Argentina and Colombia meet Sunday night at Miami Gardens, Florida. Uruguay will play Canada in the third-place game on Saturday in Charlotte.\n\nBefore an overwhelmingly pro-Colombia crowd at Bank of America Stadium, filled with yellow jerseys and flags, Uruguay fell behind for the first time in the tournament.\n\nJames Rodr\u00edguez's corner kick was headed in from short range by Lerma, who outjumped Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez for his third international goal and second of the tournament. Rodr\u00edguez has six assists in the tournament -- triple the total of any other player.\n\nMu\u00f1oz received his first yellow card from Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos in the 31st minute for a reckless slide tackle on Maximiliano Ara\u00fajo and his second for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the stomach.\n\nRodr\u00edguez was given a yellow card in the 55th minute for arguing with Ramos when the referee failed to stop play when Richard R\u00edos was kicked on a shin by Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez.\n\nR\u00edos was removed on a stretcher, re-entered the match, then went down in another challenge and was substituted in the 62nd minute. Rodr\u00edguez was removed at the same time to keep him eligible for the final.\n\nColombia goalkeeper Federico Valverde didn't have to make his first save until he stopped Nicol\u00e1s de la Cruz in the 68th minute.\n\nLuis Su\u00e1rez, Uruguay's career leader with 68 goals, entered in the 66th minute and hit the outside of a post with a shot in the 71st.\n\nColombia's Mateus Uribe, another second-half sub, put an open shot wide in the 88th, and Uribe's open shot in the fourth minute of stoppage time ricocheted off the body of sliding goalkeeper Sergio Rochet and then the crossbar.\n\nThe match was played in 90-degree heat on a surface that was converted from artificial turf to grass in the weeks leading up the game.\n\nArgentina is seeking a record 16th Copa The former Real Madrid midfielder registered his sixth assist of the tournament as Jefferson Lerma's headed effort beat Sergio Rochet at his near post to put Colombia 1-0 up.\n\nEverything was going well for Colombia up until stoppage time near the end of the first 45. {"uri": "8219899530", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "06:34:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T06:34:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T06:34:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.espn.com.au/football/story/_/id/40537147/colombia-find-new-way-win-tense-copa-america-semifinal", "title": "Colombia find new way to win in tense Copa Am\u00e9rica semifinal", "body": "CHARLOTTE, North Carolina -- The hallmark of a championship team is the ability to win games in a variety of fashions and circumstances. Heading into Wednesday's semifinal against Uruguay, Colombia has had things its own way at the Copa Am\u00e9rica, scoring goals for fun, and winning three of their four matches, with the lone blemish -- if you can call it that -- a draw with Brazil.\n\nBut in Wednesday's match, Colombia had to summon all of its reserves. Los Cafeteros played more than half the match with 10 men following Daniel Munoz's second yellow card in in first-half stoppage-time. But it was able to ride more set piece brilliance from James Rodr\u00edguez, some stretched-to-the-limit defending, and yes, some luck too to prevail 1-0, earning a trip to just the third Copa final in its history.\n\n\"I think this is a squad that is giving its all, and beyond the circumstances of the match, they really deserve this and we're very happy,\" said Colombia manager Nestor Lorenzo, with the help of a translator. \"We're very happy for bringing joy to the Colombian people.\"\n\nUruguay is a team that loves to shove teams -- literally sometimes -- out of their comfort zone, pressing all over the field in a bid to achieve maximum chaos. After a slow start, La Celeste appeared to be doing exactly that, with Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez twice going close. Jefferson Lerma's goal, however, put Colombia ahead just before half-time. But then Munoz's ill-advised elbow to Manuel Ugarte's chest -- especially in the age of VAR -- earned him a second caution and the player advantage to Uruguay.\n\n\"One of the main topics we discuss is that we never want to be one man down,\" said Lorenzo. \"It is almost impossible to maintain performance with 10 players on the pitch. Teams that were dominating their opponents, when they were one man down, were eliminated from the tournament.\"\n\nColombia proved to be the exception, with Lorenzo maximizing his bench, and the team going beyond what it thought possible.\n\n\"We always talk about multiplying the efforts. Sometimes 10 can make the effort of 12 players,\" said Lorenzo.\n\nFor Uruguay manager Marcelo Bielsa, the ejection was the ultimate poisoned gift. Instead of being able to pounce on turnovers and create opportunities in transition, Uruguay was faced with the prospect of trying to break down a Colombia side that was increasingly content to sit back and defend. The chaotic became predictable.\n\n\"I would have preferred to avoid the sending off of the Colombian player because what happened in the second half,\" he said. \"Given the way in which Colombia had to play to maintain the situation with one man down, it created greater challenges than the ones we were facing when they were 11.\"\n\nIt helped Colombia's cause that another moment of magic from Rodriguez had helped Los Cafeteros into a lead, with his corner-kick setting up Lerma for the game's only goal. It was Rodriguez's record-breaking sixth assist of the tournament, continuing his stellar run through this Copa Am\u00e9rica. But for Lorenzo, there were 14 other heroes.\n\n\"I think it's a group that wants to be protagonist of this tournament. They want to win,\" he said. \"They are very hungry as players and eager and they really add many elements to the game beyond the tactical side. I think we we're at the pivotal moment and we also see that there are some weaknesses that we need to overcome. And until you overcome those, you cannot grow. And when you do overcome those obstacles, you can evolve. So, I think we're doing very well and yes, we are moving forward.\"\n\nRodriguez's performance was in contrast to that of another legendary player in Uruguay's Luis Su\u00e1rez. Bielsa threw Suarez on with 23 minutes remaining in a bid to find the elusive goal that would take the match to penalties. Suarez had his opportunities too. He had a wide-open look at goal in the 72nd minute, only to hit the outside of the post. He had a chance to create danger two minutes later only to shank his touch over the end line when he had considerable space in the box.\n\nIt was one of many situations in which Lorenzo got the better of Bielsa. For a time, the Colombia manager continued to play with two forwards after Munoz's sending off, before resorting to a five-man back line late, as Colombia began to tire. Lorenzo's side actually came closest to scoring, but substitute Mateus Uribe squandered a pair of wide-open chances late. It didn't matter. Colombia survived. As for Lorenzo, he refused to look at the match as a contest of managers.\n\n\"I think that to beat Bielsa you need to walk many miles,\" he said. \"He is a revered coach and I really admire him as a person, and it was our turn to win.\"\n\nIf there was anything to take a shine off the game, it was the post-match melee in which several Uruguay players went into the stands to battle Colombia fans after they felt their family members were in danger. The apparent lack of sufficient security will certainly go down as another instance where CONMEBOL's poor organization of the tournament was revealed. The image of Nunez comforting his child will be one of the enduring images of the tournament.\n\nNow Lorenzo, an Argentine, finds himself going up against the country of his birth in the final. He mentioned that his friends have been talking about the possibility. But Lorenzo has been laying down some Columbian roots for some time. He was an assistant with Colombia for seven years under Jose Pekerman during one of the stops the two made together, and he's been in charge of the senior team since 2022.\n\n\"I think it will be a very beautiful moment,\" he said of Sunday's final. \"I will be next to players that I have known throughout my career and really admire.\"\n\nAs for the team itself, this is new ground to a degree. Los Cafeteros have but one Copa Am\u00e9rica title to their name, from back in 2001, and were beaten finalists on one other occasion in 1975. The semifinals have been a veritable graveyard, however. Seven times previously Colombia has fallen in that round, including three years ago when Argentina beat then on penalties on their way to the title. At last, the semifinal hoodoo has been vanquished. There's just one more hurdle to go.\n\n\"Colombia has always played it to win. Anything can happen,\" Lorenzo said. \"Argentina is the best team in the world, champion in America, intercontinental champion, champion of the world. But we will try.\"", "source": {"uri": "espn.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uruguay", "type": "loc", "score": 5, In a way, they already are.\n\nDarwin Nunez misses, mazy Luis Diaz runs, Luis Suarez hysterics, lung-busting end-to-end action - you'd be forgiven for forgetting that this match was a Copa America semifinal taking place in North Carolina.\n\nWednesday's matchup between Colombia and Uruguay - played in an American footballs stadium, no less - had an overwhelming Premier League flavor as Colombia clung to a 1-0 win in an extremely heated clash.\n\nReally, there was something for everybody, including Darwin Nunez's many skeptics after the Liverpool forward burned three chances in the first half - one which caused teammate Federico Valverde to pound the floor in frustration.\n\nThere would be plenty more British-based influence.\n\nLiverpool's Darwin Nunez had a brutal night as he missed several great chances to score\n\nCrystal Palace's Jefferson Lerma notched the lone goal for Cololmbia, who are now in the Copa America finals\n\nCrystal Palace midfielder Jefferson Lerma scored the opener for Colombia, who also started Liverpool's Luis Diaz and former Spurs midfielder Rodrigo Bentancur.\n\nLerma's Eagles teammate Daniel Munoz was also sent off for a second, silly yellow card on the stroke of half time when he elbowed Manuel Ugarte, while Man United's Facundo Pellestri bustled up and down the wing - without much luck.\n\nAnd Liverpool legend - and current Inter Miami star - Luis Suarez was brought on as a second half-substitute with Uruguay chasing a goal. He almost just got them one when he hit the post from inside the box.\n\nMake no mistake about it, though: despite the current Premier League players and alums, this was a decidedly South American affair, as a sea of yellow filled the Bank of America Stadium stands, and the streets of Charlotte before.\n\nOne Colombian reporter even performed a prayer in Spanish right before kick off.\n\nHe may have needed it during a hectic, end-to-end night that saw Colombia clinging to their slender lead towards the end.\n\nThings seemed to go off the rails for Colombia when Richard Rios got hurt in the second half. Not necessarily because of his play prior, but because of the feverish reaction it elicited as Uruguay continued play with him crumpled in the corner.\n\nJames Rodriguez angrily beelined the referee and got in his face during the next stoppage and was subsequently booked. The yellow didn't do much damage, but the moment of madness saw Uruguay creep back in the game.\n\nNunez again saw a chance go begging when the ball got stuck in his feet in the box, before Colombia's Camilo Vargas made a fairly miraculous diving save in the 68th minute.\n\nThere was a (discarded) penalty shout too, and more memorably a chance that the ever-lethal Suarez spurned from close in the 71st minute.\n\nThe miss caused him to fall to the ground in anguish, before Valverde whizzed a shot wide minutes later.\n\nColombia, barely, would hold on despite sub Mateus Uribe missing two golden chances after coming on as a sub. The first of which, in the 88th minute, was hit wide from point-blank range and the second - which was even harder to miss - somehow ricocheting off of Rochet onto the bar.\n\nUruguay kept pushing - They were jumping over in an effort to try and separate the Colombia fans from them.\"\n\nFists were subsequently thrown at Nunez in a punch-up, with one hit landing on his face.\n\nUruguay captain Jose Gimenez spoke to TUDN on the incident: \"This is a disaster. Our family is in danger.\n\n\"We had to get into the stands to take out our loved ones with small babies, newborns. Everything was a disaster. There was not a single police officer.\"\n\nUruguayan newspaper El Observador stated Ronald Araujo, Matias Vina and Mathias Olivera were also present with Nunez as they approached the stand, with the fight lasting approximately 10 minutes.\n\nIt took more than 10 minutes for police to descend on the fight scene and PA said that \"about 100 Uruguayan fans and members of the federation staff remained on the field for their own protection more than 20 minutes after the game.\"\n\nAfter defending his family, Nunez consoled one of his visibly shaken children following the incident.\n\nWe {"uri": "8219778320", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "04:54:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T04:54:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T04:53:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.etvbharat.com/en/!sports/colombia-beats-uruguay-1-0-and-will-face-lionel-messi-and-argentina-in-copa-america-final-enn24071100936", "title": "Colombia Beats Uruguay 1-0 ; To Face Lionel Messi's Argentina In Copa America Final", "body": "Charlotte (US): Jefferson Lerma scored in the 39th minute, and Colombia played a man short the entire second half in a 1-0 win over Uruguay on Wednesday night to reach the Copa America final against Lionel Messi and Argentina.\n\nDaniel Munoz was ejected in first-half stoppage time for his second yellow card, but Colombia held on to reach the championship for the first time since winning its only Copa title as host in 2001. Colombia extended its unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games, one more than from 1992-94 and the longest current streak in men's soccer. In a contentious match that included seven yellow cards and one red, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle and some players went into the stands to scrap with fans.\n\nDefending champion Argentina and Colombia meet Sunday night at Miami Gardens, Florida. Before an overwhelmingly pro-Colombia crowd at Bank of America Stadium, filled with yellow jerseys and flags, Uruguay fell behind for the first time in the tournament.\n\nJames Rodrguez's corner kick was headed in from short range by Lerma, who outjumped Jos Mara Gimenez for his third international goal and second of the tournament. Rodrguez has six assists in the tournament -- triple the total of any other player. Muoz received his first yellow card from Mexican referee Csar Ramos in the 31st minute for a reckless slide tackle on Maximiliano Arajo and his second for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the stomach.\n\nRodrguez was given a yellow card in the 55th minute for arguing with Ramos when the referee failed to stop play when Richard Ros was kicked on a shin by Darwin Nez. Ros was removed on a stretcher, re-entered the match, then went down in another challenge and was substituted in the 62nd minute. Rodrguez was removed at the same time to keep him eligible for the final. Colombia goalkeeper Federico Valverde did not have to make his first save until he stopped Nicols de la Cruz in the 68th minute.\n\nLuis Suarez, Uruguay's career leader with 68 goals, entered in the 66th minute and hit the outside of a post with a shot in the 71st. Colombia's Mateus Uribe, another second-half sub, put an open shot wide in the 88th, and Uribe's open shot in the fourth minute of stoppage time ricocheted off the body of sliding goalkeeper Sergio Rochet and then the crossbar. The match was played in 90-degree heat on a surface that was converted from artificial turf to grass in the weeks leading up to the game.\n\nArgentina is seeking a record 16th Copa America title and {"uri": "8220319933", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "11:11:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T11:11:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T11:10:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/luis-suarez-sparks-mass-brawl-between-colombia-and-uruguay-players/", "title": "Fans think Luis Suarez tried to bite Colombian player in viral video - it sparked a huge brawl", "body": "Highlights Luis Suarez sparked a brawl between Colombia and Uruguay players after their Copa America semi-final match. Speculation has emerged that Suarez attempted to bite Miguel Borja in a viral video, which then kickstarted the fight. Uruguay players, including Darwin Nunez, were then involved in a fight between players and Colombia supporters in the stands of the stadium.\n\nColombia's Copa America semi-final against Uruguay descended into chaos after the final whistle, with players getting involved in a mass brawl both amongst themselves and with fans in the crowd. And a video of Luis Suarez has since gone viral, with fans speculating that he tried to bite an opposition player which led to tempers flaring on the pitch.\n\nTuesday night's match was a feisty encounter as both teams looked to book their place in the final, with the victor going on to face Argentina. It was Colombia who took the lead in the game, thanks to Crystal Palace's Jefferson Lerma.\n\nNestor Lorenzo's side were then dealt a blow when Daniel Munoz was sent off shortly before half-time for elbowing Manuel Ugarte, but despite Uruguay's efforts after the interval, they could not find an equaliser. Frustration continued to build as the game wore on, with a total of eight yellow cards shown before full time in their 1-0 defeat.\n\nRelated Ranking the Top 11 South American Footballers in History\n\nFrom Lionel Messi to Ronaldo, South America has produced some of the greatest players of all-time.\n\nSuarez Confronts Miguel Borja at Full Time Fans speculate he tried to bite Colombian\n\nTempers seemingly boiled over after the final whistle went, which confirmed Uruguay's elimination from the competition. Players and coaching staff clashed on the field, and it was Suarez's actions which seemingly set things off.\n\nFootage after the game appears to show the former Liverpool man walking up to Miguel Borja following the game and leaning in towards his shoulder. Some have said that he attempted to bite the forward before he walked away to talk to James Rodriguez. That then led to everything kicking off, with Suarez even seen throwing a punch at one member of Colombia's coaching staff.\n\nIt wouldn't be the first time that Suarez attempted to bite a player, having committed three similar offences during his career. While at Ajax in 2010, he bit PSV's Otman Bakkal on the shoulder, which led to a seven-game suspension. He then received a 10 game ban for biting Chelsea's Branislav Ivanovic while at Liverpool, before then being suspended for four months by FIFA after biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini in 2014.\n\nGIVEMESPORT Key Statistic: Luis Suarez is Uruguay's top scorer of all time with 68 goals, 10 more than Edinson Cavani who is in second place and 32 more than third-placed Diego Forlan.\n\nDarwin Nunez Fights in Crowd After Game Players seemingly concerned over the safety of their families\n\nSuarez's actions likely would have received more attention were it not for the wild scenes off the pitch which then emerged after the final whistle. Uruguay players were seen storming into the crowd to confront Colombia's supporters, with footage even showing Darwin Nunez fighting them in the stands.\n\nThe reason behind the scuffle off the pitch was supposedly because of their families being made to feel unsafe by Colombia fans who were all around them. Jose Maria Giminez expressed after the match that they had to defend their loved ones, labelling the entire situation 'a disaster'. CONMEBOL were also forced to release a statement, saying that there was no place for violence at the competition.\n\n\"Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values. There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field. We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all of their passion into cheering on their national teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nUruguay will be hoping for calmer scenes when they take on Canada in their third-place playoff match on Sunday 14th July, as both teams seek to get their hands on a bronze medal. {"uri": "8219670454", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "03:01:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T03:01:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T03:00:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.90min.com/posts/uruguay-0-1-colombia-player-ratings-as-colombia-advance-to-copa-america-2024-final-despite-daniel-munoz-red-card", "title": "Uruguay 0-1 Colombia: Player ratings as Colombia advance to Copa America 2024 final despite Daniel Munoz red card", "body": "Colombia extended their unbeaten streak to 28 games as Nestor Lorenzo's squad defeated Uruguay to advance to the Copa America 2024 final despite playing with ten men for more than 50 minutes.\n\nColombia and Uruguay both won their respective groups at Copa America 2024, and a semi-final between the two sides felt inevitable. Colombia emphatically defeated Panama in the quarter-finals 5-0, while Uruguay survived a penalty shootout against Brazil. Tonight, the two sides faced off to decide who gets to take on the reigning champions, Argentina, in the Copa America final.\n\nHow the game unfolded\n\nIn front of a stadium of yellow shirts, Colombia looked the more dangerous side in the early stages of the match, pushing forward with precision and speed to test Uruguay's makeshift backline. It was La Celeste, though, who had the first real chance of the game when Darwin Nunez released a left-footed strike that went just wide in the 17th minute. The Liverpool striker would have two more decent looks at goal, but he lacked the end product.\n\nUruguay might not have been able to capitalize on their chances, but Colombia did not make the same mistakes. Jefferson Lerma, back in the starting XI after serving a one-game suspension for yellow card accumulation, got on the end of another brilliant James Rodriguez corner with a header at the back post in the 39th minute.\n\nJust six minutes after the opening goal, Daniel Munoz, who was already booked 31st minute, received a second yellow for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the chest. Colombia went into the locker room up a goal, but down a man.\n\nA goal for Uruguay felt inevitable in the second half, but La Celeste struggled to take advantage of their extra player. Their best chance came in the 71st minute when an unmarked Luis Suarez kissed the outside of the post with a strike from 15 yards out. Marcelo Bielsa's squad kept knocking on the door, but could not find an equalizer against Colombia's stout backline, forcing them to settle for the third place match while Colombia advanced to the Copa America final.\n\nGK: Camilo Vargas - 7/10 - Vargas kept a clean sheet tonight and made timely saves when it mattered most.\n\nRB: Daniel Munoz - 3/10 - Munoz was sent off in the first half after receiving two yellow cards, leaving his team with ten men in a must-win match.\n\nCB: Davinson Sanchez - 7/10 - Down a man, Sanchez was called upon to both maintain Colombia's clean sheet and stop Luis Suarez in the second half.\n\nCB: Carlos Cuesta - 7/10 - Cuesta carried the ball forward from the backline in the first half, contributing to Colombia's attack, but he had to stand tall in the second half to keep Uruguay off the scoresheet.\n\nLB: Johan Mojica - 6/10 - Mojica defended well tonight, especially once Colombia went down to ten men. The left-back effectively took Facundo Pellistri and Cristian Olivera out of the game.\n\nDM: Richard Rios - 6/10 - Rios is the engine of Colombia's midfield, constantly helping out on defense while also pushing forward on the attack. He was also the victim of several harsh tackles that eventually forced him off the pitch in the 61st minute.\n\nDM: Jefferson Lerma - 7/10 - After serving his one-game suspension for yellow card accumulation, Lerma returned to the starting XI and scored Colombia's only goal tonight.\n\nRM: Jhon Arias - 5/10 - Arias had a quiet first half, supporting the attack when he could. The midfielder was subbed off at halftime, though, in favor of a defender after Munoz's red card.\n\nAM: James Rodriguez - 7/10 - Rodriguez recorded his sixth assist tonight on Colombia's only goal, the most by a single player since 2011.\n\nLM: Luis Diaz - 8/10 - Diaz terrorized the right side of Uruguay's defense, using his speed and dribbling ability to take on various players and carve out goalscoring opportunities. The Liverpool player put forth a valiant effort down a man to hold the ball up.\n\nST: Jhon Cordoba - 5/10 - Cordoba found himself on the end of a couple half-chances, but the striker failed to test Sergio Rochet.\n\nSUB: Santiago Arias - 6/10 - Arias was subbed on at halftime to slot in at right-back after Munoz was sent off. Despite only making one prior appearance this Copa America, the defender did well to help his backline stop Uruguay.\n\nSUB: Mateus Uribe - 5/10 - Uribe came on for the injured Rios and brought energy to the Colombian midfield as they fought to defend with ten men. Uribe could have sealed the game in the 88th and the 94th minute, but missed both chances.\n\nSUB: Kevin Castano - 5/10 - Castano's fresh legs were a welcomed reprieve for the tired Colombians on the pitch.\n\nSUB: Yerry Mina - 6/10 - Mina was subbed on in the 75th minute to give Los Cafeteros an extra center-back.\n\nSUB: Luis Sinisterra - N/A - Sinisterra came on in the 86th minute and joined in on the defensive effort.\n\nNestor Lorenzo - 8/10 - Nestor Lorenzo deserves all the credit for leading Colombia to the Copa America 2024 final. The manager made crucial substitutions after Daniel Munoz was sent off in the first half, giving his side every chance to maintain their 1-0 lead and their unbeaten streak. It takes a certain resilience to survive down a man in a semi-final against a team that had not lost at this year's Copa America, but Lorenzo's squad came out with the victory.", "source": {"uri": There, it will face a stiff task against Lionel Messi and reigning World Cup champion Argentina, which cruised through its half of the field while allowing a single goal in five games.\n\nThe game was played in Charlotte, but might as well have been hosted in Bogot\u00e1. The Bank of America stands were packed with fans sporting yellow Colombia jerseys eager to cheer their team on. Colombia delivered for those fans in a testy game that tallied six yellow cards saw a red-card ejection.\n\nColombia entered Wednesday's game as the highest-scoring team in the tournament (11 goals), fresh off a 5-0 quarterfinal win Panama. It struck first on a corner kick in the 38th minute. James Rodr\u00edguez sent the ball to the back post on the corner kick, where Jefferson Lerma leapt high in the air and squeezed the ball between the post and goalkeeper Sergio Rochet.\n\nThe goal was just the second allowed by Uruguay all tournament.\n\nColombia's defense, meanwhile, stifled a Uruguay offense that scored nine goals in four games en route to Wednesday's matchup. Uruguay didn't put any of its four first-half shots on goal.\n\nThe tide threatened to shift late in the second half. Colombia's Daniel Mu\u00f1oz, who picked up a yellow card earlier in the half on a tackle, picked up his second just before the half. After a scuffle following a foul on Colombia's Davinson S\u00e1nchez, Uruguay's Manuel Ugarte grabbed Mu\u00f1oz's jersey from behind.\n\nMu\u00f1oz responded with an elbow to the chest that knocked Ugarte to the turf, drawing his second yellow and ultimately a red card that led to his ejection.\n\nHead coach N\u00e9stor Lorenzo protested to no avail. Mu\u00f1oz was tossed, and Colombia was set to play the second half a man down.\n\nUruguay's offense was much improved after halftime as it controlled the ball and put two of its seven shots on goal. The Reds are keen to establish the facts around the worrying scenes at the Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte which saw their striker enter the crowd and get involved in altercations with Colombia supporters before they make any official comment.\n\nIt comes after claims from Uruguay captain Jose Maria Gimenez that a 'disaster' could have occurred as Uruguay players' families were targeted by Colombia supporters. Gimenez, along with Ronald Araujo, Nunez, and other Uruguay players jumped into the stands and it was the Liverpool striker who was singled out in altercations.\n\nThe Atletico Madrid defender said: \"I hope that those organising this event take more care of the families, the people, and the surroundings of the stadiums because this is a disaster.\n\n\"The same thing happens in every match. Our families are suffering because of those who drink too much alcohol and behave like children with no sense. I hope they take precautions and it doesn't happen again because this is a disaster.\"\n\nColombia, despite having 10 men for the second half, held on to a 1-0 win to book a place in the final against Argentina on Sunday.\n\nBut the game will be remembered for the scenes at the end. Liverpool will now wait for the time difference to allow them to contact Nunez as part of their duty of care for the player and also speak to the Uruguayan football federation to establish the facts. Nunez, 25, could face a ban for his actions despite the potential reasoning behind it.\n\nSouth American football's governing body, CONMEBOL, said: \"CONMEBOL strongly condemns any act of violence that affects football.\n\n\"Our work is based on the conviction that football connects us and unites us, through its positive values. There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field.\n\n\"We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all their passion into cheering on their teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nNunez was clearly emotional as he held one of his children on the pitch after he had returned down from the stands at the American stadium.\n\nFormer Tottenham midfielder Eric Dier was given a four-match ban and fined \u00a340,000 for climbing over seats to confront a fan in March 2020. Dier claimed he was defending his brother, Patrick, in the scenes after\n\nSpurs had lost to Norwich in an FA Cup clash while he had also been abused himself. James Rodriguez's masterclass and a resolute performance from 10-men Colombia sealed their date with Argentina in the final following a 1-0 victory over Uruguay in the Copa America semi-final.\n\nNorth Carolina [US], July 11 (ANI): James Rodriguez's masterclass and a resolute performance from 10-men Colombia sealed their date with Argentina in the final following a 1-0 victory over Uruguay in the Copa America semi-final.\n\nAs the final whistle blew in North Carolina's Bank of America Stadium, Colombia players jumped in jubilation to celebrate their win that defied the odds to keep Uruguay's high-flying attack quiet.\n\nAlso Read | President Droupadi Murmu Plays Badminton with Former Olympic Medallist Saina Nehwal Ahead of Ace-Shuttler's Her Story - My Story' Lecture (Watch Video).\n\nTheir determined performance extended their unbeaten run to a team-record 28 games. Their last defeat dates back to February 2022, served to them by the opposition that awaits them in the final of the ongoing tournament on Sunday.\n\nUruguay had their chances to go in front throughout the 90 minutes but struggled to guide the ball into the back of the net.\n\nAlso Read | Elena Rybakina Beats Elina Svitolina To Reach Wimbledon 2024 Semifinals, To Face Barbora Krejcikova.\n\nLiverpool's ace Darwin Nunez attempted to side-foot the ball inside the back of the net, but his shot was a whisker away from his target in the 19th minute.\n\nIt was Rodriguez who carried the attacking threat and paved the way for Colombia to lift their first Copa America title since 2001.\n\nIn front of an avid atmosphere created by the ecstatic fans, he served the ball to Jefferson Lerma, who headed the ball into the net in the 39th minute of the game.\n\nDespite going in front, Colombia's task to defend their slender one-goal advantage became an intricate affair. Defender Daniel Munoz swung his elbow at Uruguay's Manuel Ugarte, was shown a second yellow card and got sent off the field in the first-half stoppage time.\n\nWith time running out, Uruguay decided to introduce one of their most prolific strikers, Luis Suarez, into the thick of the action.\n\nIn the 71st minute, he had the opportunity to bring the game back on level terms but failed to deliver in the decisive moment.\n\nColombia struck the crossbar in the final minutes of the game, but one goal turned out to be sufficient to seal their date with Argentina in the final. (AP) -- Jefferson Lerma scored in the 39th minute, and Colombia played a man short the entire second half in a 1-0 win over Uruguay on Wednesday night to reach the Copa America final against Lionel Messi and Argentina.\n\nDaniel Mu\u00f1oz was ejected in first-half stoppage time for his second yellow card, but Colombia held on to reach the championship for the first time since winning its only Copa title as host in 2001. Colombia extended its unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games, one more than from 1992-94 and the longest current streak in men's international soccer.\n\nIn a contentious match that included seven yellow cards and one red, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle and some players went into the stands to scrap with fans.\n\nDefending champion Argentina and Colombia meet Sunday night at Miami Gardens, Florida. The Albiceleste are seeking a record 16th Copa title and are looking to join Spain from 2008-12 as the only countries to win three straight major championships.\n\nBefore an overwhelmingly pro-Colombia crowd of 70,644 that filled Bank of America Stadium with yellow jerseys and flags, Uruguay fell behind for the first time in the tournament.\n\nJames Rodr\u00edguez's corner kick was headed in from short range by Lerma, who outjumped Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez for his third international goal and second of the tournament. Rodr\u00edguez has six assists in the tournament -- triple the total of any other player.\n\nMu\u00f1oz received his first yellow card from Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos in the 31st minute for a reckless slide tackle on Maximiliano Ara\u00fajo and his second for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the stomach.\n\nRodr\u00edguez was given a yellow card in the 55th minute for arguing with Ramos when the referee failed to stop play after Richard R\u00edos was kicked on a shin by Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez.\n\nR\u00edos was removed on a stretcher, re-entered the match, then went down in another challenge and was substituted in the 62nd minute. Rodr\u00edguez was removed at the same time to keep him eligible for the final.\n\nColombia goalkeeper Federico Valverde didn't have to make his first save until he stopped Nicol\u00e1s de la Cruz in the 68th minute.\n\nLuis Su\u00e1rez, Uruguay's career leader with 68 goals, entered in the 66th minute and hit the outside of a post with a shot in the 71st. He grasped his head in his hands in disgust.\n\nColombia's Mateus Uribe, another second-half sub, put an open shot wide in the 88th, and Uribe's open shot in the fourth minute of stoppage time ricocheted off the body of sliding goalkeeper Sergio Rochet and then the crossbar.\n\nUruguay moved Rochet up the field in the final minute, desparate for a goal.\n\nThe match was played in 90-degree heat on a surface that was converted from artificial turf to grass in the weeks leading up the game.\n\nPlayers on the NFL's Carolina Panthers have been outspoken about soccer teams having the luxury of playing on grass on their home field. NFL games here are played artificial turf, which players say leaves them more susceptible to injuries.\n\nAP Copa America coverage: https://apnews.com/hub/copa-america", "source": {"uri": The altercation involved players, referees, camera crews, and business executives became entangled in a frenzied scrum, the scene a blur of motion and confusion.\n\nSuarez, wearing his renowned No. 9 shirt, was spotted towering over opponents and shoving individuals thought to be from Colombia's coaching team. With tensions running high, Suarez pushed a man in a red hat off balance, igniting further chaos as a reserve Uruguayan player retaliated.\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool plan for Darwin Nunez as club prepare response to shocking scenes in South America\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool already have ready-made Van Dijk replacement to save them millions\n\nThe commentators captured the moment perfectly: \"I'll give you one guess who sparked this originally,\" before the camera focused on Suarez. \"And now it's boiling over,\" they added, witnessing more figures from the sidelines dive in to try and calm the storm.\n\nThe chaos wasn't confined to the pitch; it spilled over into the stands where Liverpool's Darwin Nunez was seen scaling barriers to confront Colombian supporters. A shirtless Nunez engaged in a fistfight, defending himself while exchanging heated words, as beverages were thrown through the air.\n\nThe crowd continued to taunt the striker as the situation turned into a chaotic spectacle. Uruguay's Jose Gimenez spoke out about the incident, claiming that the players had to step in to protect their families from aggressive Colombia fans due to a lack of police presence.\n\nGimenez commented: \"It was a disaster; there was no police and we had to defend our families.\" Colombia secured a narrow 1-0 win against Uruguay with Jefferson Lerma heading in a superb cross from James Rodriguez early on.\n\nThe victory was made more difficult when Daniel Munoz got sent off for a second bookable offence after elbowing Manuel Ugarte, leaving Colombia with ten men. Despite being a man down, Uruguay couldn't capitalise on their advantage, managing only two shots on target during the entire match.\n\nThey pushed for an equaliser, winning free kicks towards the end but were unable to make them count, with the game slipping away from them. As of now, CONMEBOL has not responded to any footage from the controversial semi-final or issued any disciplinary actions.\n\nHowever, they have previously acted quickly against violence, as seen last {"uri": "2024-07-418404233", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "09:13:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T09:13:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T09:08:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/11/sport/colombia-uruguay-clash-copa-america-spt-intl/index.html", "title": "Colombia advances to Copa Am\u00e9rica final as tempers flare post-match", "body": "Uruguay forward Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez clashes with Colombia fans after the semifinal.\n\nColombia advanced to the Copa Am\u00e9rica final following a 1-0 win over Uruguay at Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, North Carolina, on Wednesday, but the game was marred by unsavory scenes after full-time.\n\nJefferson Lerma scored the match's only goal in the 39th minute as Los Cafeteros extended their unbeaten streak to 28 matches.\n\nThe match was testy and featured seven yellow cards and one red card after Colombia's Daniel Mu\u00f1oz was ejected in the first half after being shown a second yellow card.\n\nTempers flared even more after the match.\n\nAfter the final whistle, players from both squads got into it at center field before the Fox Sports 1 broadcast showed Uruguayan players entering the stands and getting into a scuffle with fans.\n\nA 'disaster'\n\nUruguay captain Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez said after the match that players were trying to defend their families and called the incident with fans a \"disaster.\"\n\n\"Let me tell you something: they should have been careful because there are families in the grandstand,\" Gimenez told the official broadcaster in Spanish.\n\n\"And if there is an avalanche falling over our families, those of the fans of a certain sector of Colombia - and they don't let me talk about this on the microphone, but I'm going to say it now because I know I can, if they don't cut you off before.\n\n\"This is a disaster. Our families were in danger. We had to go to the grandstand to take out our loved ones carrying little newborn babies. A disaster.\n\n\"There wasn't a single policeman in the whole half hour. A disaster. And we were the ones showing our faces for our loved ones. Hopefully, the people organizing this will be a little more careful with the families, with the people and with the surroundings of the stadiums, which is a disaster.\n\n\"Because all games are the same. Our families are suffering because of people who drink two drinks of alcohol, don't know how to drink and behave like children and can't be decent. I hope they will be careful the next game and this won't happen again because this is a disaster.\"\n\nPlayers from both squads clashed on the field after the full-time whistle.\n\nNick Tre. Our family is in danger. We had to get into the stands to take out our loved ones with small babies, newborns,\" he told TUDN. \"Everything was a disaster. There was not a single police officer.\"\n\nIt took more than 10 minutes for police to arrive on the scene and to restore order. The public address announcer asked for fans to leave the stadium, but several supporters remained.\n\nAbout 100 Uruguayan fans and and members of the federation staff remained on the field for their own protection more than 20 minutes after the game, while Colombia fans made their way out to celebrate.\n\nCONMEBOL released a statement after the game saying that it strongly condemns any act of violence that affects the game.\n\n\"Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values,\" the organization said. \"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the field.\n\n\"We invite everyone in the remaining days to pour all of their passion into cheering on their national teams and having an unforgettable party.\"\n\nUruguay coach Marcelo Bielsa said he didn't see what was happening right away.\n\n\"There was some argument in the midfield, and when I saw that happening, I went to the locker room. {"uri": "2024-07-418076491", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "02:31:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T02:31:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T22:12:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/sports/articles/2024-07-10/colombia-beats-uruguay-1-0-and-will-face-lionel-messi-and-argentina-in-copa-america-final", "title": "Colombia Beats Uruguay 1-0 and Will Face Lionel Messi and Argentina in Copa America Final", "body": "CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) -- Jefferson Lerma scored in the 39th minute, and Colombia played a man short the entire second half in a 1-0 win over Uruguay on Wednesday night to reach the Copa America final against Lionel Messi and Argentina.\n\nDaniel Mu\u00f1oz was ejected in first-half stoppage time for his second yellow card, but Colombia held on to reach the championship for the first time since winning its only Copa title as host in 2001. Colombia extended its unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games, one more than from 1992-94 and the longest current streak in men's soccer.\n\nIn a contentious match that included seven yellow cards and one red, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle and some players went into the stands to scrap with fans.\n\nDefending champion Argentina and Colombia meet Sunday night at Miami Gardens, Florida.\n\nBefore an overwhelmingly pro-Colombia crowd at Bank of America Stadium, filled with yellow jerseys and flags, Uruguay fell behind for the first time in the tournament.\n\nJames Rodr\u00edguez's corner kick was headed in from short range by Lerma, who outjumped Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez for his third international goal and second of the tournament. Rodr\u00edguez has six assists in the tournament -- triple the total of any other player.\n\nMu\u00f1oz received his first yellow card from Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos in the 31st minute for a reckless slide tackle on Maximiliano Ara\u00fajo and his second for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the stomach.\n\nRodr\u00edguez was given a yellow card in the 55th minute for arguing with Ramos when the referee failed to stop play when Richard R\u00edos was kicked on a shin by Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez.\n\nR\u00edos was removed on a stretcher, re-entered the match, then went down in another challenge and was substituted in the 62nd minute. Rodr\u00edguez was removed at the same time to keep him eligible for the final.\n\nColombia goalkeeper Federico Valverde didn't have to make his first save until he stopped Nicol\u00e1s de la Cruz in the 68th minute.\n\nLuis Su\u00e1rez, Uruguay's career leader with 68 goals, entered in the 66th minute and hit the outside of a post with a shot in the 71st.\n\nColombia's Mateus Uribe, another second-half sub, put an open shot wide in the 88th, and Uribe's open shot in the fourth minute of stoppage time ricocheted off the body of sliding goalkeeper Sergio Rochet and then the crossbar.\n\nThe match was played in 90-degree heat on a surface that was converted from artificial turf to grass in the weeks leading up the game.\n\nArgentina is seeking a record 16th Copa America title and is looking to join Spain as the only countries to win three straight major titles.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8219780845", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "04:56:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T04:56:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T04:56:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/au/football/news/darwin-nunez-uruguay-players-suspended-copa-america/6546026f651e032ee373be9a", "title": "Will Darwin Nunez, Uruguay players be suspended? What Copa America rules say about brawl with Colombian fans", "body": "Uruguay's Copa America semifinal clash with Colombia descended into madness at the blow of the final whistle, with La Celeste star Darwin Nunez among a handful of Uruguay players to head into the stands to confront Colombia fans following their 1-0 defeat to Los Cafeteros.\n\nNunez was the most prominent player to enter the stands, climbing over scaffolding to get involved in the action. He greeted one rowdy Colombian supporter (who had already thrown punches at the growing mass of Uruguayan representatives at Bank of America Stadium) with a pair of hooks and took a shot from another yellow-clad Colombian fan.\n\nUruguay captain Jose Maria Gimenez explained what compelled members of La Celeste to enter into the stands during a post-match interview with Spanish-language broadcaster TUDN, revealing that a segment of the Colombian fans created an \"avalanche\" around the players' families.\n\n\"Our families were in danger, we had to go into the stands to get our loved ones out, with small, newborn children. The policemen came after half an hour,\" Maria Jimenez said.\n\n\"We were standing up for ourselves, for our people. I hope that those who are organizing this are more careful with the families and with the [fans], it's a disaster, the same thing happens every match. Our families are suffering because of some [fans] who have two shots of alcohol and behave like children and have no decent sense of decency.\"\n\nNoble as that is, it's unclear whether such an explanation would suffice for CONMEBOL, South American soccer's governing body. Former France and Manchester United star Eric Cantona was famously handed a nine-month ban for launching a kung-fu kick toward a Crystal Palace supporter back in 1995. Could such a ruling set a precedent for Nunez and his Uruguayan teammates' actions?\n\nThe Sporting News gives you the run down on just what will happen with Nunez and the rest of the Uruguay side following Wednesday's explosive fireworks.\n\nMORE: Darwin Nunez, La Celeste players enter stands, throw punches after Copa America loss\n\nAt present, it's unknown whether Nunez and the other Uruguayan players who joined him in the bleachers will see heavy penalties -- including suspensions -- levied in their direction.\n\nChapter 15 of CONMEBOL's Copa America rule book details the governing body's outlook on handling disciplinary matters. There is no section describing the protocol if a brawl between players and fans erupts in the stands. However, Article 145 does highlight that teams found to have violated disciplinary guidelines are also \"exclusively\" liable for civil or other litigation from other soccer federations, as well as any other third party involved in the matter.\n\nGiven the number of people involved in the skirmish in Charlotte, that could represent a whole lot of third parties.\n\nFor what it's worth, CONMEBOL did condemn the clash that took place in the Bank of America stands.", "source": {"uri": "sportingnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sporting News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8219647743", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "02:32:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T02:32:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T02:31:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/sports/national-sports/2024/07/10/colombia-beats-uruguay-10-and-will-face-lionel-messi-and-argentina-in-copa-america-final/", "title": "Colombia beats Uruguay 1-0 and will face Lionel Messi and Argentina in Copa America final - Medicine Hat News", "body": "SUBSCRIBE NOW CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) - Jefferson Lerma scored in the 39th minute, and Colombia played a man short the entire second half in a 1-0 win over Uruguay on Wednesday night to reach the Copa America final against Lionel Messi and Argentina. Daniel Mu\u00c3\u00b1oz was ejected in first-half stoppage time for his second yellow card, but Colombia held on to reach the championship for the first time since winning its only Copa title as host in 2001. Colombia extended its unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games, one more than from 1992-94 and the longest current streak in men's international soccer. In a contentious match that included seven yellow cards and one red, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle and some players went into the stands to scrap with fans. Defending champion Argentina and Colombia meet Sunday night at Miami Gardens, Florida. The Albiceleste are seeking a record 16th Copa title and are looking to join Spain from 2008-12 as the only countries to win three straight major championships. Before an overwhelmingly pro-Colombia crowd of 70,644 that filled Bank of America Stadium with yellow jerseys and flags, Uruguay fell behind for the first time in the tournament. James Rodr\u00c3\u00adguez's corner kick was headed in from short range by Lerma, who outjumped Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00c3\u00ada Gim\u00e9nez for his third international goal and second of the tournament. Rodr\u00c3\u00adguez has six assists in the tournament -- triple the total of any other player. Mu\u00c3\u00b1oz received his first yellow card from Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos in the 31st minute for a reckless slide tackle on Maximiliano Ara\u00c3\u00bajo and his second for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the stomach. Rodr\u00c3\u00adguez was given a yellow card in the 55th minute for arguing with Ramos when the referee failed to stop play after Richard R\u00c3\u00ados was kicked on a shin by Darwin N\u00c3\u00ba\u00c3\u00b1ez. R\u00c3\u00ados was removed on a stretcher, re-entered the match, then went down in another challenge and was substituted in the 62nd minute. Rodr\u00c3\u00adguez was removed at the same time to keep him eligible for the final. Colombia goalkeeper Federico Valverde didn't have to make his first save until he stopped Nicol\u00c3\u00a1s de la Cruz in the 68th minute. Luis Su\u00c3\u00a1rez, Uruguay's career leader with 68 goals, entered in the 66th minute and hit the outside of a post with a shot in the 71st. He grasped his head in his hands in disgust. Colombia's Mateus Uribe, another second-half sub, put an open shot wide in the 88th, and Uribe's open shot in the fourth minute of stoppage time ricocheted off the body of sliding goalkeeper Sergio Rochet and then the crossbar. Uruguay moved Rochet up the field in the final minute, desparate for a goal. The match was played in 90-degree heat on a surface that was converted from artificial turf to grass in the weeks leading up the game. Players on the NFL's Carolina Panthers have been outspoken about soccer teams having the luxury of playing on grass on their home field. NFL games here are played artificial turf, which players say leaves them more susceptible to injuries. ___ AP Copa America coverage:", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-07-418683070", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "13:09:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T13:09:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T12:46:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/luis-suarez-blasts-colombia-after-uruguays-copa-america-defeat", "title": "Luis Suarez blasts Colombia after Uruguay's Copa America defeat", "body": "The fallout from the Uruguay Colombia Copa America semi-final continues.\n\nColombia's national football team secured a hard-fought victory over Uruguay in the Copa America semi-final. A single goal by Jefferson Lerma in the 39th minute was enough to send Colombia through to the final. However, the post-match scenes were far from celebratory, as tensions boiled over into chaos on the field.\n\nEmotions ran high as the final whistle blew, confirming Colombia's victory. Players from both teams, referees, camera crews, and officials became embroiled in a frenzied scuffle. Among the chaos, Luis Suarez was seen confronting and pushing Colombian players and staff members, clearly frustrated by his opponents' outcome and behavior.\n\nThe situation escalated further when Darwin Nunez climbed into the stands to confront Colombian fans. Shirtless and visibly enraged, Nunez exchanged punches with fans and defended himself amid a flurry of thrown drinks. The scene quickly turned into a spectacle, overshadowing Colombia's triumph.\n\nLuis Suarez speaks out on Uruguay's defeat and drama afterwards\n\nAfter the match, Luis Suarez addressed the media, expressing his frustration with the events that unfolded. \"What bothers me the most is the way they mock,\" Suarez stated. \"There are always clashes, laughs, words, whatever. But what bothers me the most is the way they mock and celebrate, it makes no sense.\"\n\nSuarez emphasized the importance of sportsmanship, comparing the situation to Uruguay's previous match against Brazil. \"We eliminated Brazil and none of us walked past any Brazilian player. On the contrary, we went to greet them. We're colleagues on the field; we know the suffering of a defeat. Walking past a fellow professional like that looks bad, but the one above sees everything and everything comes back.\"\n\nHe urged his teammates to stay strong and united despite the setback. \"As a group, we need to rise, stay strong, stay united. We will often face situations like this.\"\n\nThe governing body of South American football, CONMEBOL, has issued a statement condemning the violence that followed the game. However, it remains to be seen what specific actions will be taken against the players involved.\n\nWhile the altercation has taken some focus away from the match itself, Colombia's performance deserves recognition. Their disciplined defense and strategic play led to Lerma's decisive goal, ensuring their place in the final. The team's ability to maintain composure under pressure was key to their success.\n\nThough overshadowed by the post-match chaos, Colombia's victory has set the stage for an exciting Copa America final against Argentina, led by Lionel Messi. The final promises to be a thrilling encounter, with both teams eager to lift the coveted trophy.\n\nColombia's win over Uruguay was a significant achievement, but the scenes that followed marred the triumph. Players' actions on both sides have sparked a debate about sportsmanship and the expected behavior of professional athletes. As Colombia prepares to face Argentina in the final, the team will need to focus on their game and rise above the distractions. Football fans around the world will be eagerly watching to see who will emerge victorious in the Copa America final.\n\nThis match will test both teams' skill and character. The spotlight will be on how they handle the pressure and maintain their professionalism on the field. The Copa America final promises to be a memorable event, showcasing the best of South American football. Daniel Munoz was given a red card after elbowing Uruguay's Manuel Ugarte, reducing Colombia to ten men while holding a slim 1-0 lead in the first half of extra time. The red card, a second yellow for Munoz, added to the tension after his initial booking in the 31st minute, which followed a yellow card for Uruguay's Nicolas de la Cruz just five minutes earlier.\n\nREAD MORE: Mohamed Salah meeting Arne Slot for first time goes down exactly how Liverpool fans hoped it would\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool transfer news LIVE: Jeremie Frimpong deadline, Karim Adeyemi 'talks', Joao Neves plan\n\nThe game-defining moment came in the 39th minute, just before the red card drama when Jefferson Lerma soared to meet a cross from James Rodr\u00edguez. Lerma's header from the left side of the six-yard box found the bottom left corner, igniting Colombian celebrations as they took the lead.\n\nDespite having a numerical advantage for over half the match, Uruguay struggled to mount a meaningful offense. They managed just two shots on goal, hampered by Colombia's tenacious defense and indomitable spirit, even with a man down.\n\nWhile Nunez showed sportsmanship toward D\u00edaz after the game, the post-match scene turned fiery when he entered the stands only in his GPS vest and exchanged punches with fans as drinks flew in his direction.
