{"uri": "8219630888", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "02:12:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T02:12:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T02:11:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "url": "https://bleacherreport.com/articles/10127920-copa-america-bracket-2024-odds-predictions-for-messi-argentina-vs-colombia-final", "title": "Copa Am\u00e9rica Bracket 2024: Odds, Predictions for Messi, Argentina vs. Colombia Final", "body": "Lionel Messi and Argentina will defend their Copa America title against the team with the longest unbeaten streak in men's international soccer.\n\nArgentina meets Colombia on Sunday in Miami in what will be the first-ever Copa America final meeting between the pair of South American sides.\n\nArgentina flexed its regular level of dominance to reach the final on United States soil, but Colombia is a bit of a surprise finalist.\n\nColombia has not advanced to the Copa America since 2001, when it won its only Copa title, and had to navigate a group with Brazil and a semifinal against Uruguay.\n\nArgentina is the worthy favorite since it is the reigning Copa America and World Cup champion, but Colombia will be a frisky underdog.\n\nArgentina's perfected how to navigate a major tournament.\n\nThe Albiceleste are one win away from their third major title in the last three years. They defeated Brazil to win the 2021 Copa America and downed France in an electric 2022 FIFA World Cup title match.\n\nLionel Messi is of course the main attraction for any Argentina game, but its entire team has played well throughout the tournament.\n\nGoalkeeper Emiliano Martinez is one of the best at his position in the world and he leads a defense that allowed one goal and held four clean sheets so far at the Copa America.\n\nColombia features an equally as impressive defensive unit that held Uruguay scoreless in Wednesday's semifinal despite playing the entire second half down a man.\n\nLos Cafeteros conceded on two occasions in the tournament, once to Brazil and another time to Paraguay. They held three clean sheets and have not conceded in two knockout-round contests.\n\nColombia put up five goals on Panama in the quarterfinals, but that had more to do with the gap in overall quality in that game than what Colombia can bring to the field on Sunday.\n\nLiverpool's Luis Diaz and James Rodriguez are the most dangerous players for Colombia, and while they can be dangerous in attack, they lack experience in an international final with their national team.\n\nArgentina has a roster full of battle-tested players and that could be a massive advantage for the reigning Copa champion if the game is close going into the second half.\n\nColombia will likely play with no pressure because of its underdog role, but if it falls behind, it may not have an answer for Argentina.\n\nHistory is not on Colombia's side either. It has a single win in its last 12 meetings with Argentina and it only owns a single Copa title from 2001.\n\nThree of the last four Copa America finals had less than two goals in regulation and two of them went to penalties, so expect a tight affair in which one moment of brilliance, potentially from Messi, makes the difference.\n\nIf you or someone you know has a gambling problem, crisis counseling and referral services can be accessed by calling 1-800-GAMBLER (1-800-426-2537) (IL/IN/MI/NJ/PA/WV/WY), 1-800-NEXT STEP (AZ), 1-800-522-4700 (CO/NH), 888-789-7777/visiting ccpg.org/chat (CT), 1-800-BETS OFF (IA), 1-877-770-STOP (7867) (LA), visiting OPGR.org (OR), or calling/texting TN REDLINE 1-800-889-9789 (TN) or 1-888-532-3500 (VA).\n\nOdds and lines subject to change. 21+ (18+ NH/WY). Colombia extended its unbeaten streak to a team record 28 games, one more than from 1992-94 and the longest current streak in men's soccer.\n\nIn a contentious match that included seven yellow cards and one red, players from both teams pushed and shoved in a scrum on the field at the final whistle and some players went into the stands to scrap with fans.\n\nDefending champion Argentina and Colombia meet Sunday night at Miami Gardens, Florida.\n\nBefore an overwhelmingly pro-Colombia crowd at Bank of America Stadium, filled with yellow jerseys and flags, Uruguay fell behind for the first time in the tournament.\n\nJames Rodr\u00edguez's corner kick was headed in from short range by Lerma, who outjumped Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez for his third international goal and second of the tournament. Rodr\u00edguez has six assists in the tournament -- triple the total of any other player.\n\nMu\u00f1oz received his first yellow card from Mexican referee C\u00e9sar Ramos in the 31st minute for a reckless slide tackle on Maximiliano Ara\u00fajo and his second for elbowing Manuel Ugarte in the stomach.\n\nRodr\u00edguez was given a yellow card in the 55th minute for arguing with Ramos when the referee failed to stop play when Richard R\u00edos was kicked on a shin by Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez.\n\nR\u00edos was removed on a stretcher, re-entered the match, then went down in another challenge and was substituted in the 62nd minute. Rodr\u00edguez was removed at the same time to keep him eligible for the final.\n\nColombia goalkeeper Federico Valverde didn't have to make his first save until he stopped Nicol\u00e1s de la Cruz in the 68th minute.\n\nLuis Su\u00e1rez, Uruguay's career leader with 68 goals, entered in the 66th minute and hit the outside of a post with a shot in the 71st.\n\nColombia's Mateus Uribe, another second-half sub, put an open shot wide in the 88th, and Uribe's open shot in the fourth minute of stoppage time ricocheted off the body of sliding goalkeeper Sergio Rochet and then the crossbar.\n\nThe match was played in 90-degree heat on a surface that was converted from artificial turf to grass in the weeks leading up the game.\n\nArgentina is seeking a record 16th Copa America While playing for Ajax in 2010, the Uruguayan bit PSV player Otman Bakkal on the shoulder, resulting in a seven-game suspension.\n\nA few years later, while at Liverpool, Suarez then picked up a ban of ten matches after he bit Chelsea defender Branislav Ivanovic. {"uri": "8219601398", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "01:35:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T01:35:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T01:35:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4313725531101227, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/darwin-nunez-outburst-speaks-volumes-33216403", "title": "Darwin Nunez outburst speaks volumes as Liverpool star feels pressure", "body": "Uruguay's striker Darwin Nunez, had a tough first half in the Copa America semi-final against Colombia, missing two golden opportunities - and a frustrated outburst after one miss indicated he knew how important they might be.\n\nThe Liverpool forward managed to bypass the Colombian defence and found himself one-on-one with goalkeeper Camilo Vargas. However, he lacked the necessary composure and sent his shot wide of the bottom-left corner after 22 minutes.\n\nShortly after, Nunez was through again but hurried his effort and sent it over the bar. Nunez appeared to be in disbelief following his second crucial miss, having earlier expressed his anger after squandering a significant opportunity.\n\nAs he spun away in frustration, he screamed as it became clear he was feeling the pressure of leading the line for Uruguay in an enormous game, knowing Lionel Messi and Argentina await in the final. Within the first 30 minutes, Nunez had taken all four of Uruguay's shots but failed to challenge Vargas on any occasion.\n\nEntering the semi-final, Nunez had scored two goals in four games at Copa America for Uruguay and was on a scoring spree ahead of the tournament. He had netted in seven consecutive games for Uruguay, totalling eight in ten, but his visibly frustrated reaction suggested he was perhaps feeling the pressure of the occasion.\n\nThe Liverpool forward had scored in Uruguay's first two games of Copa America, securing victories over Panama and Bolivia. Despite failing to score in a 1-0 win over the United States men's national team, he is still considered a superior option to Luis Suarez by head coach Marcelo Bielsa.\n\nMany supporters have been torn on Nunez since Liverpool club-record move from Benfica in 2022. He's netted 20 times in 65 Premier League matches.\n\nDespite showing signs of being a top-tier striker, Nunez has been ridiculed by opposing fans for squandering key opportunities. He always seems to be in the right spot but occasionally lacks the killer instinct when presented with a golden chance.\n\nSince making his Premier League debut, Nunez has taken 192 shots in 65 games, with 83 hitting the mark. While 20 of those on-target attempts have found the back of the net, he's missed 47 significant chances.\n\nOn average, Nunez misses a major opportunity every 0.72 matches, but he's also had a run of bad luck. No other player has hit the woodwork more than Nunez (14) since he arrived in England.\n\nFans are optimistic that new Liverpool manager Arne Slot can bring out the best in Nunez next season. His Copa America exploits are sure to have boosted his confidence before returning to pre-season - but the semi-final was a frustrating end to a tournament which saw him shoulder plenty of responsibility for his national side.", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Mirror"}, "authors": [{"uri": "rich_jones@mirror.co.uk", "name": "Rich Jones", "type": "author", Players from the Uruguay team claimed that rival fans threatened family members watching the game, which prompted the players to climb into the stands. Among the participants were one of Uruguay's star players, Darwin N\u00fa\u00f1ez, and team captain Jose Maria Gimenez.\n\nGimenez claimed the fans were the aggressors and that the players entered the stands to protect and defend their families.\n\n\"Let me say something before they cut you off because they won't let us speak into the microphone. They don't want me to say anything about what's going on, but this is a disaster,\" Gimenez said after the skirmish in the stands. \"Please be careful, our families are in the stands, there are little newborn babies. It was a disaster. There was no police, and we had to defend our families.\"\n\n\"This is the fault of two or three people who had a few too many drinks and don't know how to drink,\" Gimenez said.\n\nCONMEBOL, the organizers of the Copa Cup, the governing body of South American football, condemned the incident and announced it was launching an investigation into the skirmish.\n\n\"CONMEBOL strongly condemns any act of violence that affects football,\" the organization said in a released statement after the game. \"Our work is based on the conviction that soccer connects and unites us through its positive values.\"\n\nThere was also a confrontation between players from both teams on the pitch after the game ended. It was the culmination of a tense, highly competitive match between the teams of the South American countries.\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE WASHINGTON EXAMINER\n\nMarcelo Bielsa, Uruguay's coach, discussed the altercation in a press conference after the game. He acknowledged the hostilities between the players but thought it ended once the game was over.\n\n\"I thought that the incident ended with some argument on the midfield, and when I saw that happening, I went to the locker room,\" Bielsa said. \"I thought that they were thanking the fans for their support. {"uri": "8220749044", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-11", "time": "15:37:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-11T15:37:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-11T15:37:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://whdh.com/news/colombia-advances-to-copa-america-final-as-tempers-flare-post-match/", "title": "Colombia advances to Copa Am\u00e9rica final as tempers flare post-match - Boston News, Weather, Sports | WHDH 7News", "body": "(CNN) -- Colombia advanced to the Copa Am\u00e9rica final following a 1-0 win over Uruguay at Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, North Carolina, on Wednesday, but the game was marred by unsavory scenes after full-time.\n\nJefferson Lerma scored the match's only goal in the 39th minute as Los Cafeteros extended their unbeaten streak to 28 matches.\n\nThe match was testy and featured seven yellow cards and one red card after Colombia's Daniel Mu\u00f1oz was ejected in the first half after being shown a second yellow card.\n\nTempers flared even more after the match.\n\nAfter the final whistle, players from both squads got into it at center field before the Fox Sports 1 broadcast showed Uruguayan players entering the stands and getting into a scuffle with fans.\n\nA 'disaster'\n\nUruguay captain Jos\u00e9 Mar\u00eda Gim\u00e9nez said after the match that players were trying to defend their families and called the incident with fans a \"disaster.\"\n\n\"Let me tell you something: they should have been careful because there are families in the grandstand,\" Gimenez told the official broadcaster in Spanish.\n\n\"And if there is an avalanche falling over our families, those of the fans of a certain sector of Colombia - and they don't let me talk about this on the microphone, but I'm going to say it now because I know I can, if they don't cut you off before.\n\n\"This is a disaster. Our families were in danger. We had to go to the grandstand to take out our loved ones carrying little newborn babies. A disaster.\n\n\"There wasn't a single policeman in the whole half hour. A disaster. And we were the ones showing our faces for our loved ones. Hopefully, the people organizing this will be a little more careful with the families, with the people and with the surroundings of the stadiums, which is a disaster.\n\n\"Because all games are the same. Our families are suffering because of people who drink two drinks of alcohol, don't know how to drink and behave like children and can't be decent. I hope they will be careful the next game and this won't happen again because this is a disaster.\"\n\nSouth America's football governing body - CONMEBOL - said it \"emphatically condemns\" the incident.\n\n\"Our work begins with the conviction that football connects us and unites us, through its positive values,\" it said in a statement after the game.\n\n\"There is no place for intolerance and violence on and off the pitch.\n\n\"We invite everyone in the days that remain to throw all their passion to support their national teams and have an unforgettable party.\"\n\nCNN has reached out to the Uruguayan Football Association (UFA), while the Charlotte Police Department declined to comment.\n\nColombia, which has won the tournament once in its history back in 2001, will face Lionel Messi and Argentina in the final on Sunday at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Florida.\n\n(Copyright (c) 2024 CNN.
